content.question: Choose the correct statement about the stall of a straight wing aeroplane:

options.A: The nose down effect is the result of increasing downwash, due to flow separation.
options.B: Just before the stall the aeroplane will have a nose-down tendency.
options.C: The horizontal tail will stall at a higher speed than the wing.
options.D: Buffeting is the result of flow separation on the tail plane.

key_points: For a straight wing, just before the stall the CP will move aft away from CG
Thus creating a nose pitch down moment
For a swept wing, just before the stall, the CP will move forward in front of the CG
learning.explanation: For a straight wing, just before the stall the CP will move aft away from CG. Thus creating a nose pitch down moment. For a swept wing, just before the stall, the CP will move forward in front of the CG. Generating a nose pitch up moment

content.question: During a flight, the stall warning goes off and the pilot does not notice it. What happens in a full stall?

options.A: The aircraft nose rises even though the elevator is deflected fully downwards.
options.B: The aircraft nose will remain the same if the elevator is neutral.
options.C: Nose drops even though the elevator is deflected fully upwards.
options.D: The aircraft nose drops and then will rise independently of the elevator position.

key_points: STALL
A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift
Impending Stall—an impending stall occurs when the AOA causes a stall warning, but has not yet reached the critical AOA
learning.explanation: STALL. A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift. Impending Stall—an impending stall occurs when the AOA causes a stall warning, but has not yet reached the critical AOA. Indications of an impending stall can include buffeting, stick shaker, or aural warning. Full Stall—a full stall occurs when the critical AOA is exceeded. Indications of a full stall are typically that an uncommanded nose-down pitch cannot be readily arrested, and this may be accompanied by an uncommanded rolling motion. For airplanes equipped with stick pushers, its activation is also a full stall indication. The longer it takes for the pilot to recognize an impending stall, the more likely it is that a full stall will result. A stalled wing may be accompanied by one or more of the following: Buffet Poor pitch authority poor roll control (unresponsive flight controls). An inability to arrest descent.

content.question: The critical angle of attack:

options.A: changes with an increase in gross weight.
options.B: remains unchanged regardless of gross weight.
options.C: decreases if the CG is moved aft.
options.D: increases if the CG is moved forward.

key_points: There is a certain angle of attack (AOA), at which the flow cannot follow the shape of the profile, the flow separates from the surface and vortices are created
This results in a smaller suction, smaller lift and high drag
If AOA is increased further beyond this AOA, lift will reduce
learning.explanation: There is a certain angle of attack (AOA), at which the flow cannot follow the shape of the profile, the flow separates from the surface and vortices are created. This results in a smaller suction, smaller lift and high drag. If AOA is increased further beyond this AOA, lift will reduce. This angle of attack is called critical angle of attack. The critical angle of attack will remain the same regardless of gross weight. A given wing will always stall at the same AOA, regardless of Weight, Loadfactor, Density Altitude and airspeed. However, increased weight, a higher load factor and increased density altitude do increase the airspeed at which the aircraft reaches its critical AOA.

content.question: High-speed buffet is induced by:

options.A: the bow wave in front of the wing.
options.B: boundary layer control.
options.C: interaction between flow separation and shock wave motion.
options.D: a shift of the centre of gravity.

key_points: High-speed buffet is the rapid movement of the control surfaces caused by turbulent airflow passing over them
It can only occur when the Mach number is above the critical Mach number and is likely to be accompanied by a tendency for the airplane to pitch nose-down
The maximum operating altitude of an airplane can be restricted by the load factor
learning.explanation: High-speed buffet is the rapid movement of the control surfaces caused by turbulent airflow passing over them. It can only occur when the Mach number is above the critical Mach number and is likely to be accompanied by a tendency for the airplane to pitch nose-down. The maximum operating altitude of an airplane can be restricted by the load factor. Above that altitude any turbulence may induce Mach buffet, which could cause the airplane to exceed the maximum permitted load factor. The airflow behind a shockwave is turbulent and can cause a rapid vibrating movement of the horizontal stabilizer surfaces and is often referred to as the ‘shock stall’ and is the primary cause of high-speed buffet. A secondary cause of the rapid movement of the control surfaces, especially with supercritical airfoil sections, is when the wing reaches a speed of MCRIT the relatively weak shockwave that forms moves rapidly backward and forward over the surface of the wing producing similar indications to those of the shock stall.

content.question: Which statement about negative tail stall is correct?

options.A: When negative tail stall occurs, the aeroplane will show an uncontrollable pitch-up moment.
options.B: When negative tail stall occurs, the aeroplane will show an uncontrollable pitch-down moment.
options.C: Negative tail stall is a stall of the fin with a negative sideslip angle (nose pointing to the right of the relative airflow).
options.D: Negative tail stall is a stall of the tailplane when the aerodynamic force is in upward direction.

key_points: The tailplane is a smaller lifting surface found aft of the main wing, on the tail of many fixed wing aircraft
Like the main wing, a tailplane is designed to operate with smooth airflow along its surface
When the airflow separates from the tailplane, this is referred to as a tailplane stall
learning.explanation: The tailplane is a smaller lifting surface found aft of the main wing, on the tail of many fixed wing aircraft. Like the main wing, a tailplane is designed to operate with smooth airflow along its surface. When the airflow separates from the tailplane, this is referred to as a tailplane stall. The tailplane is designed to produce a downward force (resulting in "negative" lift). When the tailplane stalls, this downforce will no longer exist, resulting in a sudden uncommanded nose down pitching moment.

content.question: If an aircraft enters a fully developed spin, what should be the pilot's first action?

options.A: Wing levelled
options.B: Full opposite rudder
options.C: Elevator down
options.D: Power idle

key_points: SPIN RECOVERY Although the POH is the primary reference for recovery from a spin, the following can be used as a general procedure: P - Retard the throttle to idle
In most aircraft, power hampers the recovery
A - Ailerons neutral
learning.explanation: SPIN RECOVERY Although the POH is the primary reference for recovery from a spin, the following can be used as a general procedure: P - Retard the throttle to idle. In most aircraft, power hampers the recovery. A - Ailerons neutral. Many pilots will attempt to recover from the spin using the ailerons. This may actually make the problem worse. R - Apply full opposite rudder. Apply rudder opposite the rotation of the spin. If you have trouble determining which way the airplane is spinning, look at your turn coordinator or turn needle. It will indicate the direction of rotation. E - Apply forward elevator. Immediately after applying opposite rudder, apply a quick forward motion on the control yoke and hold anti-spin controls until the aircraft starts to recover. D - Recover from the dive. Once you have completed the four previous steps, and the rotation stops, recover from the dive. The descent rate may be over 5000 feet per minute and the airspeed will rapidly exceed redline. Remember to neutralize the rudder after the rotation stops.

content.question: Behind the transition point in a boundary layer:

options.A: the mean speed increases and the friction drag decreases.
options.B: the boundary layer gets thicker and the mean speed decreases.
options.C: the boundary layer gets thinner and the mean speed increases.
options.D: the mean speed and friction drag increase.

key_points: The boundary layer is the layer of fluid (in our case this fluid is the atmosphere) in the immediate surface of a bounding surface (the airfoil) where the effects of viscosity are significant
There are two types of boundary layer; the laminar and the turbulent boundary layer
In the laminar boundary layer, the flow moves parallel to the surface over which it flows
learning.explanation: The boundary layer is the layer of fluid (in our case this fluid is the atmosphere) in the immediate surface of a bounding surface (the airfoil) where the effects of viscosity are significant. There are two types of boundary layer; the laminar and the turbulent boundary layer. In the laminar boundary layer, the flow moves parallel to the surface over which it flows. In the laminar boundary layer, the air flows very smoothly. The velocity increases with distance from the airfoil and there is no movement of air perpendicular to the surface of the airfoil. Laminar flow creates less friction drag than the turbulent flow, but is less stable. At a distance from the leading edge of the airfoil, the air transitions from a laminar flow to a turbulent flow. This is called the transition point. This air does not flow smoothly, it contains swirls. There is flow in parallel and perpendicular direction. This air creates more drag than the laminar air flow, has more kinetic energy (higher mean speed) and breaks down less easily and is therefore more stable.

content.question: A medium range jet transport aeroplane is flying straight and level when an upgust increases the load factor to 1.5 g. If the straight and level stall speed (VS) is 172 kt, what will VS be during the gust encounter?

options.A: 258 kt
options.B: 211 kt
options.C: 272 kt
options.D: 140 kt

key_points: The load factor is the actual lift divided by the weight, and lift is proportional to airspeed²
A load factor of 1
5 describes an increase in lift to a new value of 1
learning.explanation: The load factor is the actual lift divided by the weight, and lift is proportional to airspeed². A load factor of 1.5 describes an increase in lift to a new value of 1.5 × lift. Therefore we can calculate this question by the following formula: (VNEW ÷ VOLD)² = n Where VOLD = 172kt and n = 1.5g √n = VNEW ÷ VOLD VNEW = √n × VOLD VNEW = √1.5 × 172 kt VNEW = 211 kt The gust encounter will cause an increase in the stall speed (VS) to 211kt.

content.question: On the base leg of a a circuit to land, the pilot is distracted by the warning of an alternator failure, but elects to continue the approach, immediately turning onto final. During the final turn the pilot feels that the aircraft bank angle is difficult to maintain, that the ailerons and elevator are lighter and NOT as effective as usual. These symptoms are most likely related to…

options.A: a sign of loose control lines.
options.B: caused by the engine losing power.
options.C: an indication of a control restriction.
options.D: a warning of an incipient stall.

key_points: When the lift developed by an aeroplane wing is no longer sufficient to sustain the mass of the aeroplane in flight, in the configuration being considered, the wing is stalled
A stall is caused by airflow separation
Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great
learning.explanation: When the lift developed by an aeroplane wing is no longer sufficient to sustain the mass of the aeroplane in flight, in the configuration being considered, the wing is stalled. A stall is caused by airflow separation. Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great. STALLING ANGLE OF ATTACK At a constant mass and air density, the coefficient of lift (CL), and consequently the total amount of lift, is dependent on the angle of attack. Graphically, lift increases almost linearly from an angle of attack of 0º to 4º, and then at an increasing rate to 15º. Lift cannot be obtained without incurring the penalty of drag. At a specific angle of attack, depending on circumstances, the lift generated is insufficient to sustain the aircraft in level flight. The angle of attack at which this occurs is the stalling angle or critical angle and is the point at which CLMAX is attained. An aeroplane will not stall unless the critical angle is exceeded. The aeroplane may be considered stalled when the behaviour of the aeroplane gives a clear distinctive indication of an unacceptable nature to the pilot that the aeroplane is stalled. Acceptable indications of a stall, occurring either individually or in combination are: a. A nose-down pitch that cannot be readily arrested. b. Buffeting, of a magnitude and severity that is a strong and effective deterrent to further speed reduction. c. The pitch control reaches the aft stop and no further increase in pitch attitude occurs when the control is held full aft for a short time before recovery is initiated. d. Unresponsive flight controls.

content.question: Which CG position contributes to flat spin?

options.A: Within the range of CG (both for and aft limit).
options.B: The CG position does not matter.
options.C: Forward CG.
options.D: Aft CG.

key_points: Flat spins are the worst and most dangerous type of spin
In a flat spin, the aircraft has no forward airspeed
It spins around its vertical axis as it sinks straight towards the ground
learning.explanation: Flat spins are the worst and most dangerous type of spin. In a flat spin, the aircraft has no forward airspeed. It spins around its vertical axis as it sinks straight towards the ground. Due to the high angle of attack of a flat spin, it is nearly impossible to recover, as the horizontal stabilizer is most likely in stall, too. The only possibility then is to move the CG forward. In small aircraft what you can do is to lean forward and hope for the best. The type of spin a plane enters depends mainly on the CG Position (and thrust setting): CG towards the forward limit makes an aircraft more stable, and control forces will be higher which makes it less likely that large, abrupt control movements will be made. When trimmed, the aeroplane will tend to return to level flight if the controls are released, but the stall speed will be higher. CG towards the aft limit decreases longitudinal static stability and reduces pitch control forces, which tends to make the aeroplane easier to stall. Once a spin is entered, the further aft the CG, the flatter the spin attitude. All in all, do not spin with an aircraft that is not designed for that or with too aft CG position. Note: Watch the following video to understand the attitude of the aircraft during a flat spin https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=22eADnRqMwo&t=16s

content.question: Located on the underside of a wing’s leading edge, Vortilons produce a vortex on the wing’s…

options.A: lower surface, at low angles of attack, to provide improved roll control.
options.B: upper surface, at cruise angles of attack, to keep the boundary layer attached to the wing.
options.C: lower surface, at high angles of attack, to keep the boundary layer attached to the wing.
options.D: upper surface, at high angles of attack, to reduce the spanwise flow of air.

key_points: WING FENCE (figure 1) Wing fences (boundary layer fences), are thin metal fences which generally extend from the leading edge to the trailing edge on the top surface and are intended to prevent outward drift of the boundary layer
VORTILON (figure 2) Vortilons, are also thin metal fences, but are smaller than a full chordwise fence
They are situated on the underside of the wing leading edge
learning.explanation: WING FENCE (figure 1) Wing fences (boundary layer fences), are thin metal fences which generally extend from the leading edge to the trailing edge on the top surface and are intended to prevent outward drift of the boundary layer. VORTILON (figure 2) Vortilons, are also thin metal fences, but are smaller than a full chordwise fence. They are situated on the underside of the wing leading edge. The support pylons of pod mounted engines on the wing also act in the same way. At high angles of attack a small but intense vortex is shed over the wing top surface which acts as an aerodynamic wing fence - minimizing spanwise flow of the boundary layer.

content.question: Which of these statements about boundary layers is correct?

options.A: A laminar boundary layer is thicker than a turbulent one.
options.B: A turbulent boundary layer produces less friction drag than a laminar one.
options.C: A turbulent boundary layer becomes laminar at the transition point.
options.D: Compared with a laminar boundary layer, a turbulent boundary layer is better able to resist a positive pressure gradient before it separates.

key_points: Due to the higher average velocity of the turbulent boundary layer compared to the laminar boundary layer, the turbulent boundary layer has more energy that will better able to resist the adverse pressure gradient
Therefore the turbulent layer separates much later than the laminar boundary layer
This is why vortex generators are commonly used on general aviation aircraft to create a larger area of turbulent air on the wing
learning.explanation: Due to the higher average velocity of the turbulent boundary layer compared to the laminar boundary layer, the turbulent boundary layer has more energy that will better able to resist the adverse pressure gradient. Therefore the turbulent layer separates much later than the laminar boundary layer. This is why vortex generators are commonly used on general aviation aircraft to create a larger area of turbulent air on the wing. This will lead to an increase in critical angle of attack and decrease the stall speed. The other answers were incorrect because: “Laminar boundary layer is thicker than a turbulent one” is incorrect because as you can see in the diagram, the turbulent boundary layer is thicker. “A turbulent boundary layer produces less friction drag than a laminar one” is incorrect because a turbulent boundary layer produces more friction than a laminar boundary layer. “A turbulent boundary layer becomes laminar at the transition point” is incorrect because turbulent air will not by nature turn into laminar air. However, laminar air does turn into turbulent air at the transition point as seen on the diagram.

content.question: Some aeroplanes experience natural buffet whilst in a pre-stall condition. What causes this?

options.A: The centre of pressure moving aft just prior to the stall.
options.B: Separated turbulent airflow on the main wing interacting with the ailerons.
options.C: Separated turbulent airflow from the main wing encountering the tail.
options.D: The centre of pressure moving forward just prior to the stall.

key_points: The buffet experienced by some aircraft just before the stall comes from the fact that some of the wing has already begun to stall, and the boundary layer has separated from the wing (usually near the wing root) close to the trailing edge on the upper side
The area behind the separation point is now stalled, incredibly turbulent airflow, and this flows backwards with the rest of the airflow, hitting the horizontal stabiliser (tailplane)
This turbulent flow hitting the tailplane and elevator is the primary cause of the natural buffeting felt in some aeroplanes
learning.explanation: The buffet experienced by some aircraft just before the stall comes from the fact that some of the wing has already begun to stall, and the boundary layer has separated from the wing (usually near the wing root) close to the trailing edge on the upper side. The area behind the separation point is now stalled, incredibly turbulent airflow, and this flows backwards with the rest of the airflow, hitting the horizontal stabiliser (tailplane). This turbulent flow hitting the tailplane and elevator is the primary cause of the natural buffeting felt in some aeroplanes. If an aircraft does not present with natural buffeting before the stall, then stall warners or stick shakers will be fitted to warn of the impending stall. As for the other options: The centre of pressure does move aft during the stall of most wings, which helps provide the necessary pitch down moment to break the stall and begin recovery, however, it is not the cause of any buffeting. A stall occurring over the section of the wing with ailerons would cause aileron buffeting through the controls, but this means the wing is completely stalled, not pre-stall, as the wing root is designed to stall first, and the wing tips are designed to stall last, to preserve aileron effectiveness in the stall and prevent wing drops.

content.question: What should you do if you encounter a thunderstorm during your cruise that you cannot circumnavigate?

options.A: Climb above the thunderstorm.
options.B: Descend to a lower altitude to avoid the thunderstorm.
options.C: Fly at turbulence penetration speed.
options.D: Increase airspeed to pass through the thunderstorm quickly.

key_points: Turbulence Penetration Speed For flight in turbulence an airspeed must be chosen to give margin against stalling and overstressing the aircraft structure
This speed is VRA/MRA (the rough-air speed) or turbulence penetration speed
VRA/MRA will give adequate protection from over-stressing the aircraft with maximum protection from an inadvertent stall
learning.explanation: Turbulence Penetration Speed For flight in turbulence an airspeed must be chosen to give margin against stalling and overstressing the aircraft structure. This speed is VRA/MRA (the rough-air speed) or turbulence penetration speed. VRA/MRA will give adequate protection from over-stressing the aircraft with maximum protection from an inadvertent stall. Thunderstorms should be circumnavigated and preferably upwind. Extensive use of weather radar scanning is useful. A turbulence penetration speed should be selected to minimise the gust loads on the aircraft. When possible, descent to a lower altitude should be considered as it gives more performance and buffet margin to cope with gusts.

content.question: Vortilons that are attached to the underside of a wing:

options.A: Create a vortex, at low angles of attack, to keep the boundary layer attached to the wing.
options.B: Re-energises the flow on the underside of the wing.
options.C: Improve low speed handling characteristics.
options.D: Minimises turbulent wake behind the wing.

key_points: Vortilons are fixed aerodynamic devices on aircraft wings used to improve handling at low speeds
They are situated on the underside of the wing leading edge
When the wing approaches stall, span-wise flow starts to flow across the vortilons which start to generate a vortex
learning.explanation: Vortilons are fixed aerodynamic devices on aircraft wings used to improve handling at low speeds. They are situated on the underside of the wing leading edge. When the wing approaches stall, span-wise flow starts to flow across the vortilons which start to generate a vortex. The vortex energises the boundary layer over the wing. The turbulent flow in the boundary layer delays the flow separation resulting in increased controllability of the airplane in stall. During high airspeeds (low angle of attack) vortilons have minimum drag as they are streamlined with the airflow and don’t generate any vortex. Vortilons help to improve aileron performance at high angles of attack and thus improve the spin resistance of the airplane.

content.question:
Which of the following may cause buffeting when flying through Clear Air Turbulence?
1. Mach variations,
2. Precipitation distorting the airflow,
3. Reduced mach margins at altitude,
4. Autopilot disengagement.

options.A: 1 and 3
options.B: 3 and 4
options.C: 2 and 4
options.D: 1 and 2

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting
Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure
Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage
learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. The aircraft must therefore be operated in such a manner that a (safety) margin exists before aerodynamic buffet will occur. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved. This is called a ‘Buffet Onset’ chart which is used by flight crews to ensure their aircraft is always operated with a specified minimum buffet margin. For any given combination of mass, center of gravity position and airspeed, the maximum operating altitude is that altitude at which a normal positive acceleration increment of 0.3 g, without exceeding the buffet onset boundary, is possible. Note: Flying in turbulent conditions may cause sudden changes in speed and load factor. Looking at the buffet margin graph attached, we can conclude that both speed/mach variations and changes in load factor may bring the aircraft closer to one of the buffet margins.

content.question: An aircraft is in a steady climb to high altitude at a constant thrust setting. The autopilot is set to maintain constant vertical speed. The danger associated with this autopilot selection is:

options.A: The risk of a stall at high altitude.
options.B: The risk of exceeding MMO.
options.C: The risk of exceeding VMO.
options.D: The risk of exceeding VNE.

key_points: The autopilot's vertical speed mode allows you to perform constant-rate climbs and descents
In this mode, the vertical speed is prioritised over airspeed

When you engage the vertical speed mode, the FD/autopilot will attempt to maintain the specified vertical speed until you choose a different setting in autopilot, the aircraft reaches an assigned altitude set into the assigned altitude selector/alerter, or the autopilot is disconnected
learning.explanation: The autopilot's vertical speed mode allows you to perform constant-rate climbs and descents. In this mode, the vertical speed is prioritised over airspeed. When you engage the vertical speed mode, the FD/autopilot will attempt to maintain the specified vertical speed until you choose a different setting in autopilot, the aircraft reaches an assigned altitude set into the assigned altitude selector/alerter, or the autopilot is disconnected. As altitude increases and the air gets thinner, the IAS will reduce for a given pitch setting. Consequently, the angle of attack also reduces. As a result, the vertical speed will reduce for a certain pitch attitude. The autopilot will therefore chase the selected vertical speed by pitching up. This results in further decreased IAS. Ultimately, this could lead to a stall.

content.question: A jet aeroplane is cruising at high altitude with a Mach number that provides a buffet margin of 0.3 g. In order to increase the buffet margin to 0.4 g the pilot must:

options.A: fly at a larger angle of attack.
options.B: fly at a higher Mach number.
options.C: fly at a lower altitude and the same Mach number.
options.D: extend the flaps to the first selection.

key_points: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor
In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range
The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries
learning.explanation: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor. In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range. The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries. The margin between the two types of stall narrows with increasing altitude. Notably the true airspeed of the low-speed stall increases with increasing altitude for a given indicated airspeed, whilst the true airspeed of the shock stall reduces up to the base of the tropopause, above which it remains constant. The point at which the two stalls coincide is referred to as the 'coffin corner'. The altitude at which an aircraft can fly at one airspeed in a 1 g maneuver is called the aerodynamic ceiling. Since this condition has no safety margin, aircraft must be operated within a buffet margin of 0.3 g. If this safety margin is to be increased, the aircraft must be flown at a lower altitude.

options.A: in steady wings level horizontal flight.
options.B: when weight is greater than lift.

options.D: during a steady horizontal turn.

The correct symbol for load factor is (n), but it is colloquially known as (g)
Load Factor = Lift / Weight Certain maneuvers require the aircraft weight to be greater than the lift force
learning.explanation: Load Factor - The ratio of the weight of an aircraft to the load imposed by lift. The correct symbol for load factor is (n), but it is colloquially known as (g). Load Factor = Lift / Weight Certain maneuvers require the aircraft weight to be greater than the lift force. For example, weight is greater than lift in a steady climb or descent. In this case, Load Factor is less than 1.

content.question: How will an increase in weight affect Critical Alpha?

options.A: It is only changed under increased load factor.
options.B: It has no effect on critical alpha.
options.C: Critical alpha decreases.
options.D: Critical alpha increases.

key_points: STALL An aircraft stalls when the streamlined/laminar airflow (or boundary layer) over the wing's upper surface, which produces lift, breaks away from the surface when the critical angle of attack is exceeded, irrespective of airspeed, and becomes turbulent, causing a loss in lift
The only way to recover is to decrease the angle of attack
An aircraft will stall at a constant angle of attack (critical angle of attack)
learning.explanation: STALL An aircraft stalls when the streamlined/laminar airflow (or boundary layer) over the wing's upper surface, which produces lift, breaks away from the surface when the critical angle of attack is exceeded, irrespective of airspeed, and becomes turbulent, causing a loss in lift. The only way to recover is to decrease the angle of attack. An aircraft will stall at a constant angle of attack (critical angle of attack). The Critical angle of attack depends on the aerodynamic design of a wing, and it is independent of other factors, namely weight. Because most aircraft do not have angle of attack indicators, the pilot has to rely on airspeed indications. However, the speed at which the aircraft will stall is variable depending on the effects of the following properties: Weight, Actual weight, Load factor (g in a turn), Effective weight/center of gravity position, Altitude, Wing design/lift, Configuration and Propeller engine power.

content.question: After recovering from a spin, while trying to maintain straight and level flight, the pilot accidentally applies excessive aft pressure on the elevator. This action may lead to...

options.A: a secondary spin in the opposite direction.
options.B: a secondary stall and/or exceedance of load factor.
options.C: a loss of directional control and yaw instability.
options.D: increased lift and climb rate.

key_points: The options here are not brilliant but there is certainly one that is more correct than the others
In a spin, the aircraft is stalled but not evenly, and the inside wing has a higher angle of attack so is stalled more than the outside wing, creating a continuous spiraling stall, called a spin
The way to recover from a stall is given in the POH, but a general rule for most aircraft is as follows
learning.explanation: The options here are not brilliant but there is certainly one that is more correct than the others. In a spin, the aircraft is stalled but not evenly, and the inside wing has a higher angle of attack so is stalled more than the outside wing, creating a continuous spiraling stall, called a spin. The way to recover from a stall is given in the POH, but a general rule for most aircraft is as follows. P - Retard the throttle to idle. In most aircraft, power hampers the recovery. A - Ailerons neutral. Many pilots will attempt to recover from the spin using the ailerons. This may actually make the problem worse. R - Apply full opposite rudder. Apply rudder opposite the rotation of the spin. If you have trouble determining which way the airplane is spinning, look at your turn coordinator or turn needle. It will indicate the direction of rotation. E - Apply forward elevator. Immediately after applying opposite rudder, apply a quick forward motion on the control yoke and hold anti-spin controls until the aircraft starts to recover. D - Recover from the dive. Once you have completed the four previous steps, and the rotation stops, recover from the dive. The descent rate may be over 5000 feet per minute and the airspeed will rapidly exceed redline. Remember to neutralize the rudder after the rotation stops. The application of aft elevator pressure could quite easily send the aircraft into a further stall/spin, as this would try to continue increasing the angle of attack. However, if the aircraft becomes fully unstalled, then this action may actually take the aircraft into a spiral dive instead and potentially overload the wings with high load factor. As for the other options, a secondary spin in the other direction usually comes from continuing to apply rudder after recovering (with too low airspeed) and yaw instability is not related to this scenario. The aircraft is also descending through this process, so no climb rate should be expected.

content.question: A turbojet aeroplane in straight and level flight is cruising at FL290. For a given mass and CG position, how will the high-speed buffet and low-speed buffet as an IAS vary when the flight is operated at FL330?

options.B: The low-speed buffet decreases and the high-speed buffet increases.
options.C: Both the low-speed buffet and high-speed buffet increase.
options.D: The low-speed buffet increases and the high-speed buffet decreases.

key_points: Before the days of FMS, the buffet boundary was displayed on a chart
The buffet boundary has both low and high speed limits: The low speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of the pre-stall buffet at a 10% margin above VS
The high speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of Mach related buffet, normally MMO, but sometimes slightly below that
learning.explanation: Before the days of FMS, the buffet boundary was displayed on a chart. The buffet boundary has both low and high speed limits: The low speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of the pre-stall buffet at a 10% margin above VS. The high speed buffet boundary describes the IAS at which we find the onset of Mach related buffet, normally MMO, but sometimes slightly below that. At low altitudes, these speeds are far apart, leaving a wide range of operating speeds. Although stalling IAS remains constant at first as altitude increases, it starts to increase at higher altitude. Also, the IAS at which we get Mach buffet will steadily decrease, because TAS increases in the climb and local speed of sound decreases. The two buffet boundaries will move closer toogether and eventually meet at an altitude where no margins exists, the coffin corner or aerodynamic ceiling, i.e. you cannot fly faster or slower because you will either stall or hit MMO. The right-hand limit on the graph shows the maximum indicated airspeed VMO and then at high altitude the maximum Mach number, MMO. The left-hand limit is based on the stall speed, 1.1 VS. Therefore, with increasing altitude, the low-speed buffet will increase and the high-speed buffet will decrease.

content.question: The following factors increase stall speed:

options.A: increasing bank angle, increasing thrust, slat extension.
options.B: a higher weight, selecting a higher flap setting, a forward CG movement.
options.C: an increase in load factor, a forward CG movement, decrease in thrust.
options.D: a lower weight, decreasing bank angle, a smaller flap setting.

key_points: A forward CG shift will result in a larger downforce required by the tailplane which increases the need for lift
If thrust decreases, the support of weight decreases
Consequently, more lift is required which means that the angle of attack must be increased
learning.explanation: A forward CG shift will result in a larger downforce required by the tailplane which increases the need for lift. If thrust decreases, the support of weight decreases. Consequently, more lift is required which means that the angle of attack must be increased. This will increase the stall speed. Any airplane, within the limits of its structure and the strength of the pilot, can be stalled at any airspeed. VS = √(2W ÷ p S CLMAX) The equation above well defines the factors affecting the stall speed, in summary; aircraft weight, air density, maximum lift coefficient, and the load factor. AIRCRAFT WEIGHT. Stall speed is proportional with the aircraft weight. Stall speed increases, as the weight increases; and decreases as the weight decreases. AIR DENSITY. Aircraft stall speeds are usually given in terms of CAS or IAS as an aircraft limitations. However, as seen in the equation above, it is actually a true airspeed which is inversely proportional with the density. Therefore, although it is constant in terms of CAS/IAS, it increases with the altitude because of the density variation. MAXIMUM LIFT COEFFICIENT. Maximum lift coefficient may be varied by high lift devices such as flaps and slats. Higher maximum lift coefficients will result in slower stall speeds. Lowest maximum lift coefficient is obtained when flaps are retracted (airplane in clean configuration), thus highest stall speed occurs in clean configuration. LOAD FACTOR. Stall speed is proportional with the load factor. It increases as the load factor increases. If VSS is the stall speed of an aircraft in steady level flight, then stall speed during maneuvers will be: VSN =√n VSS Or during a turn maneuver: VSN = VSS ÷ √ cos a

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting
Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure

learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. The aircraft must therefore be operated in such a manner that a (safety) margin exists before aerodynamic buffet will occur. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved. This is called a ‘Buffet Onset’ chart which is used by flight crews to ensure their aircraft is always operated with a specified minimum buffet margin. content.question: According to CS-23 and CS-25 an aeroplane must have controllable stall characteristics and be able to recover control at or slightly beyond the stalling angle of attack. Which of the statements that follow is a factor that, if certain design measures are not taken, might hinder the ability to meet the mentioned requirements?

options.A: Straight wings tend to stall at the root first, which creates a large nose-down pitching moment.
options.B: Tapered wings tend to stall at the tips first, making the aeroplane too stable in roll.
options.C: Highly cambered aerofoils tend to provide little or NO warning when approaching the stall.
options.D: Aft swept wings tend to stall at the tips first, which may create a nose-up pitching moment.

key_points: Wing sweep is a tendency for first stalling the wingtip and a pitch-up moment
Both are unwanted stall characteristics which can lead to a deep stall
This tendency can be reduced by design modifications (wing fences, vortilons and saw tooth leading edges) which minimize the root-to-tip spanwise flow of the boundary layer
learning.explanation: Wing sweep is a tendency for first stalling the wingtip and a pitch-up moment. Both are unwanted stall characteristics which can lead to a deep stall. This tendency can be reduced by design modifications (wing fences, vortilons and saw tooth leading edges) which minimize the root-to-tip spanwise flow of the boundary layer. These devices delay tip stall. Vortex generators are also frequently used on a swept wing to delay tip stall and improve the stall characteristics. The wing root can also be encouraged to stall first. This can be done by modifying the aerofoil section at the root, fitting stall strips and by fitting less efficient leading edge flaps (Kruger flaps) to the inboard section of the wing. During the recovery ailerons can be used with smooth and coordinated application of rudder.

content.question: It is possible for the stabiliser to stall prematurely due to ice contamination. In this case...

options.A: the aeroplane will pitch down.
options.B: the aeroplane will pitch up.
options.C: longitudinal control of the aeroplane will NOT be affected.
options.D: lateral control of the aeroplane will be greatly affected.

key_points: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does
The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack

The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost
learning.explanation: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does. The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack. The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost. Stalling of an ice contaminated tailplane could be precipitated by extension of the wing flaps. Lowering the flaps increases the downwash, and this increases the negative angle of attack of the tailplane. If the tailplane has ice contamination, this could be sufficient to cause it to stall. Recovery procedure in this situation would be to retract the flaps again, thus reducing the downwash. Take care when increasing an aircraft's forward airspeed to compensate for ice on the wings, since every knot of airspeed added to prevent wing stall brings the aircraft a knot closer to tailplane stall. Consequently, it is vital that the tailplane, like the wing, is free from contamination. This type of stall does not usually occur, but if it does, recovery is normally impossible.

As the aircraft has excellent stall characteristics, the aircraft eventually stalls and starts to descend at a constant speed, with the pilot still pulling the stick fully backwards. Select the correct statement about drag before and after the stall.

options.A: Induced drag decreases before the stall and increases sharply after, while parasite drag decreases after the stall.
options.B: Induced drag increases until the stall, then decreases slightly, while total drag continues to increase beyond the stall.
options.C: Induced drag decreases steadily until the stall, then sharply increases.
options.D: Induced drag and parasite both increase to their maximum during the stall, then decrease sharply thereafter.

key_points: Important note: At time of writing, this question has been fed back to us 3 times, all similar questions but with a few differences
The correct option has been the same or very similar in all feedback so far, and therefore we have added this as a single question

Please inform us in the comments if you see this question in the exam, and please add information about anything different you remember, along with your exam authority, thank you! As you will likely know by this point, aircraft drag at low subsonic speeds is split into 2 components, parasite drag and induced drag
learning.explanation: Important note: At time of writing, this question has been fed back to us 3 times, all similar questions but with a few differences. The correct option has been the same or very similar in all feedback so far, and therefore we have added this as a single question. Please inform us in the comments if you see this question in the exam, and please add information about anything different you remember, along with your exam authority, thank you! As you will likely know by this point, aircraft drag at low subsonic speeds is split into 2 components, parasite drag and induced drag. For unstalled flight, the induced drag decreases with speed and parasite drag increases with speed, as shown above, creating the familiar total drag graph. Therefore, as the pilot in question slows the aircraft down when close to the stall, the induced drag will increase quite significantly and the parasite drag will gradually decrease. When the aircraft does actually stall though, the rules become more complex. Induced drag is actually short for "lift-induced drag", and when the aircraft stalls, it loses a lot of lift, so therefore the lift induced drag decreases somewhat after the stall. Parasite drag, however, no longer fits the usual curve, as the aircraft now has a much larger frontal area, as it has a very high (fully stalled) angle of attack, and therefore the air is hitting the underside of the fuselage, wings and tailplane much more than previously. This is not streamlined at all, so the parasite drag increases after the stall, and the more stalled the aircraft gets, the larger the parasite drag. Together, this means that total drag continues increasing after the stall.

content.question:
Which statement is correct?
I. Stall speeds are determined with the CG at the aft limit.
II. Minimum control speeds are determined with the CG at the aft limit.

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: Stall speeds are determined with the least favourible CG position
For an aircraft, this is the most forward point because then the main wing will be producing the most lift
With the CG furthest ahead of the centre of pressure, the horizontal stabilizer will be producing a downwards force, which the main wings will have to compensate for by producing more lift
learning.explanation: Stall speeds are determined with the least favourible CG position. For an aircraft, this is the most forward point because then the main wing will be producing the most lift. With the CG furthest ahead of the centre of pressure, the horizontal stabilizer will be producing a downwards force, which the main wings will have to compensate for by producing more lift. The main wings will therefore have to be at a higher angle of attack and therefore be closer to the stall. Hence the stall will occur at higher speeds with a forward cg then with a rearward cg. Minimum control speeds are also determined with the least favourible conditions. When considering an engine failure, we know that the aircraft will rotate around its CG, but the distance of the moment doesn’t change when it moves fore or aft, the engines moment would only change when we move it along the lateral axis of the aircraft. However, the position of the CG will influence the rudder arm, and hence the rudder moment. A CG on the af limit will provide a small arm and therefore the least ability to oppose the yawing moment of the engine failure.

content.question: An aircraft is flying at a constant Mach number and constant angle of attack. After the aircraft experienced wind shear, the low speed buffet margin...

options.A: increases.
options.B: decreases.
options.C: remain the same.
options.D: is not influenced by the load factor.

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting
Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure
Aircraft must therefore be operated with a (safety) margin to aerodynamic buffet
learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Aircraft must therefore be operated with a (safety) margin to aerodynamic buffet. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved: - Load factor. - Mach number. - Angle of attack. - Pressure altitude. - Weight. - CG position. LOAD FACTOR Because load factor increases the stall speed, different curves can be drawn for all values of load factor up to the maximum permissible ‘g’, and together they constitute the set of stalling boundaries for the given aircraft. Such a set of curves is shown in attached figure. Superimposed on these curves are dashed lines representing lines of constant Mach number, showing how high Mach numbers can be achieved, even at relatively low EAS, at high altitudes. Encountering wind shear increases the load factor, which increases the stall speed. This means that the margin to the low speed buffet margin is decreased. Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor. In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range. The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries.

content.question: When considering a swept-back wing, without corrective design features, at the stall:

options.A: wing root stall will occur first, which produces a rolling moment.
options.B: tip stall will occur first, which produces a nose-up pitching moment.
options.C: tip stall will occur first, which produces a nose-down pitching moment.
options.D: leading edge stall will occur first, which produces a nose-down pitching moment.

key_points: The lift from a wing is generated by airflow over it from front to back
If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer
This causes them to be thicker and more susceptible to transition to turbulence or flow separation
learning.explanation: The lift from a wing is generated by airflow over it from front to back. If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer. This causes them to be thicker and more susceptible to transition to turbulence or flow separation. The normal tip vortice on a swept wing joins up with a leading edge separation bubble, creating a larger vortex called the Ram’s horn vortex. This vortex goes inboard along the wing’s leading edge. The downward flow from the vortex induces pressure on the boundary layer at the wingtip, whereas on straight wings the exact opposite occurs. With a swept wing, this creates a slow-moving layer of air at the wing tip. This slow-moving air will separate into disturbed flow and will then stall the tip. As the wingtips for a swept wing are positioned aft of the center of pressure (CP), the center of pressure upon a wing tip stall will move forward, creating a nose up moment. This nose up moment will further increase the Angle of Attack if not corrected in time, increasing the layer of slow-moving air, worsening the situation. Due to the decreased downwash on the elevator, the elevator could be less responsive, creating a so called deep stall. Unswept wings do not have this problem, as the CP for an unswept wing will move backwards as the aircraft approaches and exceeds CLMAX. The pitch up phenomenon is a dangerous characteristic of swept wing aircraft (with a T-tail) that move at high speed. It could result in a quickly worsening stalling situation, making it very hard to recover.

learning.explanation: SPIN RECOVERY Although the POH is the primary reference for recovery from a spin, the following can be used as a general procedure: P - Retard the throttle to idle. In most aircraft, power hampers the recovery. A - Ailerons neutral. Many pilots will attempt to recover from the spin using the ailerons. This may actually make the problem worse. R - Apply full opposite rudder. Apply rudder opposite the rotation of the spin. If you have trouble determining which way the airplane is spinning, look at your turn coordinator or turn needle. It will indicate the direction of rotation. E - Apply forward elevator. Immediately after applying opposite rudder, apply a quick forward motion on the control yoke and hold anti-spin controls until the aircraft starts to recover. D - Recover from the dive. Once you have completed the four previous steps, and the rotation stops, recover from the dive. The descent rate may be over 5000 feet per minute and the airspeed will rapidly exceed redline. Remember to neutralize the rudder after the rotation stops.

THE INCIPIENT SPIN (figures 1 and 2) If the wing drops at the stall, the resulting rolling action alters the direction of the relative airflow on to the wing
It increases the angle of attack of the down-going wing and reduces the angle of attack of the up-going wing
learning.explanation: Spinning is a condition of stalled flight in which an aircraft describes a downward spiral path, and is normally the by-product of wing drop when operating near the stall. THE INCIPIENT SPIN (figures 1 and 2) If the wing drops at the stall, the resulting rolling action alters the direction of the relative airflow on to the wing. It increases the angle of attack of the down-going wing and reduces the angle of attack of the up-going wing. The down-going wing becomes more stalled, leading to a reduction in the coefficient of lift and an increase in the coefficient of drag. Conversely, the up-going wing becomes less stalled, leading to an increase in the coefficient of lift and a reduction in the coefficient of drag. The difference in lift between the wings produces a rolling moment and the aircraft rolls in the direction of the down-going wing. The yawing moment resulting from the large difference in drag between the down-going and up-going wings further aids this. These moments lead to autorotation: the aircraft continues to roll, a side-slip develops, and the nose drops. Without corrective action, the rate of rotation steadily increases, resulting in a fully developed spin. FULLY DEVELOPED SPIN It is usual for the aircraft to rotate several times around a spin axis before settling into a steady state spin, with the final pitch attitude depending mainly on the position of the centre of gravity. The spin can be either flat or steep. This condition is reached when the rate of rotation and sink stabilise at constant values. When this occurs, the forces and moments acting are considered to be in equilibrium and the relative airflow comes vertically upward to meet the aircraft. FORWARD CG This results in a steeper spin and a faster rate of sink. This makes the recovery easier because the spin is less stable. AFT CG This results in a flatter spin and a lower rate of sink. This makes the recovery more difficult, because the spin is more stable. If the centre of gravity is aft of its permitted limits, it significantly reduces the likelihood of recovery from a settled spin condition. When an aircraft is in a steep spin rotation it is primarily in roll, whereas in a flat spin it is primarily in yaw. (figure 3)

II. Minimum control speeds are determined with the CG at the forward limit.

options.B: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is correct, II is correct.
options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: Stall speeds are determined with the least favourible cg position
For an aircraft, this is the most forward point because then the main wing will be producing the most lift
With the cg furthest ahead of the centre of pressure, the horizontal stabilizer will be producing a downwards force, which the main wings will have to compensate for by producing more lift
learning.explanation: Stall speeds are determined with the least favourible cg position. For an aircraft, this is the most forward point because then the main wing will be producing the most lift. With the cg furthest ahead of the centre of pressure, the horizontal stabilizer will be producing a downwards force, which the main wings will have to compensate for by producing more lift. The main wings will therefore have to be at a higher angle of attack and therefore be closer to the stall. Hence the stall will occur at higher speeds with a forward cg then with a rearward cg. Minimum control speeds are also determined with the least favourible conditions. When considering an engine failure, we know that the aircraft will rotate around its cg, but the distance of the moment doesn’t change when it moves fore or aft, the engines moment would only change when we move it along the lateral axis of the aircraft. However, the position of the cg will influence the rudder arm, and hence the rudder moment. A cg on the af limit will provide a small arm and therefore the least ability to oppose the yawing moment of the engine failure.

learning.explanation: A stick shaker, as the name suggests shakes the control colum warning the pilot of an impeding stall. It does not apply any corrective measures. A stick pusher is a system that will push the stick forward, lowering the nose and therefore decreasing the angle of attack to prevent a stall. content.question:
During training flights, it is normal to demonstrate accelerated stalls. These are carried out at speeds below 90kt and are induced by using excessive stick inputs to pull up during stall recovery. Spiral dives are also manoeuvres which are demonstrated during training flights. In this case, as the spiral dive develops, the speed is allowed to increase to 130kt. Considering the aeroplane limitations given below, which statement is correct?
VS: 45 kt
VA: 100 kt
VNO: 125 kt
VNE: 160 kt

options.A: Careful application of the elevator must be used to recover from the spiral dive in order to avoid an excessive load factor.
options.B: The aeroplane may suffer an excessive load factor and damage during the stall recovery exercises.
options.C: If too much elevator is used to recover from the spiral dive, the aeroplane may stall and enter a spin.
options.D: The rudder must be used to roll the wings level from the spiral dive, as the ailerons may cause excessive wing bending.

key_points: "The aeroplane may suffer an excessive load factor and damage during the stall recovery exercises
" Incorrect
The question's mention of "excessive" stick inputs, creates the impression that the aircraft might experience a high load factor and potential damage during recovery exercises
learning.explanation: "The aeroplane may suffer an excessive load factor and damage during the stall recovery exercises." Incorrect. The question's mention of "excessive" stick inputs, creates the impression that the aircraft might experience a high load factor and potential damage during recovery exercises. Nevertheless, the fact that they limit the speed increase to only 130 kt, well below VNE, minimizes the actual risk of structural damage. "If too much elevator is used to recover from the spiral dive, the aeroplane may stall and enter a spin." Incorrect. If excessive pulling occurs and surpasses the critical angle of attack, the aircraft will stall. However, what the examiner likely intends is that when initially employing ailerons to level the wings and recover from a spiral dive, there's no need for an "excessive" application of elevator. The essence of the statement is to emphasize not pulling too hard at the detection of a spiral dive but prioritizing leveling the wings first. It's crucial to recall that in a spiral dive, the wings are not yet stalled, making it imperative to first halt the rolling moment and then initiate a pull to recover lost altitude. In contrast, a spin involves a stall, necessitating a recovery process of pushing the control stick initially, followed by maintaining neutral ailerons and applying rudder in the opposite direction of the spin. "The rudder must be used to roll the wings level from the spiral dive, as the ailerons may cause excessive wing bending." Incorrect. In contrast to a spin, a recovery from a spiral dive involves initially leveling off to counteract the excessive static directional stability relative to lateral stability, thereby stopping the rolling moment. It's crucial to execute this maneuver cautiously to prevent any potential structural damage. If the rudder is applied before the ailerons in this situation, additional stress is imposed on the airframe because the aircraft is already in a nose-down attitude with a sideslip, further banking due to directional stability. This is why stall escape maneuvers or upset recovery procedures in commercial airliners explicitly avoid instructing the use of the rudder pedals.

Lowest maximum lift coefficient is obtained when flaps are retracted (airplane in clean configuration), thus highest stall speed occurs in clean configuration. LOAD FACTOR. content.question: An aeroplane where its CG is located forward of its Centre of Pressure suffers a premature tailplane stall as a result of ice contamination. Provided the wings do NOT stall, the outcome will be a(n)...

options.B: uncommanded nose down pitch that will be accompanied by the activation of the stall warning system.
options.C: uncommanded nose up pitch that will be accompanied by the activation of the stall warning system.
options.D: nose down pitch upset, the magnitude of which will depend on the location of the aeroplane’s CG.

key_points: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does
The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack

The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost
learning.explanation: STABILIZER STALL DUE TO ICE The tailplane is an aerofoil, and because it is thinner than the wing, it is likely to experience icing before the wing does. The effect will be the same as for the wing; the stall will occur at a lower angle of attack. The tailplane is normally operating at a negative angle of attack, producing a down load, so if the tailplane stalls and the down load is lost, the nose of the aircraft will drop and longitudinal control will be lost. Stalling of an ice contaminated tailplane could be precipitated by extension of the wing flaps. Lowering the flaps increases the downwash, and this increases the negative angle of attack of the tailplane. If the tailplane has ice contamination, this could be sufficient to cause it to stall. Recovery procedure in this situation would be to retract the flaps again, thus reducing the downwash. Take care when increasing an aircraft's forward airspeed to compensate for ice on the wings, since every knot of airspeed added to prevent wing stall brings the aircraft a knot closer to tailplane stall. Consequently, it is vital that the tailplane, like the wing, is free from contamination. This type of stall does not usually occur, but if it does, recovery is normally impossible.

The two aeroplanes from the annex have conventional flight controls but different design principles. This means that the two aircraft will be affected by thrust changes in different ways
learning.explanation: In this scenario, it is all about the engine location. Aeroplane 1 has a high tail-mounted engine design, whereas aeroplane 2 has underslung wing-mounted engines. This means that the two aircraft will be affected by thrust changes in different ways. We call the high mounted engines on aeroplane 1 "thrust stabilising", as they produce thrust through or above the line of our CG, so cause a small pitch down moment when extra thrust is applied, which gains airspeed. The underslung engines on aeroplane 2 have a much lower thrust line, so the aircraft will pitch up significantly when thrust is increased. This is a de-stabilising effect, as the airspeed may actually reduce with increased engine thrust, due to the pitch up moment. In the go-around then, aircraft 1 will handle as expected, with full thrust causing an acceleration, and pitch up command required to achieve the +12º go-around attitude. In aircraft 2, it is highly likely that applying full power will pitch the aeroplane so much nose up that the pilots will have to push on the controls to avoid over-rotating and losing valuable speed. Note: there are a few other questions with this (or a very similar) graphic, so make sure to read the question and options carefully. We can pretty much guarantee that the examiner will mix and match some options to catch out people who mistake the question for a different one.

" CORRECT
learning.explanation: "I. The combination of a wing with sweepback and a T-tail make an aeroplane prone to deep stall." CORRECT. A deep stall is a dangerous phenomenon that occurs when the turbulence created by the main wing encompasses the horizontal stabilizer of the aircraft, preventing the aircraft from recovering from the stall. Aircraft with swept-back wings are prone to deep stall, regardless of horizontal stabilizer position (T-tail or low tail). T-tail will worsen recovery characteristics. Swept-forward wings at very high angle of attack are prone to deep stall as well. However, if a low horizontal tail is fitted, some pitch down moment may be produced with the help of the horizontal stabilizer since it is out of the separated turbulent wake of the wing. "II. A stick shaker system is fitted to an aeroplane to resolve deep stall problems." INCORRECT A stick shaker, as the name suggests shakes the control colum warning the pilot of an impeding stall. It does not apply any corrective measures.

As you enter the vortex ring, you experience turbulence and a rapid increase in IAS as you pick up a headwind. You start to climb as your performance increases. 2. As you enter the strongest part of the horizontal shaft, your airspeed peaks at 100 knots, an increase of 20 knots. You're still climbing as you enter the downdraft. 3. content.question: Both CS-23 and CS-25 specifications state that an aeroplane must have sufficient controllability at and just above the critical angle of attack to aid in stall recovery. Which of the following statements identifies a consideration which could influence the stall handling characteristics, unless particular design measures are taken to avoid this?

options.A: High-wing aeroplane tend to have a greater pitch-up tendency, as an aeroplane progressively pitches up.
options.B: Supercritical aerofoils may increase the pitch-up tendency when compared to traditional cambered aerofoils.
options.C: Aft-fuselage mounted engines have a large pitching moment when thrust is increased during the recovery.
options.D: The vertical position of the horizontal stabiliser may affect the ability to recover, in particular a T-tail design.

key_points: This question is asking about handling characteristics at the stall, and the correct answer is in reference to deep stalls
A deep stall happens when an aircraft main wing stalls, but the angle of airflow means that the stalled air flows directly over the horizontal tailplane
This usually happens on T-tail aircraft, as the tail often becomes about level with the wing at critical angle of attack
learning.explanation: This question is asking about handling characteristics at the stall, and the correct answer is in reference to deep stalls. A deep stall happens when an aircraft main wing stalls, but the angle of airflow means that the stalled air flows directly over the horizontal tailplane. This usually happens on T-tail aircraft, as the tail often becomes about level with the wing at critical angle of attack. This turbulent flow will mean that there is little or no elevator control, and the horizontal stabiliser is not producing any controllable lift. This can leave the aircraft without any pitch control, causing a potentially unrecoverable deep stall (a.k.a. a super stall). Aircraft with deep stall characteristics are often fitted with a stick-pusher to avoid reaching that point. The other design feature they could ask about is underslung engines. Underslung engines are mounted under the main wings, as is most common on modern jets. When thrust is increased on these engines, a very large pitch-up moment is induced, due to their thrust line being far below the centre of gravity. As thrust is often added to recover from a stall, this could cause an upwards pitch which could overpower even full nose-down pitch control at low speeds. We call this thrust line "destabilising". The high mounted tail engines seen on many smaller jets are not susceptible to this effect, as they have a high thrust line and a "stabilising" thrust moment.

If the presence of windshear is confirmed, delay take-off or do not continue an approach. If windshear is suspected, be especially alert to any of the danger signals and be prepared for the possibility of an inadvertent encounter. content.question:
Which of these statements about the buffet free range in a buffet onset boundary graph are correct or incorrect?
1. When speed increases the buffet free range decreases.
2. When altitude decreases the buffet free range decreases.

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor
In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range
The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries
learning.explanation: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor. In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range. The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries. For a given aircraft there is a Mach number which, even at low angle of attack, cannot be exceeded because of the onset of shock stall. The EAS corresponding to this Mach number falls as altitude increases, so the range of operating speeds is reduced at both ends. Flying at a different speed will not influence the buffet boundaries, therefore statement 1 is incorrect. At altitude, the equivalent stalling speed increases with ‘g’ rather more rapidly than at sea level, because of the Mach number effect on CLMAX. Also, the buffet boundary becomes much more severe. Above a certain altitude the buffet boundary may intersect the stall boundary at a value of ‘g’ lower than the structural limit. This ‘point’ is another representation of “coffin corner”. We can then conclude that decreasing altitude, increases the buffet margin, therefore statement 2 is incorrect.

content.question: An aeroplane is established on final approach descending through 1000 ft when the pilot realizes that the aeroplane is about to enter an area of heavy tropical rain. The pilot must consider that the stalling…

options.A: speed increase due to the CLMAX reduction because of water distorting the shape of the airfoil and the airflow pattern.
options.B: speed increase due to compressibility effects appearing earlier than normal because of the concentration of water on the wings.
options.C: angle of attack decrease due to the apparent decrease of the load factor from the heavy downpour of rain.
options.D: angle of attack decreases due to the associated gusts from the heavy downpour of rain.

key_points: The airframe may become contaminated by ice, frost or water either whilst it is in flight or when standing on the ground

WATER CONTAMINATION If the wings are contaminated with water due to heavy rain, the boundary layer may become turbulent further forward on the wing, particularly if the section is of the laminar flow type
This will cause increased drag and may disrupt the boundary layer resulting in a significantly higher stall speed
learning.explanation: The airframe may become contaminated by ice, frost or water either whilst it is in flight or when standing on the ground. WATER CONTAMINATION If the wings are contaminated with water due to heavy rain, the boundary layer may become turbulent further forward on the wing, particularly if the section is of the laminar flow type. This will cause increased drag and may disrupt the boundary layer resulting in a significantly higher stall speed. EFFECT OF HEAVY RAIN ON STALL SPEED - Weight Heavy rain will form a film of water on an aircraft and increase its weight slightly, maybe as much as 1 - 2% this in itself will increase stall speed. - Aerodynamic Effect The film of water will distort the aerofoil, roughen the surface and alter the airflow pattern on the whole aircraft. CLMAX will decrease causing stall speed to increase. - Drag The film of water will increase interference drag, profile drag and form drag. In light rain, drag may increase by 5%, in moderate by 20% and in heavy rain by up to 30%. - Impact An additional consideration, while not affecting stall speed, is the effect of the impact of heavy rain on the aircraft. Momentum will be lost and airspeed will decrease, requiring increased thrust. At the same time, heavy rain will also be driving the aircraft downwards. The volume of rain in any given situation will vary, but an aircraft on final approach which suddenly enters a torrential downpour of heavy rain will be subject to a loss of momentum and a decrease in altitude, similar to the effect of microburst windshear.

content.question: An inexperienced pilot inadvertently flies a light aircraft into a cloud, and due to lack of visual references allows the aircraft to enter a spiral dive. As the aircraft flies out of the cloud the pilot pulls hard on the control column to recover. The aircraft can still stall in this attitude due to the…

options.B: aircraft IAS being below the published stall speed.
options.C: aircraft being above manoeuvre speed.
options.D: wing exceeding best L/D angle of attack.

key_points: When the lift developed by an aeroplane wing is no longer sufficient to sustain the mass of the aeroplane in flight, in the configuration being considered, the wing is stalled
A stall is caused by airflow separation
Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great
learning.explanation: When the lift developed by an aeroplane wing is no longer sufficient to sustain the mass of the aeroplane in flight, in the configuration being considered, the wing is stalled. A stall is caused by airflow separation. Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great. STALLING ANGLE OF ATTACK At a constant mass and air density, the coefficient of lift (CL), and consequently the total amount of lift, is dependent on the angle of attack. Graphically, lift increases almost linearly from an angle of attack of 0º to 4º, and then at an increasing rate to 15º. Lift cannot be obtained without incurring the penalty of drag. At a specific angle of attack, depending on circumstances, the lift generated is insufficient to sustain the aircraft in level flight. The angle of attack at which this occurs is the stalling angle or critical angle and is the point at which CLMAX is attained. An aeroplane will not stall unless the critical angle is exceeded.

learning.explanation: SPIN RECOVERY Although the POH is the primary reference for recovery from a spin, the following can be used as a general procedure: P - Retard the throttle to idle. In most aircraft, power hampers the recovery. A - Ailerons neutral. Many pilots will attempt to recover from the spin using the ailerons. This may actually make the problem worse. R - Apply full opposite rudder. Apply rudder opposite the rotation of the spin. If you have trouble determining which way the airplane is spinning, look at your turn coordinator or turn needle. It will indicate the direction of rotation. E - Apply forward elevator. Immediately after applying opposite rudder, apply a quick forward motion on the control yoke and hold anti-spin controls until the aircraft starts to recover. D - Recover from the dive. Once you have completed the four previous steps, and the rotation stops, recover from the dive. The descent rate may be over 5000 feet per minute and the airspeed will rapidly exceed redline. Remember to neutralize the rudder after the rotation stops.
