key_points: MICROBURSTS These are the most lethal forms of windshear

They normally occur in the vicinity of thunderstorms and are mainly associated with cumulonimbus clouds THE EFFECT OF A MICROBURST ENCOUNTER DURING THE APPROACH The attached depicts how an aircraft typically reacts when subject to a microburst during the approach: - Increasing headwinds, causing the IAS to rise (temporary energy gain) and the aircraft to climb above the glidepath

They normally occur in the vicinity of thunderstorms and are mainly associated with cumulonimbus clouds THE EFFECT OF A MICROBURST ENCOUNTER DURING THE APPROACH The attached depicts how an aircraft typically reacts when subject to a microburst during the approach: - Increasing headwinds, causing the IAS to rise (temporary energy gain) and the aircraft to climb above the glidepath. - A downdraught that increases the rate of descent and decreases the IAS, thereby causing the aircraft to drop further below the glidepath. The rate of descent may lessen due to increased thrust availability. This may lead to a reduction in airspeed below the stalling speed and if operating at high angles of attack, which are normally associated with the approach and landing phases of flight, the wing may stall. A successful recovery from a microburst encounter depends on the altitude, thrust, and speed reserves available. In addition to these effects, severe wind, turbulence, heavy rain, and blinding flashes of lightning often accompany microbursts.

key_points: BOUNDARY LAYER When a solid is placed into a flow, there will be a layer, where the velocity is smaller than in the undisturbed stream, reducing to 0 at the surface of the body
Boundary Layer is defined as a region where the velocity of the flow reaches a certain percentage (i
e
learning.explanation: BOUNDARY LAYER When a solid is placed into a flow, there will be a layer, where the velocity is smaller than in the undisturbed stream, reducing to 0 at the surface of the body. Boundary Layer is defined as a region where the velocity of the flow reaches a certain percentage (i.e. 90% or 99%) of the undisturbed stream velocity from zero. Inside the boundary layer, the viscosity of the fluid alters the flow, while outside of this layer viscosity can be neglected. The boundary layer will exist in two forms, either laminar or turbulent. In general, the flow at the front will be laminar and become turbulent some distance back, known as the transition point.

content.question: One important advantage a turbulent boundary layer has over a laminar layer is that the turbulent boundary layer:

options.A: is thinner.
options.B: has less tendency to separate from the surface.
options.C: has less energy.
options.D: has a lower skin friction drag.

key_points: The boundary layer is the layer of fluid (in our case this fluid is the atmosphere) in the immediate surface of a bounding surface (the airfoil) where the effects of viscosity are significant
There are two types of boundary layer; the laminar and the turbulent boundary layer
In the laminar boundary layer, the flow moves parallel to the surface over which it flows
learning.explanation: The boundary layer is the layer of fluid (in our case this fluid is the atmosphere) in the immediate surface of a bounding surface (the airfoil) where the effects of viscosity are significant. There are two types of boundary layer; the laminar and the turbulent boundary layer. In the laminar boundary layer, the flow moves parallel to the surface over which it flows. In the laminar boundary layer, the air flows very smoothly. The velocity increases with distance from the airfoil and there is no movement of air perpendicular to the surface of the airfoil. Laminar flow creates less friction drag than the turbulent flow, but is less stable. At a distance from the leading edge of the airfoil, the air transitions from a laminar flow to a turbulent flow. This air does not flow smoothly, it contains swirls. There is flow in parallel and perpendicular direction. This air creates more drag than the laminar air flow, has more kinetic energy and breaks down from the surface less easily and is therefore more stable.

options.B: High Angle of Attack due to the decrease in TAS.
options.C: High Mach Number due to the increase in TAS.
options.D: High Mach Number due to the increase in LSS.

key_points: M = TAS ÷ LSS During a climb, air density is decreasing
Therefore, the TAS needs to constantly increase to maintain a constant IAS/CAS
The OAT decreases with increasing altitude, so the LSS will decrease since LSS = 38
learning.explanation: M = TAS ÷ LSS During a climb, air density is decreasing. Therefore, the TAS needs to constantly increase to maintain a constant IAS/CAS. The OAT decreases with increasing altitude, so the LSS will decrease since LSS = 38.95 x √ (°K) (directly proportional to temperature). According to the above equation, if the TAS increases and the LSS decreases, the Mach number will increase. The Mach number will steadily increase, potentially beyond MMO to a point at which high speed buffet develops.

content.question: A student pilot is flying a spinning exercise. Included in the recovery actions from an incipient spin is:

options.A: Rudder deflection in the opposite direction to the yaw, with reference to the turn needle.
options.B: Aileron deflection in the opposite direction to the yaw, with reference to the turn needle.
options.C: Rudder deflection in the opposite direction to the yaw, with reference to the slip ball.
options.D: Aileron deflection in the opposite direction to the yaw, with reference to the slip ball.

key_points: SPIN RECOVERY Although the POH is the primary reference for recovery from a spin, the following can be used as a general procedure: P - Retard the throttle to idle
In most aircraft, power hampers the recovery
A - Ailerons neutral
learning.explanation: SPIN RECOVERY Although the POH is the primary reference for recovery from a spin, the following can be used as a general procedure: P - Retard the throttle to idle. In most aircraft, power hampers the recovery. A - Ailerons neutral. Many pilots will attempt to recover from the spin using the ailerons. This may actually make the problem worse. R - Apply full opposite rudder. Apply rudder opposite the rotation of the spin. If you have trouble determining which way the airplane is spinning, look at your turn coordinator or turn needle. It will indicate the direction of rotation. E - Apply forward elevator. Immediately after applying opposite rudder, apply a quick forward motion on the control yoke and hold anti-spin controls until the aircraft starts to recover. D - Recover from the dive. Once you have completed the four previous steps, and the rotation stops, recover from the dive. The descent rate may be over 5000 feet per minute and the airspeed will rapidly exceed redline. Remember to neutralize the rudder after the rotation stops.

content.question: A pilot is flying an aeroplane manually, in a turn, but forgets to add thrust and enters a stall. As a first action in order to initiate stall recovery, the pilot should...

options.A: Bring the wings level to direct the lift upwards.
options.B: Add thrust to increase speed past the stalling speed.
options.C: Apply rudder to raise that dropped wing.
options.D: Apply nose-down pitch to reduce the angle of attack.

key_points: The CL of an aerofoil increases with angle of attack up to a maximum (CLMAX)

Any further increase above this stalling angle, or critical angle of attack, will make it impossible for the airflow to smoothly follow the upper wing contour, and the flow will separate from the surface, causing CL to decrease and drag to increase rapidly
A stall is caused by airflow separation
learning.explanation: The CL of an aerofoil increases with angle of attack up to a maximum (CLMAX). Any further increase above this stalling angle, or critical angle of attack, will make it impossible for the airflow to smoothly follow the upper wing contour, and the flow will separate from the surface, causing CL to decrease and drag to increase rapidly. A stall is caused by airflow separation. Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great. STALL RECOVERY To recover from a stall or prevent a full stall, the angle of attack must be decreased to reduce the adverse pressure gradient. This may consist of merely releasing back pressure, or it may be necessary to smoothly move the pitch control forward, depending on the aircraft design and severity of the stall. Allow airspeed to increase and recover lost altitude with moderate back pressure on the pitch control. Pulling too hard could trigger a secondary stall, or worse, could exceed the limit load factor and damage the aircraft structure. As angle of attack reduces below the critical angle, the adverse pressure gradient will decrease, airflow will re-attach, and lift and drag will return to their normal values.

content.question:
A “stall warning” can be produced synthetically by electronic means, by a system that may malfunction. What are the natural stall warnings confirming an approaching stall?
(1) Aerodynamic buffeting
(2) Increased aileron effectiveness
(3) Inability to arrest a rate of descent
(4) Stick pusher activation

options.A: 1 and 3.
options.B: 1 and 4.
options.C: 2 and 4.

key_points: STALL A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift
Specifically, a stall occurs when the AOA—the angle between the chord line of the wing and the relative wind—exceeds the wing’s critical AOA
It is possible to exceed the critical AOA at any airspeed, at any attitude, and at any power setting
learning.explanation: STALL A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift. Specifically, a stall occurs when the AOA—the angle between the chord line of the wing and the relative wind—exceeds the wing’s critical AOA. It is possible to exceed the critical AOA at any airspeed, at any attitude, and at any power setting. Impending Stall—an impending stall occurs when the AOA causes a stall warning, but has not yet reached the critical AOA. Indications of an impending stall can include buffeting, stick shaker, or aural warning. Full Stall—a full stall occurs when the critical AOA is exceeded. Indications of a full stall are typically that an uncommanded nose-down pitch cannot be readily arrested, and this may be accompanied by an uncommanded rolling motion. The flying controls will feel unresponsive or “mushy”. For airplanes equipped with stick pushers, its activation is also a full stall indication. Note: The question asks for natural stall warnings.

To produce that same amount of lift along the vertical axis, the aircraft will need to fly faster than in straight and level flight

To produce that same amount of lift along the vertical axis, the aircraft will need to fly faster than in straight and level flight. Thus, the stall speed (minimum flight speed) will increase during a turn.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
At a mass of 130 tons:

options.A: the buffet free range in 1 g flight at FL410 is from approximately M = 0.76 to M = 0.83.
options.B: buffet free flight is possible at M = 0.80 only.
options.C: buffet free flight at 1 g at FL410 is possible without any Mach number restriction.
options.D: the buffet free range in a level 30 degree bank turn at FL360 is from approximately M = 0.75 to M = 0.84.

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting
Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure
Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage
learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. The aircraft must therefore be operated in such a manner that a (safety) margin exists before aerodynamic buffet will occur. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved. This is called a ‘Buffet Onset’ chart which is used by flight crews to ensure their aircraft is always operated with a specified minimum buffet margin. In this exercise: Start by drawing a line from de 1g load factor that intersects the 130-ton curve. From here, draw a straight line from right to left that intersects the FL410 curve. The goal is to have to intersection points, which correspond to the lowest and highest limits of the buffet boundaries. In this case, the low speed boundary is M0.76 and the high-speed boundary is M 0.83

content.question: The load factor is less than 1 (one):

options.A: when lift is greater than weight.
options.B: during a steady horizontal turn.
options.C: during a wings level stall before recovery.
options.D: in steady wings level horizontal flight.

key_points: The balance of forces in steady climb show thrust is partly acting upwards and weight is partly adding to the drag
Because the thrust is now assisting lift, there is less lift required than in level flight
For steady speed, the thrust and two effects of aerodynamic drag and weight must be equal
learning.explanation: The balance of forces in steady climb show thrust is partly acting upwards and weight is partly adding to the drag. Because the thrust is now assisting lift, there is less lift required than in level flight. For steady speed, the thrust and two effects of aerodynamic drag and weight must be equal. T= Thrust W= Weight D= Drag T= D + W sin(gamma) This means that the climb angle (sin gamma) depends on excess thrust and weight. In descent the formula will become T= D – W sin(gamma) The load factor is the relationship between lift and weight. As the lift in a stall is decreased and the load factor in straight and level flight is 1, the load factor will now be less than 1.

content.question: Low speed pitch up can be caused by the:

options.A: outward drift of the boundary layer on a swept-back wing.
options.B: dihedral effect.
options.C: boundary layer separation at the wing tip of a forward swept wing.
options.D: wing tip vortices on high aspect ratio wings.

key_points: The lift from a wing is generated by airflow over it from front to back
If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer
This causes them to be thicker and more susceptible to transition to turbulence or flow separation
learning.explanation: The lift from a wing is generated by airflow over it from front to back. If the span-wise flow increases, the boundary layer on the wing surface travels for longer. This causes them to be thicker and more susceptible to transition to turbulence or flow separation. The normal tip vortice on a swept wing joins up with a leading edge separation bubble, creating a larger vortex called the Ram’s horn vortex. This vortex goes inboard along the wing’s leading edge. The downward flow from the vortex induces pressure on the boundary layer at the wingtip, whereas on straight wings the exact opposite occurs. With a swept wing, this creates a slow-moving layer of air at the wing tip. This slow-moving air will separate into disturbed flow and will then stall the tip. As the wingtips for a swept wing are positioned aft of the center of pressure (CP), the center of pressure upon a wing tip stall will move forward, creating a nose up moment. This nose up moment will further increase the Angle of Attack if not corrected in time, increasing the layer of slow-moving air, worsening the situation. Due to the decreased downwash on the elevator, the elevator could be less responsive, creating a so called deep stall. Unswept wings do not have this problem. The pitch up phenomenon is a dangerous characteristic of swept wing aircraft (with a T-tail) that move at high speed. It could result in a quickly worsening stalling situation, making it very hard to recover.

content.question: An aeroplane is flying in steady, straight and level flight at its 1g stall speed. If the pilot intends to turn left using the ailerons, the aeroplane will…

options.A: bank to the left provided the speed does NOT decrease below the stalling speed.
options.B: bank to the right, because the wing with the down going aileron will exceed the critical angle of attack.
options.C: maintain straight and level flight because the ailerons will be unresponsive due to flow separation.
options.D: Yaw to the left, because of increased drag due to flow separation on the downgoing aileron.

key_points: USE OF FLIGHT CONTROLS CLOSE TO THE STALL At low speeds normally associated with stalling, dynamic pressure is at a very low value and greater control deflection will be required to achieve the same response; also, the flying controls will feel unresponsive or “mushy”
If an accidental stall does occur, it is vitally important that the stall and recovery should occur without too much wing drop
Moving a control surface modifies the chord line and, hence, the angle of attack
learning.explanation: USE OF FLIGHT CONTROLS CLOSE TO THE STALL At low speeds normally associated with stalling, dynamic pressure is at a very low value and greater control deflection will be required to achieve the same response; also, the flying controls will feel unresponsive or “mushy”. If an accidental stall does occur, it is vitally important that the stall and recovery should occur without too much wing drop. Moving a control surface modifies the chord line and, hence, the angle of attack. An aircraft being flown close to the stall angle may have one wing that produces slightly less lift than the other; that wing will tend to drop. Trying to lift a dropping wing with aileron will increase its angle of attack, and may cause the wing to stall completely, resulting in that wing dropping at an increased rate. At speeds close to the stall, ailerons must be used with caution. On straight wing aircraft the rudder should be used to yaw the aircraft just enough to increase the speed of a dropping wing to maintain a wing’s level attitude. Swept wing aircraft basic stall requirements are designed to enable the ailerons to be used successfully up to ”stall recognition”, but small amounts of rudder can be used if smoothly applied and co-ordinated with the ailerons. If an aileron is lowered when flying at high angles of attack, that wing could possibly stall. In that case the wing will drop instead of rising as intended.

content.question: Aircraft certified under CS-23 and CS-25 must be able to show that they are able to retain control at and just after the critical angle of attack. Which of the following design features may influence this controllability and why?

options.A: Aft mounted engines, as an increase in thrust produces a nose down moment.
options.B: Position of horizontal stabiliser, e.g. a T-tail makes it harder to recover from a stall.
options.C: Supercritical wings increase nose up tendency in a stall.
options.D: Using roll spoilers increases the chance of aileron reversal near the stall.

key_points: Note: The feedback for this question is quite limited, and there is another option that is very close to being correct, but we are happy with our choice of correct answer

Please send us any further exam feedback you have about this question, thank you! The vast majority of aircraft are never meant to stall, but it is always a possibility, no matter how many measures the designers put in to stop it occurring
This is why aircraft must be made to be controllable and predictable at stalling
learning.explanation: Note: The feedback for this question is quite limited, and there is another option that is very close to being correct, but we are happy with our choice of correct answer. Please send us any further exam feedback you have about this question, thank you! The vast majority of aircraft are never meant to stall, but it is always a possibility, no matter how many measures the designers put in to stop it occurring. This is why aircraft must be made to be controllable and predictable at stalling. In particular, we want the aircraft to have a nose down moment at the stall, and we want the controls to be effective at the stall. One way the controls could become ineffective at the stall is with a T-tail horizontal stabiliser design. Whilst a T-tail design usually takes the horizontal stabiliser away from the wake of the main wing, when the aircraft is pitched at the stalling angle of attack, often the horizontal stabiliser is in the zone of stalled airflow, where little to no lift can be gained. This is called a "deep stall" (or a super-stall) and makes the elevators quite useless, and even an all moving tailplane (which you would not usually find in a T-tail configuration) would be quite useless too. This is why most T-tail aircraft have a stall prevention device fitted called a stick pusher, which will put in a very strong pitch down control force just before the "deep stall" is reached. As we have already mentioned, there is another option present that is very close to correct. "Aft mounted engines, as an increase in thrust produces a nose down moment." We call this a stabilising thrust line, because the addition of thrust helps us gain airspeed by causing a pitch down moment as well as an increase in thrust. In our opinion it would be useful to have during stall. However, the controllability during and after the stall would not strictly be affected by this, only the ability to recover from the stall. If you interpret the question slightly differently, then this could be considered correct, but we would say it is not quite correct. "Position of horizontal stabiliser, e.g. a T-tail makes it harder to recover from a stall." As discussed above, this makes a huge difference to stall controllability, especially due to the ability of a T-tail design to go into a "deep stall". "Supercritical wings increase nose up tendency in a stall." Supercritical wings do stall slightly differently (much faster and less gradual), but this does not really relate to a nose up tendency. Also, this option does not really answer the question above, so it is incorrect. "Using roll spoilers increases the chance of aileron reversal near the stall." This one filled in incomplete feedback. Do not expect it in the exam. Aileron reversal (low speed) can happen if an aileron drops near the stall, increasing the AoA passed the stalling AoA and causing a reversal of the requested turn direction.

Refer to figure.
The two aircraft have different designs, but are of similar size and passenger capacity. What could be said with regards to the certification of the 2 aeroplanes?

options.A: Aircraft A needs fly-by-wire flight controls to ensure that it will not over-rotate during the go-around.
options.B: Aircraft B requires fly-by-wire flight controls to avoid the stall from uncommanded pitch up during the go-around.
options.C: Aircraft B needs a stick pusher system to avoid reaching an angle of attack that is too high, due to the potential for unwanted behaviour in the stall.
options.D: Aircraft A requires a mach trimmer but aircraft B would be immune to mach tuck, so does not.

key_points: Note: Beware that the aircraft options in the exam may be flipped, in that aircraft 2 may have underslung engines, and aircraft 1 have tail mounted engines
We also only know 2 options, the correct one and one incorrect one, and the other two incorrect options are likely to be different in the exam

DEEP STALL A deep stall is a dangerous phenomenon that occurs when the turbulence created by the main wing encompasses the horizontal stabilizer of the aircraft, preventing the aircraft from recovering from the stall
learning.explanation: Note: Beware that the aircraft options in the exam may be flipped, in that aircraft 2 may have underslung engines, and aircraft 1 have tail mounted engines. We also only know 2 options, the correct one and one incorrect one, and the other two incorrect options are likely to be different in the exam. DEEP STALL A deep stall is a dangerous phenomenon that occurs when the turbulence created by the main wing encompasses the horizontal stabilizer of the aircraft, preventing the aircraft from recovering from the stall. T-tail aircraft are most likely to have deep stall characteristics. When the main wing stalls, the stabilizer becomes ineffective because it is situated in the separated turbulent flow of the wing and sometimes the fuselage. This can lead to a very dangerous scenario where the aircraft can sit stable in the deep stall, with no control surface left working to get out of the situation. A common way to prevent deep stall in these types of aircraft is a stick pusher device, which detects high angles of attack, approaching the stall, and instead of notifying the pilots of this (a stick shaker, stall warner, etc.), it actually pushes the stick forwards without any pilot intervention.

content.question:
Thunderstorms are reported in the vicinity of an aerodrome when a heavy jet transport is about to commence an approach. Which combination of these methods could be used by the crew to mitigate the risk of buffet or stall?
1. Delay the approach, and divert if necessary.
2. Plan a flapless approach and landing.
3. Maintain a speed at least 30 kts above normal approach speed.
4. Delay landing flap selection until 200 ft.
5. Expect and prepare for a windshear warning and a go-around.

options.A: 1 and 5
options.B: 1, 3 and 4
options.C: 2, 4 and 5

key_points: ALL EFFORTS SHALL BE MADE TO AVOID THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY AS IT POSES RISK TO FLIGHT SAFETY Microbursts are associated with thunderstorms and are one of the most dangerous sources of windshear
A windshear encounter is a very dynamic event which can strike suddenly and with devastating effect which has been beyond the recovery powers of experienced pilots flying modern and powerful aircraft
The first and most vital defence is avoidance
learning.explanation: ALL EFFORTS SHALL BE MADE TO AVOID THUNDERSTORM ACTIVITY AS IT POSES RISK TO FLIGHT SAFETY Microbursts are associated with thunderstorms and are one of the most dangerous sources of windshear. A windshear encounter is a very dynamic event which can strike suddenly and with devastating effect which has been beyond the recovery powers of experienced pilots flying modern and powerful aircraft. The first and most vital defence is avoidance. AWARENESS AND AVOIDANCE Awareness of the weather conditions that cause windshear will reduce the risk of an encounter. If a windshear encounter is likely, the takeoff or landing should be delayed until the conditions improve, e.g. until a thunderstorm has moved away from the airport. Windshear represents a severe threat to aviation safety, the best option is to avoid it whenever possible. Nevertheless, in the case of an actual encounter with windshear, it is essential to be to quickly recognize it and then recover from it. PREVENTION A key element of adverse weather avoidance strategies is the active monitoring of the overall meteorological situation by the crew, in addition to the optimum use of the weather radar and correct understanding of the information displayed. The take-off, initial climb, final approach and landing phases of flight in the vicinity of thunderstorms may present the pilot with additional problems because of the airplane‘s proximity to the ground. To maintain a safe flight path in these phases can be very difficult. Do not take off if a thunderstorm is overhead or approaching. At destination, hold if a thunderstorm is overhead or approaching or divert if necessary. On the approach, if there is ever any doubt that you can regain a reasonable rate of descent, and land without abnormal manoeuvres, you should apply full power and go-around or make a missed approach. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Delay the approach, and divert if necessary. CORRECT: As the explanation suggests, in case of thunderstorm activity, the first mitigating action should be to avoid and therefore delay take-off/landing or divert if necessary. 2. Plan a flapless approach and landing. INCORRECT: Flaps/slats should be used for every normal approach, including those with thunderstorms present as they lower the stall speed and in the case of slats increase the critical angle of attack. 3. Maintain a speed at least 30 kt above normal approach speed. INCORRECT: Choosing to fly at a speed slightly higher than normal approach speed is a good technique to aid with speed fluctuations characteristic of thunderstorm activity. However, this would be type specific, and there is no general rule for an approach to be flown 30 knots faster than normal. 4. Delay landing flap selection until 200 ft. INCORRECT: Delaying the configuration of the aircraft is not a recommended for this type of approach, specially to as low as 200 ft. 5. Expect and prepare for a windshear warning and a go-around. CORRECT: As stated above, the first mitigating action should be to avoid the thunderstorms. On the approach, if avoiding is not possible, the crew should be prepared to perform a go-around.

content.question: The wing of an aeroplane will never stall at low subsonic speeds as long as...

options.A: the angle of attack is smaller than the value at which the stall occurs.
options.B: the IAS exceeds the power-on stall speed.
options.C: there is a nose-down attitude.
options.D: the CAS exceeds the power-on stall speed.

key_points: There is a certain angle of attack (AOA), at which the flow cannot follow the shape of the profile, the flow separates from the surface and vortices are created
This results in a smaller suction, smaller lift and high drag
If AOA is increased further beyond this AOA, lift will reduce
learning.explanation: There is a certain angle of attack (AOA), at which the flow cannot follow the shape of the profile, the flow separates from the surface and vortices are created. This results in a smaller suction, smaller lift and high drag. If AOA is increased further beyond this AOA, lift will reduce. This angle of attack is called critical angle of attack. The critical angle of attack will remain the same regardless of gross weight. A given wing will always stall at the same AOA, regardless of weight, load factor, density altitude and airspeed. However, increased weight, a higher load factor and increased density altitude do increase the airspeed at which the aircraft reaches its critical AOA.

content.question: What is holdover time?

options.A: The amount of time available holding over a fix before a diversion is necessary.
options.B: The amount of time taken for de/anti-icing fluid to become effective once applied.
options.C: The expected time spent in the hold before an approach clearance will be given.
options.D: The amount of time a de/anti-icing fluid will remain effective after application.

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.03.01.05.14: Explain de-icing/anti-icing holdover time and the likely hazards after it has expired. Holdover Time (HOT) is the estimated time the anti-icing fluid will prevent the formation of ice and frost and the accumulation of snow on the protected (treated) surfaces of an aeroplane. The HOT begins whenever the anti-icing stage begins, in single stage de/anti-icing, that is the beginning of the first stage, for 2 stage de/anti-icing, that is the beginning of the second stage. The responsibility regarding HOT and subsequent re-application of de-ice/anti-ice (if applicable) rests with the Commander from the time he has received the final report about the treatment from the Anti/De-icing person in charge. Hold-over Times are only guidelines because a variety of factors can change the effectiveness of the fluid. These factors include high winds, jet blasts, wet snow heavy precipitation, aircraft skin temperature lower than outside air temperature, direct sunlight, etc. Monitoring of the environmental conditions is therefore essential. If in doubt, a visual or tactile check must be performed before take-off to make sure the airframe is clean. Not many people know that this is a PoF learning objective, and this is the first question we've seen on it under this syllabus.

content.question: An aircraft with a mass of 1500 kg has a 1 g stall speed of 73 kt. What is the stall speed when flying in a 45º bank turn at a mass of 1192 kg?

key_points: The stall speed is defined by: VS = √((2∗W) / (ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) In this exercise there is a decrease in mass and an increase in load factor due to the turn, therefore: mNEW = 1192 kg mOLD = 1500 kg VS OLD = 73 kt nNEW = 1/cos(45°) Lets first calculate the new VS in straight and level flight (VS NEW 1G): VS NEW 1G = √(mNEW /mOLD ) * VS OLD = √(1192/1500) * 73 = 65 kt Finaly, the new VS with an angle of bank of 45°: VS NEW = √(nNEW) * VS NEW 1G = √(1/cos(45°)) * 65 = 77 kt VS NEW ≈ 77 kt The new stall speed with decreased weight and increased load factor is 77 knots

content.question: The maximum cruise altitude can be limited by a 1.3 g load factor because when exceeding that altitude:

options.A: use of normal manoeuvring bank angles may cause the limit load factor to be exceeded.
options.B: turbulence may cause the limit load factor to be exceeded.

key_points: High-speed buffet is the rapid movement of the control surfaces caused by turbulent airflow passing over them
It can only occur when the Mach number is above the critical Mach number and is likely to be accompanied by a tendency for the airplane to pitch nose-down
The maximum operating altitude of an airplane can be restricted by the load factor
learning.explanation: High-speed buffet is the rapid movement of the control surfaces caused by turbulent airflow passing over them. It can only occur when the Mach number is above the critical Mach number and is likely to be accompanied by a tendency for the airplane to pitch nose-down. The maximum operating altitude of an airplane can be restricted by the load factor. Above that altitude any turbulence may induce Mach buffet, which could cause the airplane to exceed the maximum permitted load factor. The airflow behind a shockwave is turbulent and can cause a rapid vibrating movement of the horizontal stabilizer surfaces and is often referred to as the ‘shock stall’ and is the primary cause of high-speed buffet. A secondary cause of the rapid movement of the control surfaces, especially with supercritical airfoil sections, is when the wing reaches a speed of MCRIT the relatively weak shockwave that forms moves rapidly backward and forward over the surface of the wing producing similar indications to those of the shock stall.

learning.explanation: STALL A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift. Specifically, a stall occurs when the AOA—the angle between the chord line of the wing and the relative wind—exceeds the wing’s critical AOA. It is possible to exceed the critical AOA at any airspeed, at any attitude, and at any power setting. Impending Stall—an impending stall occurs when the AOA causes a stall warning, but has not yet reached the critical AOA. Indications of an impending stall can include buffeting, stick shaker, or aural warning. Full Stall—a full stall occurs when the critical AOA is exceeded. Indications of a full stall are typically that an uncommanded nose-down pitch cannot be readily arrested, and this may be accompanied by an uncommanded rolling motion. The flying controls will feel unresponsive or “mushy”. For airplanes equipped with stick pushers, its activation is also a full stall indication.

content.question: Which of these statements about boundary layers is correct?

options.A: Compared with a turbulent boundary layer, a laminar boundary layer is better able to resist a positive pressure gradient before it separates.
options.B: A turbulent boundary layer turns into a laminar one at the transition point.
options.C: A laminar boundary layer is thicker than a turbulent one.
options.D: A turbulent boundary layer produces more friction drag than a laminar one.

key_points: There is a layer of air that clings to the surface of an object and resists movement
This characteristic of the air is its viscosity, which although very small, is enough for the molecules of the air in contact with a surface to stick to the surface
It is static and therefore causes the laminar streamline flow adjacent to this layer to slow down, which in turn produces turbulence
learning.explanation: There is a layer of air that clings to the surface of an object and resists movement. This characteristic of the air is its viscosity, which although very small, is enough for the molecules of the air in contact with a surface to stick to the surface. It is static and therefore causes the laminar streamline flow adjacent to this layer to slow down, which in turn produces turbulence. The speed of the airflow changes from zero at the surface of the airfoil to the full speed of the free flow airstream a few millimeters away from the surface. This thin layer of sluggish air that clings to the surface of the object and in which the speed change of the airflow takes place is the boundary layer. In aerodynamics the boundary layer is important when considering wing stall, skin friction drag and heat transfer in high-speed flight. Boundary layers may be laminar (layered) or turbulent (disordered). The boundary layer increases in thickness as it moves rearward over an aircraft wing, with the turbulent boundary layer being proportionally thicker than the laminar boundary layer under the same free stream velocity conditions. The turbulent boundary layer has much higher local velocities immediately adjacent to the surface. The airflow in this region therefore possesses much higher kinetic energy than the laminar boundary layer at the same distance above the surface. The rapid velocity change associated with the turbulent boundary layer is evidence of high skin friction drag. The turbulent boundary has less tendency to separate from the airfoil surface over which it is flowing than the laminar boundary layer because it is better able to withstand the positive pressure gradient.

learning.explanation: The boundary layer is the layer of fluid (in our case this fluid is the atmosphere) in the immediate surface of a bounding surface (the airfoil) where the effects of viscosity are significant. There are two types of boundary layer; the laminar and the turbulent boundary layer. In the laminar boundary layer, the flow moves parallel to the surface over which it flows. In the laminar boundary layer, the air flows very smoothly. The velocity increases with distance from the airfoil and there is no movement of air perpendicular to the surface of the airfoil. Laminar flow creates less friction drag than the turbulent flow, but is less stable. At a distance from the leading edge of the airfoil, the air transitions from a laminar flow to a turbulent flow. This air does not flow smoothly, it contains swirls. There is flow in parallel and perpendicular direction. This air creates more drag than the laminar air flow, but breaks down less easily and is therefore more stable.

The worst scenario is swept-wing and T-tail. Due to swept-back wing a deep stall occurs because of wing tip stall. Furthermore, stabilizer becomes ineffective because it is situated in the separated turbulent flow of the wing and fuselage. Aircraft with swept-back wings are prone to deep stall, regardless of horizontal stabilizer position (T-tail or low tail). T-tail will worsen recovery characteristics.

content.question: How does stall speed (IAS) vary with altitude?

options.A: It remains constant.
options.B: It increases with increasing altitude, because the density decreases.
options.C: It remains constant at lower altitudes but increases at higher altitudes due to compressibility effects.
options.D: It remains constant at lower altitudes but decreases at higher altitudes due to compressibility effects.

key_points: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1 / 2 ρV2

Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes
If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes
learning.explanation: The stall speed is defined by: VS=√((2∗W)/(ρ∗S∗CLMAX)) At the stalling angle CLMAX and S are constant, and the indicated airspeed is given by the dynamic pressure 1 / 2 ρV2. Therefore, for the same airplane mass and configuration in straight and level flight, if the slight difference between EAS and IAS caused by compressibility is ignored, an airplane will stall at the same IAS at all altitudes. If, however, compressibility is not ignored then the stalling IAS value slowly increases with increased altitude, but the change only becomes significant at very high altitudes. At a constant EAS, Mach number will increase as altitude increases. Figure 1 shows the variation of stalling speed with altitude at constant load factor (n). Such a curve is called the stalling boundary for the given load factor, in which altitude is plotted against equivalent airspeed. At this load factor (1g), the aircraft cannot fly at speeds to the left of this boundary. Over the lower range of altitude, stall speed does not vary with altitude. This is because at these low altitudes, the Mach number at VS is too low for compressibility effects to be present. Eventually (approximately 30000 ft), Mach number at VS has increased with altitude to such an extent that these effects are important, and the rise in stalling speed with altitude is apparent. As altitude increases, stall speed is initially constant then increases, due to compressibility.

content.question: In a descending turn, the inner (down pointing) wing is travelling (1) _____ than the outer (up pointing) wing, so if the airspeed drops too low, a stall towards the (2) _____ is most likely.

options.B: (1) slower; (2) outside
options.C: (1) faster; (2) inside
options.D: (1) slower; (2) inside

key_points: In any turn, it is better to be coordinated, which means the airflow is hitting the aircraft exactly upon the nose, and the aircraft is not skidding or slipping into the turn

Whilst this will even out some of the common issues with different angles of attack, the inside wing of the turn will still be going slightly slower than the outside wing, and will have a higher angle of attack, especially when descending, so will be more prone to entering the stall if the airspeed drops too low
This is a common problem on the turn from base to final in the circuit, and a killer of many pilots who didn't watch their airspeed
learning.explanation: In any turn, it is better to be coordinated, which means the airflow is hitting the aircraft exactly upon the nose, and the aircraft is not skidding or slipping into the turn. Whilst this will even out some of the common issues with different angles of attack, the inside wing of the turn will still be going slightly slower than the outside wing, and will have a higher angle of attack, especially when descending, so will be more prone to entering the stall if the airspeed drops too low. This is a common problem on the turn from base to final in the circuit, and a killer of many pilots who didn't watch their airspeed. The slower inside wing will be quite likely to stall first. This is particularly bad as the aircraft is already banked in this direction, so will be quick to lose even more control and possibly even go inverted. As a side note; slipping in the turn will make it more likely to stall the outside wing, which is slightly better. Skidding turns are especially bad, as they amplify the problems mentioned above, and make it very probable that the inner wing will stall first, which will quickly become a spin.

options.A: Initial reduction in the rate of descent.

key_points: A microburst during takeoff or landing is particularly dangerous if the pilot has reduced power and lowered the nose in response to the headwind
This leaves the aircraft in a low-power, nose-low configuration, making it difficult to recover when the wind switches to a tailwind
Due to the potential of a 30-90 knot loss in headwind, the airplane could stall or land short of the runway
learning.explanation: A microburst during takeoff or landing is particularly dangerous if the pilot has reduced power and lowered the nose in response to the headwind. This leaves the aircraft in a low-power, nose-low configuration, making it difficult to recover when the wind switches to a tailwind. Due to the potential of a 30-90 knot loss in headwind, the airplane could stall or land short of the runway. Flying through a Microburst 1. Imagine you're approaching a microburst at 80 knots. As you enter the vortex ring, you experience turbulence and a rapid increase in IAS as you pick up a headwind. You start to climb as your performance increases. 2. As you enter the strongest part of the horizontal shaft, your airspeed peaks at 100 knots, an increase of 20 knots. You're still climbing as you enter the downdraft. 3. Inside the downdraft, your headwind starts to switch to a tailwind. You're caught in the downdraft, sinking quickly toward the ground. Your airspeed begins to decrease. 4. As you exit the downdraft, your tailwind increases rapidly. The shear drops your airspeed to 60 knots, which is 20 knots below your original speed. You're at a high angle-of-attack, and still descending. 5. You encounter more turbulence as you enter the final vortex. If you haven't already hit the ground, you may begin to climb again as you exit the vortex.

content.question: What is the significance of the maximum allowed cruising altitude, based on the 1.3 g margin? At this altitude:

options.A: exceeding a load factor of 1.3 will cause permanent deformation of this aeroplane.
options.B: a manoeuvre with a load factor of 1.3 will cause a Mach number at which accelerated low speed stall occurs.
options.C: a manoeuvre with a load factor of 1.3 will cause MCRIT to be exceeded.
options.D: a manoeuvre with a load factor of 1.3 will cause buffet onset.

key_points: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor
In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range
The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries
learning.explanation: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor. In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range. The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries. The margin between the two types of stall narrows with increasing altitude. Notably the true airspeed of the low-speed stall increases with increasing altitude for a given indicated airspeed, whilst the true airspeed of the shock stall reduces up to the base of the tropopause, above which it remains constant. The point at which the two stalls coincide is referred to as the 'coffin corner'. The altitude at which an aircraft can fly at one airspeed in a 1g maneuver is called the aerodynamic ceiling. For any given combination of mass, center of gravity position and airspeed, the maximum operating altitude is that altitude at which a normal positive acceleration increment of 0.3g, without exceeding the buffet onset boundary, is possible. It is, therefore, common practice to draw the ‘buffet-onset boundary chart’ for a range of cruise masses at 1.3g. Any maneuver having a load factor exceeding 1.3g will initiate the buffet onset.

content.question: Which of the following may occur when taking off in icing conditions?

options.A: The aeroplane will develop a nose down moment and the effect is worse with flaps extended.
options.B: The aeroplane will develop a nose up moment and the effect is worse with flaps retracted.
options.C: The aeroplane will develop a nose up moment and the effect is worse with flaps extended.
options.D: The aeroplane will develop a nose down moment and the effect is worse with flaps retracted.

key_points: Note: Our initial feedback said that this came from a Performance exam, but we think that may be incorrect, as there are no Performance LOs close to this topic, but in Principles of Flight, the LO 081
learning.explanation: Note: Our initial feedback said that this came from a Performance exam, but we think that may be incorrect, as there are no Performance LOs close to this topic, but in Principles of Flight, the LO 081.03.01.05.08 pertains to it exactly. Please let us know if you see it in your exam, and which exam that is, thank you! TAILPLANE STALL Whilst it is not immediately identifiable by the question, this is asking about tailplane stalls due to icing. The tailplane (or horizontal stabiliser) is a second wing mounted at the rear of the aircraft to allow for stability, and for control (with the elevator), and in fact, is usually used to provide downwards lift to keep the aircraft's nose up, and counteract the weight/lift couple (which pushes the nose down). The tailplane is often quite a lot thinner than the main wing, so it builds up ice quicker, and means that tailplane stall due to icing can occur when there is little to no main wing ice accretion. A tailplane stall is made worse by the extension of flaps, as they increase the downwash from the main wing, which causes a larger negative angle of attack on the tailplane, which is more likely to stall the tailplane. Flaps also move the centre of pressure further back, which increases the Cg/Cp (Weight/Lift) couple, which means the elevator needs to create more downforce to keep the nose up. As the downforce from the tail decreases due to tail stall, there is a strong nose-down moment created. This is made worse - as mentioned above - by the use of flaps. The worst speed/configuration for this type of stall is just under the maximum flap speed (VFE), with flaps extended.

content.question: The pitch-up stall behaviour of a swept wing aircraft at subsonic speed is due to the centre of pressure moving:

options.A: Forward when the wing tips stall first.
options.B: Backward when the wing roots stall first.
options.C: Backward when the wing tips stall first.
options.D: Forward when the wing roots stall first.

key_points: A swept wing is designed to allow a higher maximum speed with better transonic flight characteristics, but this does mean that it sacrifices some of its low-speed flight characteristics
When swept wings are unmodified, they have a strong tendency to stall first near the tips
Loss of lift at the tips moves the CP forward, giving a nose-up pitching moment as the lift is being produce from further forwards
learning.explanation: A swept wing is designed to allow a higher maximum speed with better transonic flight characteristics, but this does mean that it sacrifices some of its low-speed flight characteristics. When swept wings are unmodified, they have a strong tendency to stall first near the tips. Loss of lift at the tips moves the CP forward, giving a nose-up pitching moment as the lift is being produce from further forwards. This tendency to tip stall is due to the induced spanwise flow of the boundary layer from root to tip. During a tip stall, all the lift production is concentrated inboard and the maximum downwash now impacts the tail plane, adding to the nose-up pitching moment. As soon as a swept wing begins to stall, both forward CP movement and increased downwash at the tail plane cause the aircraft nose to rise rapidly, further increasing the angle of attack. This is a very undesirable and unacceptable response at the stall and can result in complete loss of control in pitch from which it may be very difficult, or even impossible, to recover. This is a very dangerous characteristic of many high speed, swept wing aircraft. For this reason, commercial swept wing aircraft are fitted with modifications to ensure the root stalls first. These can be vortex generators, or washout of the wing to reduce the tip angle of incidence, etc.

content.question: A pilot is testing the slow flight characteristics of an aeroplane with tapered (non swept) wings. Which of the following could they expect to experience approaching the stall?

options.A: A light buffet on the ailerons.
options.B: A heavy buffet through the elevators.
options.C: An aggressive pitch up moment.
options.D: The controls feeling light and ineffective.

key_points: Tapered wings are when the tips of the wing have a shorter chord than the root of the wing
This can lead to efficiencies in terms of lift distribution and induced drag, but when they are unmodified, produce less than ideal stalling characteristics
Wings on large aircraft are usually tapered and swept back, but here we are talking of unswept wings only
learning.explanation: Tapered wings are when the tips of the wing have a shorter chord than the root of the wing. This can lead to efficiencies in terms of lift distribution and induced drag, but when they are unmodified, produce less than ideal stalling characteristics. Wings on large aircraft are usually tapered and swept back, but here we are talking of unswept wings only. Tapered wings are prone to stalling first near the wing tips, and this stall spreads out forwards and inwards towards the root. This is undesireable as the stall affects the ailerons first, and makes this planform very susceptible to a violent wing drop. The first sign of stall on these aeroplanes often comes as a buffet through the ailerons, starting light and getting heavier, until the ailerons are fully stalled and have either a reverse effect or very little effect on aircraft control. Given where the stall occurs, and the likelihood of an early wing drop, elevator buffet is unlikely and pitching moments are quite limited. There is sometimes a pitch down moment due to the Centre of Pressure moving rearwards during the stall, but it is often not enough to avoid the formation of a spin. Hence, these aircraft wing planforms are usually modified in some way to avoid tip stalls and encourage the wing roots to stall first.

content.question:
A pilot is flying an aeroplane whose clean configuration stall speed is 60 kt. While cruising at 95 kt the pilot has to take avoiding action against another aeroplane.
The pilot banks the aeroplane sharply and during this manoeuvre, the aeroplane stalls.
Why did the aeroplane stall at 95 kt?

options.A: A large movement of the ailerons causes both wings to stall at the tips.
options.B: In a turn, the aeroplane weight increases, which increases the stall speed.
options.C: A wing stalls when its critical angle of attack is exceeded, regardless of speed.
options.D: The change in airflow due to rapid rolling causes the up-moving wing to stall.

key_points: The low-speed stall occurs at a particular angle of attack of the wing to the relative airflow, not at a specific airspeed
In a manoeuvre such as the one described in the question, the load factor on the wing will increase as the pilot pulls back on the stick, requiring more lift from the wing
This required a higher angle of attack, and obviously the pilot has exceeded the critical angle of attack in this case, and stalled the aeroplane
learning.explanation: The low-speed stall occurs at a particular angle of attack of the wing to the relative airflow, not at a specific airspeed. In a manoeuvre such as the one described in the question, the load factor on the wing will increase as the pilot pulls back on the stick, requiring more lift from the wing. This required a higher angle of attack, and obviously the pilot has exceeded the critical angle of attack in this case, and stalled the aeroplane. The low-speed stall occurs because boundary layer becomes detached from the upper surface of the wing. This happens because the low pressure at the front of the wing upper surface becomes too strong, and the airflow gets too slow (de-energised), so the strong adverse pressure gradient pulls back the low speed air within the boundary layer, and eventually the air current starts to flip, and the boundary layer separates completely, causing turbulent, stalled airflow. content.question:
Which of these statements about the buffet free range in a buffet onset boundary graph are correct or incorrect?
1. During a push-over manoeuvre the buffet free range decreases.
2. When the mass increases the buffet free range decreases.

options.A: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor
In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range
The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries
learning.explanation: Stall boundaries set a lower limit to the operating speed, according to the load factor. In the case of a high-speed aircraft, there is also an upper limit which is due to the approach of shock stall and the associated buffet which occurs if the aircraft enters the transonic speed range. The limits associated with these effects give the buffet boundaries. For a given aircraft there is a Mach number which, even at low angle of attack, cannot be exceeded because of the onset of shock stall. The EAS corresponding to this Mach number falls as altitude increases, so the range of operating speeds is reduced at both ends. Also, an increase in load factor (bank angle) requires an increase in lift at a given EAS, hence an increase in angle of attack and a further reduction in limiting Mach number. Thus, the greater the load factor (bank angle or gust), the more severe the limitation due to buffeting. We can then conclude that decreasing load factor (push-over maneuver) increases the buffet margin, therefore statement 1 is incorrect. The weight of the aircraft also affects the envelope. An increase in weight results in an increase in stall speed, and the stall boundary is moved to the right. It also results in an increase in angle of attack at any given speed, so that the Mach number at which buffeting occurs is reduced, and the buffet boundary is moved to the left. Finally, increase in weight implies a reduction in the maximum permissible ‘g’. Thus, all the boundaries are made more restrictive by an increase in weight. We can then conclude that increasing weight (mass) decreases the buffet margin, therefore statement 2 is correct.

learning.explanation: Note: this is based on incomplete feedback on questions 819856 and 815947, please put any further exam feedback in the comments or email it to us at info@atplquestions.com so we can verify the question, thanks! The ITCZ (Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone) is an area of very large uplift and often violent thunderstorms due to converging air at the surface. It is also a region where the tropopause will be incredibly high, sometimes in the region of 55-60,000 ft. This makes it often impossible to climb away from the turbulence experienced in that region. The turbulence can cause lots of passenger distress and potential for airframe fatigue and damage when it gets severe enough. It can also change our airspeed enough to put us into either the high- or low-speed buffeting region, so we should instead descend to a lower altitude, out of the potential “coffin corner” and fly at turbulence penetration speed (this usually means slowing down from cruise speed) to get the best safety margin for turbulence.

A push-over manoeuvre is where the pilot pushes the controls forward and the load factor is reduced (usually to around zero G, but the manoeuvre is whenever the load factor is temporarily pushed below 1G). It is highly useful for reducing the load on the wings, and can break a stall immediately, as an aircraft cannot stall when the load factor is zero, allowing control to be regained temporarily to allow the aircraft to be stabilised and the airspeed to be increased. The angle of attack is reduced during a push-over manoeuvre, and this is a key part of unloading the wings.

If the aircraft increases angle of attack above this value, it will enter a stall

learning.explanation: The critical angle of attack is the angle of attack producing the maximum lift coefficient. If the aircraft increases angle of attack above this value, it will enter a stall. This value can be increased with the use of slats. Slats delay the separation of the boundary layer, by adding kinetic energy into it. A clean wing has a lower value of CLMAX, causing the Angle of Attack for a clean wing to be lower than for a wing with slats extended. A wing with flaps extended has the lowest value of CLMAX. In straight and level flight, prior to the stall, lift remains constant. Speed decreases and CL increases. In the stall (so after CLMAX has passed) the CL decreases again and speed is still low. content.question: An aeroplane slows down at high altitude towards the stall. The aircraft might be considered to have stalled even below the critical angle of attack if…

options.A: maximum continuous thrust is required to remain in level flight.
options.B: control effectiveness reduces, such that large deflection is needed to maintain wings level.
options.C: the coefficient of lift decreases with increased angle of attack.
options.D: buffet is so strong that it deters the pilot from further speed reduction.

key_points: When an airplane is flying, the airflow over the wings creates lift
As the angle of attack (AOA) increases, the lift generated by the wings also increases
However, at a certain AOA, the smooth flow of air over the wings is disrupted, and the airflow separates from the wing's surface
learning.explanation: When an airplane is flying, the airflow over the wings creates lift. As the angle of attack (AOA) increases, the lift generated by the wings also increases. However, at a certain AOA, the smooth flow of air over the wings is disrupted, and the airflow separates from the wing's surface. This leads to a sudden loss of lift, which is known as a stall. Option a) "maximum continuous thrust is required to remain in level flight." is not correct because the need for maximum continuous thrust to maintain level flight is not necessarily an indication of a stall. Option b) "control effectiveness reduces, such that large deflection is needed to maintain wings level." is also not correct because while control effectiveness may reduce as the AOA increases, it is not a definitive indicator of a stall. Option c) "the coefficient of lift decreases with increased angle of attack." is a true statement about the coefficient of lift, but it does not necessarily indicate a stall. Option d) "buffet is so strong that it deters the pilot from further speed reduction." is the correct answer because when an airplane approaches a stall, the airflow over the wings becomes turbulent, which can cause buffeting or vibration of the aircraft. If the buffeting is strong enough, it can deter the pilot from further reducing the speed, as it is an indication that the airplane is approaching a stall. Therefore, strong buffeting is a definitive indicator of an imminent stall.

content.question:
Following stall warning activation, what indicates that the warning is not false, and that recovery action is required?

4. Unusually low indicated airspeed, confirmed on both sets of instruments

key_points: STALL A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift
Specifically, a stall occurs when the AOA—the angle between the chord line of the wing and the relative wind—exceeds the wing’s critical AOA
It is possible to exceed the critical AOA at any airspeed, at any attitude, and at any power setting
learning.explanation: STALL A stall is an aerodynamic condition which occurs when smooth airflow over the airplane’s wings is disrupted, resulting in loss of lift. Specifically, a stall occurs when the AOA—the angle between the chord line of the wing and the relative wind—exceeds the wing’s critical AOA. It is possible to exceed the critical AOA at any airspeed, at any attitude, and at any power setting. Impending Stall—an impending stall occurs when the AOA causes a stall warning, but has not yet reached the critical AOA. Indications of an impending stall can include buffeting, stick shaker, or aural warning. Full Stall—a full stall occurs when the critical AOA is exceeded. Indications of a full stall are typically that an uncommanded nose-down pitch cannot be readily arrested, and this may be accompanied by an uncommanded rolling motion. The flying controls will feel unresponsive or “mushy”. For airplanes equipped with stick pushers, its activation is also a full stall indication.

For the aircraft to maintain altitude, the vertical force components must be balanced. Lift is inclined from the vertical by the bank angle φ of 45° and must be increased in order to balance the weight and produce a force to perform the turn. More lift compared to the same weight increases the load factor n. Influence of the Load Factor (n) on Stall Speed VS = VS1G x √ n Because the load factor (n) increases in a turn, stall speed will increase accordingly. An accelerated stall is caused by abrupt or excessive control movements inducing an increased load factor. An accelerated stall can occur during a sudden change in the flight path, during manoeuvres such as steep turns or a recovery from a descent. It is called an accelerated stall because it occurs at a load factor greater than 1g. The stall is more violent than a 1g stall and is often unexpected because of the relatively high airspeed.

learning.explanation: NUISANCE STALL WARNING A nuisance stall warning event is one in which the stall warning activates although the airplane is not near a stall condition. For steady speed, the thrust and two effects of aerodynamic drag and weight must be equal
learning.explanation: The balance of forces in steady climb show thrust is partly acting upwards and weight is partly adding to the drag. Because the thrust is now assisting lift, there is less lift required than in level flight. For steady speed, the thrust and two effects of aerodynamic drag and weight must be equal. T= Thrust W= Weight D= Drag T= D + W sin(alfa) This means that the climb angle (sin alfa) depends on excess thrust and weight. In descent the formula will become T= D – W sin(alfa) The load factor is the relationship between lift and weight. As the lift in a stall is decreased and the load factor in straight and level flight is 1, the load factor will now be less than 1. The steeper the climb-/descent angle, the lower the load factor. A push-over manoeuvre is a manoeuvre where there is more weight than lift. A negative G-force is therefore generated and the load factor is less than 1.

content.question: During a turn from base to final, the pilot applies more rudder to the inside of the turn, skidding the aircraft, to avoid overshooting the runway. The risk is:

options.B: Spin towards the low wing.

key_points: Most stall-spin accidents don't happen during an intentional stall
They usually happen unintentionally and down low - like when you're turning base to final
During a skid, the aircraft is turning too fast for the bank angle, and yaws into the turn
learning.explanation: Most stall-spin accidents don't happen during an intentional stall. They usually happen unintentionally and down low - like when you're turning base to final. During a skid, the aircraft is turning too fast for the bank angle, and yaws into the turn. (Most likely, you're pushing too much rudder and causing the skid.) That causes the outside wing to move faster, increasing its lift, and causing the aircraft to roll into the turn. You compensate by adding opposite aileron - increasing the angle of attack on the inside, low wing. As the inside wing exceeds the critical angle of attack, it stalls and drops. The downward deflected aileron on the low wing is still generating drag, which pulls the aircraft's nose further into the turn. And, the aircraft is still yawing into the turn from the rudder, which accelerates the roll. The result is a quick roll into the turn, and your entry into an incipient spin => In a skidding spin, the low/inside wing stalls first, which rolls the plane into the turn, flipping it "inside" or "underneath".

learning.explanation: Flat spins are the worst and most dangerous type of spin. In a flat spin, the aircraft has no forward airspeed. It spins around its vertical axis as it sinks straight towards the ground. Due to the high angle of attack of a flat spin, it is nearly impossible to recover, as the horizontal stabilizer is most likely in stall, too. The only possibility then is to move the CG forward. In small aircraft what you can do is to lean forward and hope for the best. The type of spin a plane enters depends mainly on the CG Position (and thrust setting): CG towards the forward limit makes an aircraft more stable, and control forces will be higher which makes it less likely that large, abrupt control movements will be made. When trimmed, the aeroplane will tend to return to level flight if the controls are released, but the stall speed will be higher. CG towards the aft limit decreases longitudinal static stability and reduces pitch control forces, which tends to make the aeroplane easier to stall. Once a spin is entered, the further aft the CG, the flatter the spin attitude. All in all, do not spin with an aircraft that is not designed for that or with too aft CG position. Note: Watch the following video to understand the attitude of the aircraft during a flat spin https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=22eADnRqMwo&t=16s

The high speed buffet boundary marks the onset of high speed buffeting. This speed is Mmo most of the time, sometimes it is slightly below. These speeds come closer together as altitude increases. content.question:
Refer to figure.
Regarding the Buffet Onset Boundary Chart in the annex, which of these statements are correct or incorrect?
1. Flying at M = 0.8 provides the optimum margin with respect to buffet onset.
2. The maximum altitude that can be achieved with respect to buffet onset, according to Certification Specifications, is higher at M = 0.82 than at M = 0.75.

options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.

key_points: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting
Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure
Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage
learning.explanation: In the same way that separated airflow prior to a low speed stall can cause airframe buffet, shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. Because of the higher dynamic pressure when an aircraft is operating in the transonic speed region, any shock induced buffet will have a greater potential for severe airframe damage. High speed buffet must be completely avoided. The aircraft must therefore be operated in such a manner that a (safety) margin exists before aerodynamic buffet will occur. If the variables which affect both high speed and low speed stall are considered it will be possible to identify the conditions under which buffeting will occur and a chart can be drawn to show all the factors involved. This is called a ‘Buffet Onset’ chart which is used by flight crews to ensure their aircraft is always operated with a specified minimum buffet margin. For any given combination of mass, center of gravity position and airspeed, the maximum operating altitude is that altitude at which a normal positive acceleration increment of 0.3g, without exceeding the buffet onset boundary, is possible. It is, therefore, common practice to draw the ‘buffet-onset boundary chart’ for a range of cruise masses at 1.3 g. Any maneuver having a load factor exceeding 1.3 g will initiate the buffet onset. In this exercise: This chart is specific to an aircraft, and shows the relationship of altitude, load factor, cruise data, weight, Mach number, and IAS. The optimum speed can be found by intersecting the top of the altitude curve. In this case it is M0.80, therefore statement 1 is correct. Start by drawing a vertical line from M0.82 and M0.75 to the FL410 curve (first altitude curve). From here, draw a straight line from left to right that intersects the weight curves. Finally, draw a vertical up from 1.3 g load factor that intersects the lines drawn in step 2. As we can see, flying at M0.82 gives us the ability to carry a greater weight. We can then conclude that it also gives us a higher buffet onset margin, therefore statement 2 is correct.

content.question:
What sort of characteristics should a pilot expect from a swept-back wing when it begins to stall, and why?
The aeroplane will:

options.A: Pitch up, due to forward movement of the centre of pressure, caused by the wing tips stalling first.
options.B: Pitch down, due to aft movement of the centre of pressure, caused by the wing root stalling first.
options.C: Pitch up, due to reduced downwash at the tailplane, caused by the wing root stalling first.
options.D: Pitch down, due to increased downwash at the tailplane, caused by the wing tips stalling first.

key_points: A simple swept-wing will stall at the wing tip first if not induced/controlled to stall at another wing section first by the designer

This is so because the outer wing section experiences a higher aerodynamic loading due to the wing taper, which causes a greater angle of incidence to be experienced to a degree where the airflow stalls at the wing tips
The boundary layer span-wise airflow, also a result of sweep, further contributes to the airflow stalling at the wing tips
learning.explanation: A simple swept-wing will stall at the wing tip first if not induced/controlled to stall at another wing section first by the designer. This is so because the outer wing section experiences a higher aerodynamic loading due to the wing taper, which causes a greater angle of incidence to be experienced to a degree where the airflow stalls at the wing tips. The boundary layer span-wise airflow, also a result of sweep, further contributes to the airflow stalling at the wing tips. A stall at the wing tip causes a loss of lift outboard and therefore aft (due to the wing sweep), which moves the center of pressure inboard and therefore forward; this produces a pitch-up tendency that continues as the wing stalls progressively further inboard.

content.question: Incipient spin is the term assigned to the phase of a spin:

options.A: After the initial couple of rotations and the aerodynamic forces present are in balance.
options.B: After the initial couple of rotations but the aerodynamic forces present are not yet fully balanced.
options.C: When the initial rotation starts and the aerodynamic forces present are in balance.
options.D: When the initial rotation starts but the aerodynamic forces present are not yet fully balanced.

key_points: SPIN
A stall must occur before a spin can take place
A spin occurs when one wing stalls more than the other
learning.explanation: SPIN. A stall must occur before a spin can take place. A spin occurs when one wing stalls more than the other. There are three phases of spin: INCIPIENT phase - exists from the time the aeroplane stalls and rotation starts until the spin is fully developed. This may not occur until 2 to 4 rotations have been completed - however, according to EASA, incipient spin starts already whenever, in the post stall regime, there is an uncommanded roll in excess of 45 degrees which is the result of yaw assymetry during a stall. During this phrase, the aerodynamic forces are not balanced and the aircraft is more or less tumbling. DEVELOPED phase - begins when the aerodynamic forces are in balance (the angular rotation rates, airspeed and vertical descent rate are stabilized from one turn to the next). The spin, although chaotic looking from inside the cockpit, has been established and recovery procedures are now necessary to break the spin. RECOVERY phase - controls are applied to stop spin, recover from the unusual attitude and maintain straight and level.

At the same time, the downwash from the inner wing sections becomes concentrated on the tailplane, giving a more severe nose-up pitch effect

The shift in the centre of pressure combined with the increase in downwash acting on the tailplane produces an overall nose-up pitching moment.
