key_points: Dutch roll is the undulating motion of an aeroplane in the directional and lateral planes, following a lateral disturbance to the equilibrium of the aeroplane

Dutch roll occurs when the directional stability of an aeroplane is weak and the lateral stability is strong, which may be exacerbated by an aft CG position because of the shortened corrective moment arm

If an aeroplane is disturbed laterally the combined rolling motion and yawing motion, either of which may be extreme, can cause oscillatory instability, which is much more serious than spiral instability
learning.explanation: Dutch roll is the undulating motion of an aeroplane in the directional and lateral planes, following a lateral disturbance to the equilibrium of the aeroplane. Dutch roll occurs when the directional stability of an aeroplane is weak and the lateral stability is strong, which may be exacerbated by an aft CG position because of the shortened corrective moment arm. If an aeroplane is disturbed laterally the combined rolling motion and yawing motion, either of which may be extreme, can cause oscillatory instability, which is much more serious than spiral instability. Modern jet transport aeroplanes are fitted with yaw dampers to relieve the pilot of the need to manually control Dutch roll.

content.question:
Sweepback of a wing positively influences:
1. static longitudinal stability.
2. static lateral stability.
3. dynamic longitudinal stability.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

key_points: Sweep Angle: The angle between the line of 25% chords and a perpendicular to the root chord
Purpose of Sweepback: To increase MCRIT
Sweepback factsheet: A Swept Wing Increases the Critical Mach Number (MCRIT)
learning.explanation: Sweep Angle: The angle between the line of 25% chords and a perpendicular to the root chord. Purpose of Sweepback: To increase MCRIT. Sweepback factsheet: A Swept Wing Increases the Critical Mach Number (MCRIT). All other effects from a swept wing are by-products, most of them disadvantages. However, the benefits from a higher MCRIT outweigh the associated disadvantages. Increased tendency to stall at the tip first: Tip stall can lead to pitch-up, a major disadvantage. Pitch-up can give the tendency for a swept wing aircraft to Super Stall. Aircraft that show a significant tendency to pitch-up at the stall must be fitted with a stall prevention device, a stick pusher. When compared to a straight wing of the same section, a swept wing is less aerodynamically efficient. At a given angle of attack CL is less, which increases the stall speed. CLMAX is less and occurs at a higher angle of attack. The lift curve has a smaller gradient (change in CL per degree change in alpha is less). Swept wings must be fitted with complex high lift devices, both leading and trailing edge, to give a reasonable take-off and landing distance. A swept wing must be flown at a higher angle of attack than a straight wing to give the required lift coefficient; this is most noticeable at low speeds. A swept wing makes a small positive contribution to static directional stability. A swept wing makes a significant positive contribution to static lateral stability. At speeds higher than MCRIT a swept wing generates a nose-down pitching moment, a phenomenon known as Tuck Under. The hinge line of trailing edge ‘flap’ type control surfaces is not at right angles to the airflow, which reduces the efficiency of the controls.

key_points: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor
The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”
The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude
learning.explanation: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor. The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”. The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude. The stick force gradient must not be excessively high, or the airplane will be difficult and tiring to maneuver. Also, the stick force gradient must not be too low, or the airplane may be overstressed inadvertently when light control forces exist. When the airplane has high static stability, the maneuvering stability will be high, and a high stick force gradient will result. A possibility exists that the forward CG limit could be set to prevent an excessively high maneuvering stick force gradient. As the CG moves forward, the stick force gradient increases with increasing maneuvering stability and the higher limit of stick force gradient may be reached.

As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure
learning.explanation: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP). This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating. As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure. Aircraft longitudinal stability is directly related to Centre of Gravity (CG) position. An aircraft with a more forward CG is more longitudinally stable than an aircraft with a more aft CG. Placing the CG beyond the forward limit can cause an unacceptably high value of longitudinal stability, decreasing manoeuvrability by a significant amount. Place the CG beyond the aft limit and the aircraft is too unstable, having excessive manoeuvrability. If an aircraft is longitudinally stable, an increase in Angle of Attack (α) results in a negative pitching moment. The nose will slightly fall down, decreasing the Angle of Attack. If this aircraft has a decrease of Angle of Attack, the nose will come slightly upwards again, creating a positive pitching moment again by slightly raising the nose. For this specific question, we can see that line 1 is the most longitudinally unstable aircraft and line 4 is the most longitudinally stable aircraft. With this information we can derive that the CG position is further aft at line 1 compared to line 4.

content.question: With a nose heavy aircraft (CG moves forward), the negative force produced by the horizontal stabiliser...

options.A: increases.
options.B: decreases.
options.C: remain the same.
options.D: the tailplane never produces a negative force.

key_points: Longitudinal stability is motion about the lateral axis

Static Longitudinal stability is the aircraft's natural tendency when disturbed in pitch, to return to its former trimmed angle of attack without pilot input, and is desirable throughout the aircraft's complete speed range
For the study of stability, we consider the changes in magnitude of lift force due to changes in angle of attack, acting through a stationary point, the aerodynamic centre (AC)
learning.explanation: Longitudinal stability is motion about the lateral axis. Static Longitudinal stability is the aircraft's natural tendency when disturbed in pitch, to return to its former trimmed angle of attack without pilot input, and is desirable throughout the aircraft's complete speed range. For the study of stability, we consider the changes in magnitude of lift force due to changes in angle of attack, acting through a stationary point, the aerodynamic centre (AC). There are two moments to consider: the wing moment and the tail moment: - The wing moment is a function of the change in wing lift multiplied by an arm (distance from wing CP to CG). - The tail moment is a function of the change in tailplane lift multiplied by arm (distance from tailplane CP to CG). The length of both arms is dependent upon CG position. If the CG is considered in a more forward position, the tail arm is larger and the wing arm is smaller. A more forward CG position increases static longitudinal stability. The position of the CG directly affects the magnitude of the longitudinal static stability, the tailplane downforce and the stalling speed because its position determines the length of the arm of any restoring moment. A forward movement of the CG increases the positive longitudinal static stability of an aircraft but decreases the manoeuvrability and control response because the moment arm is increased in length and increases the nose-down pitching moment. Thus, the required downforce on the tailplane increases.

content.question: In aircraft aerodynamics, what is the "static margin"?

options.A: The ratio of the tailplane’s lift coefficient to the wing’s lift coefficient.
options.B: The percentage of the mean aerodynamic chord (MAC) from the leading edge to the centre of gravity.
options.C: The distance between the centre of gravity (CG) and the neutral point.
options.D: The difference in angle between the aircraft’s longitudinal axis and the relative airflow.

key_points: STABILITY Stability of an aeroplane is its tendency to return to an original point after a disruption
Manoeuvrability is the exact opposite, it is how easy it is to change an aircraft's attitude or direction
With high stability comes low manoeuvrability (think large jet aircraft) and with low stability comes high manoeuvrability (fighter jets or aerobatic display aircraft)
learning.explanation: STABILITY Stability of an aeroplane is its tendency to return to an original point after a disruption. Manoeuvrability is the exact opposite, it is how easy it is to change an aircraft's attitude or direction. With high stability comes low manoeuvrability (think large jet aircraft) and with low stability comes high manoeuvrability (fighter jets or aerobatic display aircraft). The placement (forward/aft) of the CG is incredibly important to longitudinal stability (stability in pitch movements), as having a forward CG means that the effect of any movement affects the tailplane more than the main wing and the rest of the aircraft, and it has a greater stabilising effect (like the fins on a dart). The "neutral point" is the where the CG would be for the aircraft to have NEUTRAL static stability (in pitch). If the CG is in front of the neutral point, the aircraft is statically stable in pitch. The further forwards the CG goes, the more stable the aircraft gets. The location of the neutral point is decided by the aerodynamic surfaces and qualities of the aircraft only. The distance between the neutral point and the CG is called the static margin. The larger the static margin (forwards of the neutral point), the greater the stability, (and lower the manoeuvrability). As for the other options: "The ratio of the tailplane’s lift coefficient to the wing’s lift coefficient." Incorrect as these do not include the location of the CG. "The percentage of the mean aerodynamic chord (MAC) from the leading edge to the centre of gravity." Incorrect. This is describing the CG location as a percentage of the MAC. "The distance between the centre of gravity (CG) and the neutral point." Correct. "The difference in angle between the aircraft’s longitudinal axis and the relative airflow." This is close to the angle of attack, but not exactly. Certainly not the static margin.

key_points: CS 25
171 General The aeroplane must be longitudinally, directionally and laterally stable in accordance with the provisions of CS 25
learning.explanation: CS 25.171 General The aeroplane must be longitudinally, directionally and laterally stable in accordance with the provisions of CS 25.173 to 25.177. In addition, suitable stability and control feel (static stability) is required in any condition normally encountered in service, if flight tests show it is necessary for safe operation. Stability is the tendency of an aircraft to return to a steady state of flight (equilibrium) without any help from the pilot, after being disturbed by an external force. An aircraft must have the following qualities: Adequate stability to maintain a uniform flight condition The ability to recover from various disturbing influences Sufficient stability to minimize the workload of the pilot Proper response to the controls so that it may achieve its design performance with adequate manoeuvrability

content.question: Which of the following flight phenomena can occur at Mach numbers below the critical Mach number?

options.A: Dutch roll.
options.B: Tuck under.
options.C: Shock stall.
options.D: Mach buffet.

key_points: Critical Mach Number: (MCRIT) The critical Mach number is the Mach number of the aircraft when the speed of the airflow over some part of the aircraft first reaches the speed of sound
At high altitude, a large high-speed jet transport aircraft will be cruising at a speed marginally above its critical Mach number, and it will have a small shock wave on the wing
If such an aircraft overspeeds, the shock wave will rapidly grow larger, causing the static pressure to increase sharply in the immediate vicinity of the shock wave
learning.explanation: Critical Mach Number: (MCRIT) The critical Mach number is the Mach number of the aircraft when the speed of the airflow over some part of the aircraft first reaches the speed of sound. At high altitude, a large high-speed jet transport aircraft will be cruising at a speed marginally above its critical Mach number, and it will have a small shock wave on the wing. If such an aircraft overspeeds, the shock wave will rapidly grow larger, causing the static pressure to increase sharply in the immediate vicinity of the shock wave. The locally increased adverse pressure gradient will cause the boundary layer to separate immediately behind the shock wave. This is called a ‘shock stall’. Shock induced separation (shock stall) at high speed can also cause buffeting. Aerodynamic buffet is a valuable stall warning, but it can damage the aircraft structure. As the shock wave moves aft over the surface of the wing, the CP also moves aft. This aft movement combined with the reduced downwash at the tail plane due to the presence of the shockwave will lead to Tuck Under. As we can see, from all the options, shock stall, mach buffet and tuck under only occur when operating above MCRIT (transonic speed regime). Dutch roll occurs when the static lateral stability (caused by dihedral, etc.) is high in comparison to the static directional stability (caused by the tail fin, etc.) and may occur at Mach numbers below the critical Mach number.

content.question: Positive static stability of an aeroplane means that following a disturbance from the equilibrium condition:

options.B: the tendency is to move with an oscillatory motion of decreasing amplitude.
options.C: the initial tendency is to diverge further from its equilibrium condition.
options.D: the tendency is to move with an oscillatory motion of increasing amplitude.

key_points: An aircraft is in a state of equilibrium (trim) when the sum of all forces is zero and the sum of all moments is zero; there are no accelerations and the aircraft will continue in steady flight
If equilibrium is disturbed by a gust, or deflection of the controls, the aircraft will experience accelerations due to an unbalance of moments or forces
The type of static stability an aircraft possesses is defined by its initial tendency, following the removal of some disturbing force
learning.explanation: An aircraft is in a state of equilibrium (trim) when the sum of all forces is zero and the sum of all moments is zero; there are no accelerations and the aircraft will continue in steady flight. If equilibrium is disturbed by a gust, or deflection of the controls, the aircraft will experience accelerations due to an unbalance of moments or forces. The type of static stability an aircraft possesses is defined by its initial tendency, following the removal of some disturbing force. Positive static stability (or static stability) exists if an aircraft is disturbed from equilibrium and has the tendency to return to equilibrium. Neutral static stability exists if an aircraft is subject to a disturbance and has neither the tendency to return nor the tendency to continue in the displacement direction. Negative static stability (or static instability) exists if an aircraft tends to continue in the direction of disturbance.

learning.explanation: Static directional stability is a measure of the aircraft's resistance to slipping. The main contributor to the static directional stability is the fin. Both the size and atm of the fin determine the directional stability of the aircraft. The further the vertical fin is behind the centre of gravity, the more static directional stability the aircraft will have. If the centre of gravity moves aft, the destabilizing moment of the fuselage gets bigger, whereas the stabilizing moment of the vertical stabilizer reduces. Consequently, if CG moves aft, directional stability reduces.

content.question: An aircraft flying straight and level is displaced from equilibrium and enters in a spiral dive. After recovering from the spiral dive, the pilot applies again opposite rudder. How does this affect the aircraft?

options.A: The aircraft may enter a secondary spiral dive.
options.B: The aircraft will recover faster from the spiral dive.
options.C: The aircraft will recover from the spiral dive with some delay.
options.D: The aircraft will stall.

key_points: SPIRAL DIVERGENCE/INSTABILITY Spiral divergence will exist when static directional stability is very large when compared to the lateral stability
The character of spiral divergence is not violent
When a small sideslip is introduced, the strong directional stability tends to restore the nose into the wind while the relatively weak “dihedral effect” lags in restoring the aeroplane laterally
learning.explanation: SPIRAL DIVERGENCE/INSTABILITY Spiral divergence will exist when static directional stability is very large when compared to the lateral stability. The character of spiral divergence is not violent. When a small sideslip is introduced, the strong directional stability tends to restore the nose into the wind while the relatively weak “dihedral effect” lags in restoring the aeroplane laterally. The rate of divergence in the spiral motion is usually so gradual that the pilot can control the tendency without difficulty. Spiral instability is normally considered less objectionable than oscillatory instability, so most aircraft are designed to be spirally unstable. With this characteristic, when the aircraft is yawed, either by the prolonged application of rudder or asymmetric power, a rolling moment in the direction of yaw occurs and the aircraft quickly enters a spiral dive. This can occur when flying at low airspeeds under asymmetric power conditions, when excessive yaw due to too much power is coupled with insufficient rudder control to balance it, and may quickly place an aircraft in a dangerous attitude.

content.question: As the stability of an aeroplane increases:

key_points: Dutch Roll Dutch roll is a coupled lateral and directional oscillation which is undesirable because of the oscillatory nature

learning.explanation: Dutch Roll Dutch roll is a coupled lateral and directional oscillation which is undesirable because of the oscillatory nature. Dutch roll can occur when the static lateral stability (caused by dihedral, etc.) is high in comparison to the static directional stability (caused by the tail fin, etc.) Asymmetric shockwaves Modern transport jet aircraft tend to cruise at high altitudes with high Mach numbers, very close to - or just inside - the transonic regime. This is the range of speeds (At and above MCRIT) where some of the aircraft experiences supersonic airflow, but not all the aircraft does. This brings rise to shockwaves, first on the upper wing surfaces near the roots, then spreading to other areas of the aircraft. Shockwaves produce quite high drag forces, classed as "wave drag". If the shockwaves form asymmetrically on the aircraft, whether due to different airflow patterns over the wings, small differences in the aircraft structure, control surfaces, etc., then the different drag forces can cause a yawing motion, which sets off the oscillation known as Dutch roll. This Dutch roll would be made worse by the shockwaves forming on the faster wing, reducing lift and increasing drag to drop it down and drag it back, exacerbating the Dutch roll.

learning.explanation: A variation of CG position can cause large changes in the static longitudinal stability. key_points: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium
It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time

Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes
learning.explanation: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium. It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time. Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes. An airplane that is statically stable is not necessarily dynamically stable. However, for an airplane to be dynamically stable it must be statically stable. In other words, it cannot have long-term stability without first having short-term stability. An airplane that has positive static stability may be dynamically neutral, stable, or unstable; but an airplane that is statically unstable can never attain dynamic stability. The dynamic stability of an airplane is dependent on the airplane design, its speed, and the altitude at which it is flying. There are five states of dynamic stability and for each of them the airplane must have positive static stability. Negative dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation increases with the passage of time. Neutral dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation remains constant with the passage of time. Positive dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation decreases with the passage of time. ‘Dead beat’ positive dynamic stability – the oscillations cease immediately because they are heavily damped. ‘Divergent’ negative dynamic stability – the oscillations cease because the motion completely diverges from the original motion.

key_points: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor
The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”
The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude
learning.explanation: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor. The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”. The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude. The stick force gradient must not be excessively high, or the airplane will be difficult and tiring to maneuver. Also, the stick force gradient must not be too low, or the airplane may be overstressed inadvertently when light control forces exist. When the airplane has high static stability, the maneuvering stability will be high, and a high stick force gradient will result. A possibility exists that the forward CG limit could be set to prevent an excessively high maneuvering stick force gradient. As the CG moves aft, the stick force gradient decreases with decreasing maneuvering stability and the lower limit of stick force gradient may be reached. The aft limit, which for safety reasons on a transport airplane is always forward of the neutral point, is confined by insufficient stick-force stability and/or excessive in-flight maneuverability. The minimum stick force per ‘g’ for the maximum permitted load factor, which is 2.5 for large transport airplanes, determines the aft limit of the CG envelope. This means that with a more aft CG, a smaller force is required to achieve a given load factor. If the CG is more aft than anticipated and a force is applied with the same magnitude, the limit load factor may be exceeded.

key_points: Longitudinal stability is motion about the lateral axis

Static Longitudinal stability is the aircraft's natural tendency when disturbed in pitch, to return to its former trimmed angle of attack without pilot input, and is desirable throughout the aircraft's complete speed range
For the study of stability, we consider the changes in magnitude of lift force due to changes in angle of attack, acting through a stationary point, the aerodynamic centre (AC)
learning.explanation: Longitudinal stability is motion about the lateral axis. Static Longitudinal stability is the aircraft's natural tendency when disturbed in pitch, to return to its former trimmed angle of attack without pilot input, and is desirable throughout the aircraft's complete speed range. For the study of stability, we consider the changes in magnitude of lift force due to changes in angle of attack, acting through a stationary point, the aerodynamic centre (AC). There are two moments to consider: the wing moment and the tail moment. The wing moment is a function of the change in wing lift multiplied by arm ‘x’. The tail moment is a function of the change in tailplane lift multiplied by arm ‘y’. The length of both arms is dependent upon CG position. If the CG is considered in a more forward position, the tail arm is larger and the wing arm is smaller. A more forward CG position increases static longitudinal stability. If the nose-down (negative) tail moment is greater than the nose-up (positive) wing moment, the aircraft will have static longitudinal stability. NEUTRAL POINT If you consider the CG moving rearwards from a position of static longitudinal stability: - the tail arm ‘y’ will decrease and the wing arm ‘x’ will increase; - the (negative) tail moment will decrease and the (positive) wing moment will increase. Eventually the CG will reach a position at which the tail moment is the same as the wing moment. If a vertical gust displaces the aircraft nose-up, the sum of the moments will be zero and there will be no angular acceleration about the CG to return the aircraft towards its original position of equilibrium. Because there is no resultant moment, either nose-up or nose-down, the aircraft will remain in its new position of equilibrium; the aircraft will have neutral static longitudinal stability. The position of the CG when the sum of the changes in the tail moment and wing moment caused by the gust is zero is known as the neutral point.

key_points: DIRECTIONAL STATIC STABILITY The directional static stability of an aircraft is its natural tendency to recover from a disturbance in yaw, is mainly provided by the fin and involves moments about the normal axis and their relationship with yaw or sideslip angle
The sideslip angle (β) is the displacement aircraft centre-line from the relative airflow
By convention it is positive when the relative airflow is displaced to the right of the aircraft centre-line
learning.explanation: DIRECTIONAL STATIC STABILITY The directional static stability of an aircraft is its natural tendency to recover from a disturbance in yaw, is mainly provided by the fin and involves moments about the normal axis and their relationship with yaw or sideslip angle. The sideslip angle (β) is the displacement aircraft centre-line from the relative airflow. By convention it is positive when the relative airflow is displaced to the right of the aircraft centre-line. The sideslip gives the symmetrical fin an angle of attack equal to the sideslip angle. This produces a small aerodynamic force, which, when multiplied by the distance from the centre of gravity, produces a strong restoring moment, and yaws the aircraft back to its original equilibrium position. A swept wing provides a stable contribution depending on the amount of sweepback, which increases with increase in CL (i.e. at lower IAS). This contribution is relatively weak when compared with other components. The inclination of the forward, right, wing to the relative airflow is greater than that of the rearward wing, so there is more lift and, hence, more induced drag, on the right side. The result of this discrepancy in drag on the two sides of the wing is a yawing moment to the right, which tends to eliminate the sideslip. This is a stabilizing effect, and may be important if the sweepback angle is quite large.

learning.explanation: AERODYNAMIC DAMPING Damping is the suppression of an unwanted oscillation of a system. In an aircraft, it may be achieved manually, by an electrohydraulic system, or by aerodynamic means. This type of damping is dependent on the viscosity of the air for its success. The denser the atmosphere, the faster the unwanted movement will be extinguished When we make a control input, for instance a roll to the right, there is a resistance against this input due to "aerodynamic damping", which in this case, is where the down-going (right) wing gains an increased angle of attack as it is travelling down slightly, changing the relative airflow. This is an oscillation involving roll, yaw and sideslip

learning.explanation: DUTCH ROLL. This is an oscillation involving roll, yaw and sideslip. Because of these characteristics of the Dutch roll oscillation, lateral dynamic stability has always been more of a problem than longitudinal dynamic stability. With a dominant lateral stability this will, when a yaw is introduced, roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into the wind. The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations. This is called Dutch roll. Dutch roll might occur when the lateral stability is large compared to the directional stability. Therefore, the moments involved are roll and yaw. With increasing altitude (decreasing density) or increasing Mach number, the possibility of a Dutch roll increases. The CG position has little influence on the lateral stability, but an aft CG will reduce the directional stability because the Moment Arm of the stabilizing moment from the fin will decrease and thus increasing the likelihood of a Dutch roll. To reduce the aircraft tendency to Dutch roll, either the lateral stability should be decreased or the directional stability increased => anhedral would decrease the lateral stability. Aircraft with a tendency to Dutch roll are also fitted with yaw damper. This automatically displaces the rudder proportional to the rate of yaw to damp out the oscillation. Note: Dutch roll is a result of high Lateral stability with relatively low Directional stability. Furthermore, Longitudinal stability is not a factor.

key_points: An aircraft is in a state of equilibrium (trim) when the sum of all forces is zero and the sum of all moments is zero; there are no accelerations and the aircraft will continue in steady flight
If equilibrium is disturbed by a gust, or deflection of the controls, the aircraft will experience accelerations due to an unbalance of moments or forces
The type of static stability an aircraft possesses is defined by its initial tendency, following the removal of some disturbing force
learning.explanation: An aircraft is in a state of equilibrium (trim) when the sum of all forces is zero and the sum of all moments is zero; there are no accelerations and the aircraft will continue in steady flight. If equilibrium is disturbed by a gust, or deflection of the controls, the aircraft will experience accelerations due to an unbalance of moments or forces. The type of static stability an aircraft possesses is defined by its initial tendency, following the removal of some disturbing force. Positive static stability (or static stability) exists if an aircraft is disturbed from equilibrium and has the tendency to return to equilibrium. Neutral static stability exists if an aircraft is subject to a disturbance and has neither the tendency to return nor the tendency to continue in the displacement direction. Negative static stability (or static instability) exists if an aircraft tends to continue in the direction of disturbance.

learning.explanation: DIHEDRAL If not corrected, an unstable aeroplane will side slip down when rolled to one side. This effect is not desirable, so how can we reduce it? By tilting the wingtips upwards, the aeroplane becomes naturally more stable in the lateral plane. This is called dihedral. Lift acts perpendicular to the relative airflow. If the aeroplane rolls to the side when disturbed by a gust of wind, the lift vector leans to the side with the aeroplane. This creates a resultant sideways facing force that makes the aeroplane side slip in the same direction. As a result of this side slip, the aeroplane is subjected to a sideways component of the relative airflow. Due to dihedral, the lower wing (into the wind) meets the upcoming airflow at a greater angle of attack than the upper wing. Consequently, the lower wing produces more lift and helps the aeroplane roll back to its original position. This is how dihedral improves lateral stability.

key_points: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium
It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time

Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes
learning.explanation: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium. It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time. Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes. An airplane that is statically stable is not necessarily dynamically stable. However, for an airplane to be dynamically stable it must be statically stable. In other words, it cannot have long-term stability without first having short-term stability. An airplane that has positive static stability may be dynamically neutral, stable, or unstable; but an airplane that is statically unstable can never attain dynamic stability. The dynamic stability of an airplane is dependent on the airplane design, its speed, and the altitude at which it is flying. There are five states of dynamic stability and for each of them the airplane must have positive static stability. Negative dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation increases with the passage of time. Neutral dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation remains constant with the passage of time. Positive dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation decreases with the passage of time. ‘Dead beat’ positive dynamic stability – the oscillations cease immediately because they are heavily damped. ‘Divergent’ negative dynamic stability – the oscillations cease because the motion completely diverges from the original motion.

learning.explanation: Sideslip develops whenever an aircraft rolls away from wings level. content.question: Flying an aircraft with a joystick, if a small displacement of the joystick results in a large change in pitch/bank angle, the aeroplane is decribed as being...

key_points: An aircraft's stability affects many aspects of its flight characteristics
For an aircraft to be considered statically stable, it must initially begin to return to its original position/orientation after some sort of displacement
Think of placing a ball in a bowl, it will always begin to roll back to the bottom of the bowl, the equilibrium point
learning.explanation: An aircraft's stability affects many aspects of its flight characteristics. For an aircraft to be considered statically stable, it must initially begin to return to its original position/orientation after some sort of displacement. Think of placing a ball in a bowl, it will always begin to roll back to the bottom of the bowl, the equilibrium point. An aircraft can have stability in all three axes, pitch (longitudinal stability), yaw (directional stability) and roll (lateral stability). The opposite of stability is manoeuvrability, and if the aircraft is very stable, it is not very manoeuvrable, and vice-versa. The less stable (more manoeuvrable) we make an aircraft, the more easily it will change orientation. This is why aerobatic aircraft have very light controls, meaning that even small stick forces will cause a large aircraft movement, whereas stable aircraft, such as transport jets, are very stable, and will require much larger stick movements, and more stick force, to provide the same amount of aircraft movement. This is called stick force stability, which is a measure of how much input force is required to cause a 1G change. This question is asking about stick displacement, but it is largely the same thing. It is the reason that you would not want to cruise a highly aerobatic aircraft for long distances, as the fineness of control is difficult to achieve when the controls are so light and tiny movements cause huge changes. To answer the question, if small movements of the stick create large pitch/roll changes, the aircraft must be highly manoeuvrable. Interestingly, modern fighter aircraft, such as the Eurofighter Typhoon, are designed to be statically unstable for highest manoeuvrability, and have very responsive fly-by-wire controls making sure that the aircraft does not become unstable during flight. Excellent for air-to-air combat, terrible if they lose their FBW system.

key_points: Sideslip to the right means that the aircraft is pointing forwards but going rightwards, therefore the airflow is coming from the right hand side

Wing sweep will help increase lateral stability
learning.explanation: Sideslip to the right means that the aircraft is pointing forwards but going rightwards, therefore the airflow is coming from the right hand side. Another way to think of this is that on approach, the runway will be out of the right hand side window, even if there is no crosswind. Wing sweep will help increase lateral stability. When a swept-wing airplane is sideslipping, the wing toward the sideslip will experience a higher velocity normal to the wing's leading edge than the wing away from the sideslip. More lift is generated on the wing toward the sideslip and a roll moment arises that tends to diminish the bank angle or sideslip and return the airplane to equilibrium. In this case, the airflow over the right wing becomes straighter (less swept). Straighter wings are effectively longer, so produce more lift, resulting in a larger rolling moment to the left returning the aircraft to a non-sideslipped condition. This is an example of positive lateral stability.

The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations
learning.explanation: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor. When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state. The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations. One is a short-period oscillation and the other is a long-period oscillation called a phugoid. The phugoid is usually poorly damped; it has large variations of speed and height and has an almost uniform load factor (n). It has a constant energy motion in which the potential energy and the kinetic energy are continuously interchanging. The motion that causes short-period oscillation is normally heavily damped. It not only involves small changes of speed and height but also large changes of load factor. The speed and height of the airplane remain approximately constant.

Learning Objective 081.04.04.05.01: Describe how the following aeroplane components contribute to static directional stability: wing; fin; dorsal fin; ventral fin; angle of sweep of the wing; angle of sweep of the fin; fuselage at high alpha; strakes. The vertical stabiliser (tail fin) of an aircraft is the main contributor to static directional stability (stability in yaw), as any sideslip angle will create a lift on the fin by introducing an angle of attack to its symmetrical aerofoil, which then will create a force on the aircraft to point into the relative airflow. From here on out, we are using the words, "positive effect" (on stability) to mean that it makes the aircraft more stable. The larger we make the tail fin, the larger the positive effect (on stability). Also, the further back we make the tail fin from the centre of gravity, the larger the moment arm of the force, so the larger the positive effect. For this question, we must remember that the fin is just a wing, but when we fly coordinated (no sideslip), it is a symmetrical aerofoil, so creating no lift in either direction. Introducing a sideslip (an angle of attack - AoA) causes a lift force to be made. The greater this force, the greater the "positive effect" on stability, which pushes the tail around so the nose points towards the relative airflow. Sweepback of a wing does a few things, it increases the MCRIT of the aerofoil by making it "effectively thinner", which is very useful for high speed flight. It also changes the low speed flying characteristics a lot, decreasing the coefficient of lift for each angle of attack, but increasing the critical (stalling) angle of attack (but with a lower maximum lift output). This last bit is particularly useful for aircraft. Swept back tail fins will remain useful at higher angles of sideslip before stalling, in comparison to straight fins. Increased sweepback of the tail fin usually has a negative effect on directional stability (stability in yaw). At low/medium sideslip angles, the reduced lift coefficient for each angle of attack produces less of a restoring force (the lower gradient on the graph above). It is important to note that at higher angles of attack, within a certain range, a straight fin will have stalled (so provides almost no stability) and the swept fin would not yet have stalled due to its higher stalling AoA, and in that case, the swept fin provides far more stabilising effect than a straight fin, but only within a certain range of large sideslip angles.

learning.explanation: The most direct appreciation of the maneuvering stability of an airplane is obtained from a plot of stick force versus load factor. The airplane with positive maneuvering stability should demonstrate a steady increase in stick force with increase in load factor or “g”. The maneuvering stick force gradient - or stick force per “g” - must be positive but should be of the proper magnitude. The stick force gradient must not be excessively high, or the airplane will be difficult and tiring to maneuver. Also, the stick force gradient must not be too low, or the airplane may be overstressed inadvertently when light control forces exist. When the airplane has high static stability, the maneuvering stability will be high, and a high stick force gradient will result. A possibility exists that the forward CG limit could be set to prevent an excessively high maneuvering stick force gradient. As the CG moves aft, the stick force gradient decreases with decreasing maneuvering stability and the lower limit of stick force gradient may be reached. The aft limit, which for safety reasons on a transport airplane is always forward of the neutral point, is confined by insufficient stick-force stability and/or excessive in-flight maneuverability. The minimum stick force per ‘g’ for the maximum permitted load factor, which is 2.5 for large transport airplanes, determines the aft limit of the CG envelope. A CG position aft of this point would produce an unacceptably low value of maneuver stability and would make the airplane difficult to fly. For transport airplanes the aft limit is normally located at approximately 30% of the MAC.

content.question: How do ventral fins typically affect the longitudinal stability of an aircraft?

options.A: Ventral fins improve the longitudinal stability of the aircraft.
options.B: Ventral fins decrease the longitudinal stability of the aircraft.
options.C: Ventral fins increase the lateral stability of the aircraft.
options.D: Ventral fins have no impact on the aircraft's longitudinal stability.

key_points: The aircraft fin is a very powerful stabilising element of an aircraft, and contributes to positive stability both directionally (stability in yaw), and laterally (stability in roll)
Some aircraft have more complex aerodynamical needs though, leading to the use of dorsal and/or ventral fins as well as the main tail fin

Dorsal fins are effectively just an extension to the main fin, extending forwards to provide some benefits such as the blending with the fuselage, reducing drag, providing better stability at high sideslip angles, etc
learning.explanation: The aircraft fin is a very powerful stabilising element of an aircraft, and contributes to positive stability both directionally (stability in yaw), and laterally (stability in roll). Some aircraft have more complex aerodynamical needs though, leading to the use of dorsal and/or ventral fins as well as the main tail fin. Dorsal fins are effectively just an extension to the main fin, extending forwards to provide some benefits such as the blending with the fuselage, reducing drag, providing better stability at high sideslip angles, etc. They therefore have a positive effect on directional and lateral stability. Ventral fins (sometimes called strakes), however, are placed under the fuselage, and provide a further increase in directional stability (yaw), but have the opposite effect to the main and dorsal fins when it comes to lateral stability, they are de-stabilising. Ventral fins are very useful for improving the stall/spin characteristcs of aircraft where the fuselage and wings may render the main fin less effective at high angles of attack (similar to a deep stall, but for stability). Their main limitation is ground clearance. None of these items have any effect on longitudinal stability, which is stability in pitch, as a pitch change will not cause any angle of attack change to these components. Some ventral fins/strakes are actually angled outwards, so they are not perfectly vertical. Now this would give very slightly increased longitudinal stability due to their location at the rear of the aircraft, however, the majority of ventral fins (as is the primary intention of them) have no effect on longitudinal stability.

content.question:
A large jet aircraft is designed to be operated with a positive longitudinal stability and is equipped with a Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system. Prior to each flight, the pilots input the aircraft mass and CG location into the Flight Management System (FMS). The aircraft's FMS then informs the FBW system of this data, allowing for the correct control forces and limitations to be used, giving flight envelope protection and ensuring stability is maintained.
Consider what will happen to the aircraft's high altitude handling characteristics if the pilot inputs the INCORRECT CG position into the FMS, located forward of the actual CG position. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: Due to the design criteria applied, the longitudinal stability of the aircraft is always ensured, irrespective of the location of the CG.
options.B: The actual longitudinal stability is lower than calculated by the FBW system, and the system may allow for control surface deflections that result in instability.
options.C: The aircraft consumes more fuel than expected during the cruise phase of the flight, as the FBW system deflects the horizontal stabiliser more to counteract the error of the pilot.
options.D: The pitch rates commanded by the FBW system are lower at higher altitudes compared to the pitch rates required to ensure that the longitudinal stability remains positive.

key_points: An aircraft's stability, and in particular its longitudinal stability (stability in pitch) is massively dependent on the location of the aircraft's Centre of Gravity (CG)
As long as the CG is in front of the "neutral point", the aircraft will be longitudinally stable
The "neutral point" is a sort of average Centre of Pressure (CP) for the whole aircraft, and it goes towards where there are more aerodynamic surfaces
learning.explanation: An aircraft's stability, and in particular its longitudinal stability (stability in pitch) is massively dependent on the location of the aircraft's Centre of Gravity (CG). As long as the CG is in front of the "neutral point", the aircraft will be longitudinally stable. The "neutral point" is a sort of average Centre of Pressure (CP) for the whole aircraft, and it goes towards where there are more aerodynamic surfaces. Think of a throwing dart, the front had a weight and the back has a set of fins, therefore a very far forward CG and a far back "neutral point". This is a very stable system. A far forward CG therefore is a more stable condition. This also means a less manoeuvrable condition. Less manoeuvrability means that the pilot will have to push and pull harder on the controls to achieve the same result, as the control surfaces need to move further to achieve the same angular change. The controls feel "heavier" with a further forward CG, but the aircraft is more stable. This can be counteracted by the Fly-By-Wire system, which uses the knowledge of the aircraft's weight and CG position to estimate the required control surface deflection, and make the controls feel the same as for any other CG position, so the pilot has the same control of the aircraft, no matter the weight or CG position. If the CG is further forwards, the FBW system will amplify the pilot's inputs more than normal in the pitch axis, to make the aircraft control as it would do "normally". This means that, in this scenario, the pilot has entered an artificially far forward CG, so the FBW system will amplify the pilot's actions in pitch, but without any need to do so, as the CG is not actually that far forward. This could lead to overcontrolling of the aircraft by the fly-by-wire system, as the aircraft is not as stable as the FMS/FBW believes. The overcontrolling could potentially reduce the stability of the aircraft, or even cause instability. As this question is easy to misread or misunderstand, we will quickly go through each option: "Due to the design criteria applied, the longitudinal stability of the aircraft is always ensured, irrespective of the location of the CG." Whilst this looks plausible, the longitudinal stability is not ensured (and will be reduced or removed) when the CG goes out of the aft limit. "The actual longitudinal stability is lower than calculated by the FBW system, and the system may allow for control surface deflections that result in instability." As mentioned above, this is correct, due to the incorrectly entered CG position, which may allow the FBW to overcontrol the aircraft. The aircraft is less stable than the FBW system believes. "The aircraft consumes more fuel than expected during the cruise phase of the flight, as the FBW system deflects the horizontal stabiliser more to counteract the error of the pilot." The aircraft will actually consume less fuel than expected, but because the aircraft expects a forward CG in the cruise, which causes the tailplane to produce more downforce, and requires more lift from the wing, causing higher drag. However, the aircraft actually has a further aft CG, so will burn less fuel than expected. This is also not connected to the FBW system creating larger deflections, that is an effect which would occur in this case, but has negligible effect on fuel consumption. "The pitch rates commanded by the FBW system are lower at higher altitudes compared to the pitch rates required to ensure that the longitudinal stability remains positive." This has nothing to do with the scenario mentioned in the question (incorrectly inputted CG location).

key_points: While static stability is concerned with the initial tendency of an aircraft to return to equilibrium, dynamic stability is defined by the resulting motion with time
If an aircraft is disturbed from equilibrium, the time history of the resulting motion indicates its dynamic stability
Aircraft with neutral dynamic stability have oscillations that never dampen out
learning.explanation: While static stability is concerned with the initial tendency of an aircraft to return to equilibrium, dynamic stability is defined by the resulting motion with time. If an aircraft is disturbed from equilibrium, the time history of the resulting motion indicates its dynamic stability. Aircraft with neutral dynamic stability have oscillations that never dampen out. If a trimmed and neutrally dynamic stable aircraft is pitched up, it pitches nose low, then nose high again, and this oscillation continues, in theory, forever.

content.question: A manufacturer shortens the fuselage of a 9 seat plane to a 6 seat plane. They make the vertical fin and horizontal stabiliser bigger. How is directional stability influenced?

options.A: There is no impact on stability.
options.B: Negative, since the bigger stabiliser produces more drag.
options.C: Positive, since the higher vertical fin.
options.D: The rudder effectiveness is highly reduced.

key_points: When a manufacturer shortens the fuselage of an aircraft from 9 seats to 6 seats, the aircraft's overall dimensions and weight change
In this case, the manufacturer has increased the size of the vertical fin and horizontal stabilizer to account for the reduced fuselage length
The larger vertical fin provides greater surface area for controlling yaw, while the larger horizontal stabilizer increases pitch stability
learning.explanation: When a manufacturer shortens the fuselage of an aircraft from 9 seats to 6 seats, the aircraft's overall dimensions and weight change. In this case, the manufacturer has increased the size of the vertical fin and horizontal stabilizer to account for the reduced fuselage length. The larger vertical fin provides greater surface area for controlling yaw, while the larger horizontal stabilizer increases pitch stability. The larger vertical fin increases the surface area available to resist the yawing moment caused by asymmetrical thrust, crosswinds, or other factors that could cause the aircraft to turn left or right. This results in improved directional stability of the aircraft, which means that it is less likely to deviate from its intended course. Therefore, option "Positive, since the higher vertical fin." is the correct answer. The increased size of the vertical fin and horizontal stabilizer should not reduce the effectiveness of the rudder, as the rudder is the primary control surface for yaw control. In fact, the larger surface area of the vertical fin may even enhance the rudder's effectiveness, as it provides more area for the rudder to deflect and generate a yawing moment.

content.question: An aircraft has been placed in a spiral dive. The pilot has then let go of all the controls to see how the aircraft will naturally react. Its speed, rate of turn and rate of descent all begin decreasing. What type of spiral dive mode does the aircraft possess?

options.A: Negative.
options.B: Neutral.
options.C: Unstable.
options.D: Stable.

key_points: The feedback for this question was weak and there is another recently added question which asks a similar question in the opposite manner (Q814718 - originally seen in Austro Control), so any feedback you have about either of these questions from the real exam would be very useful to make sure this question is representative of the real exam, thank you very much
This is quite a tricky question as the examiner is almost trying to get you confused about which stability they are discussing
The spiral dive occurs as a link between strong directional (yaw) stability but weak lateral (roll) stability
learning.explanation: The feedback for this question was weak and there is another recently added question which asks a similar question in the opposite manner (Q814718 - originally seen in Austro Control), so any feedback you have about either of these questions from the real exam would be very useful to make sure this question is representative of the real exam, thank you very much. This is quite a tricky question as the examiner is almost trying to get you confused about which stability they are discussing. The spiral dive occurs as a link between strong directional (yaw) stability but weak lateral (roll) stability. Imagine an aircraft is disturbed to roll slightly right, and therefore takes up a slight right sideslip. The large fin yaws into the turn before the aircraft can roll out of it, and this yaw causes a further bank, which again causes more yaw before the aircraft can roll out of it. During this process, the nose keeps dropping to increase airspeed to maintain lift in the turn without any increase in angle of attack. In IMC without good use of instruments, this feels like straight and level flight until the G forces start to increase noticeably, at which point the pilot would finally notice that something was wrong, as they are in a high speed spiral dive. But now back to the theory. Many aircraft have a slight spiral instability, which, even though the aircraft might be statically stable in all axes, means that a small departure from straight and level will gradually become a spiral dive if no pilot inputs are made. As this is a gradual process, it is acceptable up to a certain rate of instability as the pilot can easily override it. Being stable in the spiral mode means that the aircraft naturally tends to reduce any spiral dives to zero. If an aircraft is stable in the spiral mode, then it is likely to have a strong tendency for dutch roll. For this question, then, if the aircraft's rate of turn, rate of descent and speed are all decreasing, then it is naturally rolling out of the turn, and is therefore stable in the spiral (dive) mode.

content.question: Why is it bad to have too much lateral stability?

options.A: More prone to deep stall
options.B: More prone to Dutch roll
options.C: More prone to Spiral dive
options.D: More prone to spin

key_points: With a dominant lateral stability this will, when a yaw is introduced, roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into the wind
The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations
This is called Dutch roll
learning.explanation: With a dominant lateral stability this will, when a yaw is introduced, roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into the wind. The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations. This is called Dutch roll. Dutch roll might occur when the lateral stability is large compared to the directional stability. Therefore, the moments involved are roll and yaw. The CG position has little influence on the lateral stability, but an aft CG will reduce the directional stability because the Moment Arm of the stabilizing moment from the fin will decrease and thus increasing the possibility of Dutch roll. To reduce the aircraft tendency to Dutch roll, either the lateral stability should be decreased or the directional stability increased => anhedral would decrease the lateral stability.

key_points: Note: We only know the correct option here, and the incorrect options were reported as being easy to identify as incorrect, so we have made up some suitably wrong options until we get further feedback about this question
Please send us any further feedback in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions
com, thank you! The yaw damper's main purpose is to prevent Dutch roll
learning.explanation: Note: We only know the correct option here, and the incorrect options were reported as being easy to identify as incorrect, so we have made up some suitably wrong options until we get further feedback about this question. Please send us any further feedback in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! The yaw damper's main purpose is to prevent Dutch roll. Basically speaking, Dutch roll is a series of out-of-phase turns, when the aircraft rolls in one direction and yaws in the other due to a high amount of lateral stability but not quite enough directional stability. When the yaw is introduced, the strong “dihedral effect” will roll the aircraft due to the lift increase on the wing into wind. The increased induced drag on the rising wing will yaw the aircraft in the opposite direction, reversing the coupled oscillations. Since the possibility of a Dutch roll increases with increasing altitude due to the lower aerodynamic damping at high altitude, aircraft can sometimes be restricted to fly at lower altitudes only when the yaw damper is unserviceable.

key_points: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP)
This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating
As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure
learning.explanation: The point where an aircraft’s total sum of a pressure field is acting upon the body is called the Center of Pressure (CP). This is the point where the resultant vector of lift is said to be operating. As the airfoil or Angle of attack changes (thus changing the lift coefficient), this pressure field will change and so will the center of pressure. Aircraft longitudinal stability is directly related to Centre of Gravity (CG) position. An aircraft with a more forward CG is more longitudinally stable than an aircraft with a more aft CG. Placing the CG beyond the forward limit can cause an unacceptably high value of longitudinal stability, decreasing manoeuvrability by a significant amount. Place the CG beyond the aft limit and the aircraft is too unstable, having excessive manoeuvrability. If an aircraft is longitudinally stable, an increase in Angle of Attack (α) results in a negative pitching moment. The nose will slightly fall down, decreasing the Angle of Attack. If this aircraft has a decrease of Angle of Attack, the nose will come slightly upwards again, creating a positive pitching moment again by slightly raising the nose. The point where the aircraft does not have any positive or negative static longitudinal stability, and therefore is static longitudinally neutral, is called the neutral point. Placing the CG aft of this point makes the aircraft unstable, placing the CG forward of this point makes the aircraft stable.

content.question: Choose the correct statement:

options.C: The short period oscillation should always be heavily damped.
options.D: The phugoid should always be heavily damped.

key_points: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor
When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state
The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations
learning.explanation: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor. When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state. The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations. One is a short-period oscillation and the other is a long-period oscillation called a phugoid. The phugoid is usually poorly damped; it has large variations of speed and height and has an almost uniform load factor (n). It has a constant energy motion in which the potential energy and the kinetic energy are continuously interchanging. The motion that causes short-period oscillation is usually heavily damped. It not only involves small changes of speed and height but also large changes of load factor. The speed and height of the airplane remain approximately constant.

learning.explanation: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane. Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left. Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip. A disturbance in the rolling plane causes the angle of attack of the upgoing wing to decrease and the angle of attack of the down going wing to increase. Provided the airplane is not flying close to the stalling speed, then the upgoing wing produces less lift than it did before the disturbance and the down going wing will produce more lift than it did. Together, these changes result in a rolling moment in opposition to the initial disturbance and have a ‘roll-damping’ effect. When the roll damping exactly matches the aileron torque the airplane has a steady rate of roll. The airplane design features that increase the lateral static stability are: dihedral. sweepback. high-wing mounting. increased effective dihedral. large, high vertical fin. low CG. The airplane design features that decrease the lateral static stability are: anhedral. forward-swept wings. ventral fin. low-wing mounting. extending inboard flaps.

The change in lift (side force) on the fin creates a yawing moment about the centre of gravity which tends to yaw the aeroplane into the relative airflow. The magnitude of the fin contribution to static directional stability depends on both the change in fin lift and the fin moment arm. The lift curve slope of the fin determines how sensitive the surface is to change in angle of attack. While it is desirable to have a high lift curve slope for the fin, a high aspect ratio surface is not necessarily practical or desirable due to: - Bending - Lower stalling angle - Hangar roof clearance The stall angle of the surface must be large enough to prevent stall and subsequent loss of effectiveness at expected sideslip angles. learning.explanation: A variation of CG position can cause large changes in the static longitudinal stability. In the conventional airplane configuration, the large changes in stability with CG variation are primarily due to the large changes in the wing contribution. As the CG is gradually moved aft, the airplane static stability decreases, then becomes neutral then unstable. The CG position which produces zero slope and neutral static stability is referred to as the “neutral point”. The neutral point may be imagined as the effective aerodynamic center of the entire airplane configuration, i.e. with the CG at the neutral point, all changes in net lift effectively occur at that point and no change in pitching moment results. The neutral point defines the most aft CG position without static instability. As seen in figure 1, neutral static stability would be the result if the curve had zero slope. If neutral stability existed, the airplane could be disturbed to some higher or lower lift coefficient without change in pitching moment coefficient. For an airplane to always have positive longitudinal static stability the CG must be ahead of the neutral point, so that the wing-pitching moment always exceeds the tail plane pitching moment. The further aft the neutral point is from the CG the greater is the static longitudinal stability.

The drag of a swept wing is less than that of an unswept wing. The advantage of this type of wing at high speeds is gained at the expense of its poor performance at low speed. The drag experienced with a swept wing is the component of the relative airflow at 90◦ to the line joining the aerodynamic center of the wing, which if the wing has parallel leading and trailing edges will be the normal to the leading edge of the wing. learning.explanation: An airplane may display spiral instability in case it has strong directional stability relative to its lateral stability. It looks similar to a spin, however, the wings are not stalled here. When a wind gust makes an airplane with spiral instability to side-slip, powerful directional stability tends to yaw the airplane back into alignment with the relative wind. In this case the outside wing will generate more lift as it travels faster. This tends to roll the airplane in the direction of the yaw. The rolling force overcomes the weak dihedral effect, allowing further roll. As the vertical component of lift decreases, the relative wind has an upward component with the airplane swinging in alignment with the air stream, the nose begins to drop. This results in a gradually increasing spiral dive. Note: Dutch Roll = may occur when static lateral stability is too high compared to the static directional stability.

key_points: SPIRAL INSTABILITY Spiral instability occurs when the directional stability of an aeroplane is strong and the lateral stability is weak
When a wing drops, due to a disturbance, the tendency of the aeroplane to correct this departure from the balanced condition in level flight is dependent on the lateral stability of the aeroplane
Additionally, when a wing drops, it causes other secondary motions to be initiated
learning.explanation: SPIRAL INSTABILITY Spiral instability occurs when the directional stability of an aeroplane is strong and the lateral stability is weak. When a wing drops, due to a disturbance, the tendency of the aeroplane to correct this departure from the balanced condition in level flight is dependent on the lateral stability of the aeroplane. Additionally, when a wing drops, it causes other secondary motions to be initiated. The fin and rudder tend to yaw the aeroplane into the airflow in the direction of the dropped wing. Because of the yaw, the higher wing on the outside of the turn is travelling faster than the lower wing and develops a greater amount of lift. This generates a rolling moment in the opposite direction to the correcting moment of the dihedral and if the rolling moment is greater it will tend to increase the angle of bank. If the rolling moment is of sufficient magnitude to overcome the correcting force, produced by the dihedral and the damping yaw effect, the bank angle will increase and the aeroplane will enter a steadily steepening spiral dive. This is spiral instability that can be described as a combined lateral and directional aperiodic motion.

learning.explanation: To overcome the instability in the fuselage it is possible to incorporate into the overall design dorsal or ventral fins. A dorsal fin is a small aero foil, of very low aspect ratio, mounted on top of the fuselage near the rear. A ventral fin is mounted below. If the aircraft is yawed to the right, the dorsal and ventral fins will create a side force to the right. The line of action of this force is well aft of the aircraft CG, giving a yawing moment to the left (a stabilizing effect). However, at small angles of yaw they are ineffective. Dorsal and ventral fins become more effective at relatively high sideslip angles. Due to their low aspect ratio, they do not tend to stall at any sideslip angle which an aircraft is likely to experience in service. While dorsal and ventral fins contribute positively to directional static stability, a dorsal fin contributes positively to lateral static stability, while a ventral fin is destabilizing in this mode and has no effect on longitudinal stability. It creates lift below CG in the direction of the roll.

Static Longitudinal stability is the aircraft's natural tendency when disturbed in pitch, to return to its former trimmed angle of attack without pilot input, and is desirable throughout the aircraft's complete speed range. For the study of stability, we consider the changes in magnitude of lift force due to changes in angle of attack, acting through a stationary point, the aerodynamic centre (AC). There are two moments to consider: the wing moment and the tail moment. The wing moment is a function of the change in wing lift multiplied by arm ‘x’. The tail moment is a function of the change in tailplane lift multiplied by arm ‘y’. The length of both arms is dependent upon CG position. If the CG is considered in a more forward position, the tail arm is larger and the wing arm is smaller. A more forward CG position increases static longitudinal stability. If the nose-down (negative) tail moment is greater than the nose-up (positive) wing moment, the aircraft will have static longitudinal stability.

learning.explanation: POWER EFFECTS Its effects may cause significant changes in trim left coefficient and static longitudinal stability. The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability. If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment (positive moment) => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust). Creating an unstable situation. Therefore, the effect is destabilizing. If the thrust line is above the CG, this is the opposite of the above and a thrust increase will produce a nose down moment (negative moment), and, in moderate amounts, can have a stabilising effect. The airplane will settle at a higher speed, which is presumably what the pilot wants (despite the "power controls altitude" mantra). When the line is too high, the airplane may even descend and accelerate more than necessary, until the aerodynamic moment balances out the thrust moment, but overall the condition is stable. Thrust is in line with CG. The airplane will start to climb (or reduce descent) and will settle on the same AoA and roughly the same speed.

If such is the case the aircraft CG will be further aft than is normal and the aircraft longitudinal static stability is decreased. This destabilizing influence is increased by the induced upwash of the airflow ahead of the wing. learning.explanation: If the Center of Gravity (CG) is located in front of the Center of Pressure (CP), it means that the lift acts behind the CG. This causes a nose down movement. To have the nose not move downwards, an downwards moment has to be created by the tailplane, so the tail comes down again and the nose goes up to a 0 angle.

The rolling force overcomes the weak dihedral effect, allowing further roll. As the vertical component of lift decreases, the relative wind has an upward component with the airplane swinging in alignment with the air stream, the nose begins to drop. This results in a gradually increasing spiral dive.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Assuming no pilot input the motion of the aeroplane in the diagram shows:

options.A: static longitudinal stability and dynamic longitudinal instability.
options.B: static and dynamic longitudinal stability.
options.C: neutral dynamic longitudinal stability.
options.D: static longitudinal instability.

key_points: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium
It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time

Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes
learning.explanation: Dynamic Stability is the subsequent long-term response of an airplane to a disturbance to its equilibrium. It is the change to the stability of an airplane with the passage of time. Any disturbance causes changes to the aerodynamic forces and moments acting on the airplane that are complex, particularly if the displacement is to its directional stability because it affects the airplane in both the yawing and rolling planes. An airplane that is statically stable is not necessarily dynamically stable. However, for an airplane to be dynamically stable it must be statically stable. In other words, it cannot have long-term stability without first having short-term stability. An airplane that has positive static stability may be dynamically neutral, stable, or unstable; but an airplane that is statically unstable can never attain dynamic stability. The dynamic stability of an airplane is dependent on the airplane design, its speed, and the altitude at which it is flying. There are five states of dynamic stability and for each of them the airplane must have positive static stability. Negative dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation increases with the passage of time. Neutral dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation remains constant with the passage of time. Positive dynamic stability – the amplitude of the oscillation decreases with the passage of time. ‘Dead beat’ positive dynamic stability – the oscillations cease immediately because they are heavily damped. ‘Divergent’ negative dynamic stability – the oscillations cease because the motion completely diverges from the original motion.
