key_points: The rotation of an aircraft about its normal, or vertical, axis is a yaw

If this movement is the result of an undesirable disturbance, then the ability of the airplane to return to its original heading without the assistance of any control-surface movement is a measure of its directional static stability
It is a measure of the aircraft’s ability to realign itself with the relative airflow
learning.explanation: The rotation of an aircraft about its normal, or vertical, axis is a yaw. If this movement is the result of an undesirable disturbance, then the ability of the airplane to return to its original heading without the assistance of any control-surface movement is a measure of its directional static stability. It is a measure of the aircraft’s ability to realign itself with the relative airflow. Sideslip angle (β) is the displacement angle of the airplane’s longitudinal axis in azimuth from the relative airflow. It is positive when the relative airflow is to the right of the longitudinal axis and negative when the relative airflow is left of the longitudinal axis. An airplane has directional static stability if, when in a sideslip with the airflow coming from the right (+β) initially the nose tends to yaw right (+CN). An airplane that has excessive directional static stability compared to its lateral static stability is more prone to spiral dive.

content.question: An aeroplane, with a CG location behind the centre of pressure of the wing can only maintain a straight and level flight when the horizontal tail loading is:

options.A: zero.
options.B: upwards or downwards depending on elevator deflection.
options.C: downwards.

key_points: If the Center of Gravity (CG) is located behind the Center of Pressure (CP), it means that the lift acts in front of the CG
This causes a nose up movement
To keep an aircraft level, the two moments from the wing and tailplane will have to cancel each other out
learning.explanation: If the Center of Gravity (CG) is located behind the Center of Pressure (CP), it means that the lift acts in front of the CG. This causes a nose up movement. To keep an aircraft level, the two moments from the wing and tailplane will have to cancel each other out. The CP always points upwards. This means that if the CP is in front of the CG, the nose wants to move upwards. To cancel this movement, the tailplane generates an upwards moment to keep the nose straight. In this case, the CP is located ahead of the CG. To have the nose not move upwards, an upwards moment has to be created by the tailplane, so the tail comes up again and the nose goes down to a 0 angle.

content.question: CS-23 and CS-25 require that an aeroplane must be statically stable and specify the acceptable range of stability and manoeuvrability. An aircraft's stability is affected by the CG location and the gross weight of the aircraft, amongst other factors. For a given aeroplane, the manoeuvrability...

options.A: cannot be affected by the pilot or operator as it is determined by the aircraft design.
options.B: is determined by the size of the control surfaces only, not the CG position or the weight.
options.C: is significantly higher when the centre of gravity is at the forward limit, and/or when the aeroplane is heavy.
options.D: tends to be reduced when the aeroplane is heavy or has a forward centre of gravity location.

key_points: This question is unnecessarily long and wordy, but does give some hints which help to remove incorrect options quickly
Static stability pertains to how a system reacts immediately when disturbed
In a statically stable system, it initially moves back toward its equilibrium state
learning.explanation: This question is unnecessarily long and wordy, but does give some hints which help to remove incorrect options quickly. Static stability pertains to how a system reacts immediately when disturbed. In a statically stable system, it initially moves back toward its equilibrium state. An aircraft's type of static stability is defined by its initial reaction after some external force is removed. We use the term "static" because we're only concerned with the initial tendency to return to equilibrium, without considering subsequent motion. Manoeuvrability, on the other hand, is the aircraft's ability to change its position or attitude in response to pilot inputs, allowing it to perform various manoeuvres. Stability and manoeuvrability are effectively opposite, and the greater an aircraft's stability, the lower the manoeuvrability, and vice-versa. An aircraft with a further forward CG has greater stability (but lower manoeuvrability) and aircraft with aft CG locations have lower stability, but higher manoeuvrability. Higher weight also tends to reduce manoeuvrability, but this rule isn't always as simple as the CG locations. The question tells us that stability is affected by the CG location and the gross weight of the aircraft, and, knowing that manoeuvrability and stability are closely (and inversely) linked, that hints to us that those factors also affect the manoeuvrability, which they do. That removes the following options: "cannot be affected by the pilot or operator as it is determined by the aircraft design.", as the CG location and weight can be affected by the operator/pilot, so therefore, the manoeuvrability can be too; and "is determined by the size of the control surfaces only, not the CG position or the weight.", as the manoeuvrability is changed by the CG location and weight. The other options can be chosen between based on the CG location and weight, and the effects of those mentioned above.

content.question: An aeroplane is equipped with 2 basic yaw dampers that operate independently of the flight controls. Due to a hydraulic leak, one of the yaw dampers becomes unserviceable. The aeroplane is allowed to fly as long as one yaw damper is operational, however the pilots must not commence flight if both yaw dampers are unserviceable. Why must the aeroplane have at least one serviceable yaw damper?

options.A: The yaw damper reduces the pilots workload by coordinating turns and improving the static lateral stability of the aeroplane.
options.B: The yaw damper enables the aeroplane to perform an Autoland since it uses rudder in order to maintain direction during landing.
options.C: The aeroplane becomes uncontrollable if there is NO yaw damper to improve slightly weak static directional stability.
options.D: The aeroplane suffers from Dutch roll but remains controllable if the remaining yaw damper fails during flight.

key_points: Aeroplanes with a tendency to Dutch roll are fitted with a Yaw Damper
This automatically displaces the rudder proportional to the rate of yaw to damp-out the oscillations
If the Yaw Damper fails in flight, there may be speed and altitude restrictions
learning.explanation: Aeroplanes with a tendency to Dutch roll are fitted with a Yaw Damper. This automatically displaces the rudder proportional to the rate of yaw to damp-out the oscillations. If the Yaw Damper fails in flight, there may be speed and altitude restrictions. Note that an aircraft would only be allowed to take off with only one yaw damper serviceable if the aircraft remains controllable.

content.question: What is a phugoid oscillation?

options.A: It is an oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state with large variations of speed and height.
options.B: It is an oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state with small changes of speed and height.
options.C: It is an oscillatory motion of the airplane in roll after a disturbance to its trimmed state with no variations of speed.
options.D: It is an oscillatory motion of the airplane in yaw after a disturbance to its trimmed state with no variations of speed.

key_points: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor
When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state
The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations
learning.explanation: In trimmed level flight a disturbance in pitch usually oscillates about its original state causing fluctuations in the values of speed, height and indicated load factor. When an airplane has positive longitudinal dynamic stability the amplitude of the oscillations gradually diminish as the aircraft returns to its original trimmed flight state. The oscillatory motion of the airplane in pitch after a disturbance to its trimmed state can be shown as two separate oscillations. One is a short-period oscillation and the other is a long-period oscillation called a phugoid. The phugoid is usually poorly damped; it has large variations of speed and height and has an almost uniform load factor (n). It has a constant energy motion in which the potential energy and the kinetic energy are continuously interchanging. The motion that causes short-period oscillation is normally heavily damped. It not only involves small changes of speed and height but also large changes of load factor. The speed and height of the airplane remain approximately constant.

content.question: Considering an aeroplane’s manoeuvrability in pitch, the further forward the centre of gravity...

options.A: the less the manoeuvrability due to the increased static longitudinal stability.

options.C: the greater the manoeuvrability due to the increased elevator forces that can be achieved.
options.D: the greater the manoeuvrability due to a longer elevator to CG arm, which increases the pitching moment.

key_points: An aircraft is said to be trimmed (in trim) if all moments in pitch, roll, and yaw are equal to zero
The term controllability refers to the ability of the aircraft to respond to control surface displacement and achieve the desired condition of flight
Adequate controllability must be available to perform take-off and landing and accomplish the various maneuvers in flight
learning.explanation: An aircraft is said to be trimmed (in trim) if all moments in pitch, roll, and yaw are equal to zero. The term controllability refers to the ability of the aircraft to respond to control surface displacement and achieve the desired condition of flight. Adequate controllability must be available to perform take-off and landing and accomplish the various maneuvers in flight. A contradiction exists between stability and controllability. A high degree of stability gives reduced controllability. The relationship between static stability and controllability is demonstrated by figure 1 and 2. The effect of increased static stability (forward CG movement) on controllability is illustrated by the ball in a steeper trough (figure 2). A greater force is required to “control” the ball to the same position of displacement when the static stability is increased. In this manner, a large degree of static stability tends to make the aircraft less controllable. It is necessary to achieve the proper proportion between static stability and controllability during the design of an aircraft because too much static stability (forward CG position) reduces controllability. The forward CG limit is set to ensure minimum controllability.

options.B: A disadvantage of sweepback is that it decreases MCRIT.

options.D: Sweepback increases speed stability at Mach numbers above MCRIT.

key_points: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane
Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left
Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip
learning.explanation: The lateral static stability is a measure of the airplane’s tendency to return to the wings-level attitude after a disturbance has caused the airplane to be disturbed in the rolling plane. Positive lateral static stability is the tendency of the airplane to roll to the left with a positive sideslip angle, nose to the left. Its ability to recover is dependent on the effect of sideslip. A disturbance in the rolling plane causes the angle of attack of the upgoing wing to decrease and the angle of attack of the down going wing to increase. Provided the airplane is not flying close to the stalling speed, then the upgoing wing produces less lift than it did before the disturbance and the down going wing will produce more lift than it did. Together, these changes result in a rolling moment in opposition to the initial disturbance and have a ‘roll-damping’ effect. When the roll damping exactly matches the aileron torque the airplane has a steady rate of roll. The airplane design features that increase the lateral static stability are: dihedral. sweepback. high-wing mounting. increased effective dihedral. large, high vertical fin. low CG. The airplane design features that decrease the lateral static stability are: anhedral. forward-swept wings. ventral fin. low-wing mounting. extending inboard flaps.

content.question: When an aircraft enters a spiral dive with the CG at the AFT limit, when the spiral dive is fully developed, which of the following pitch attitudes is most likely?

options.A: Nose Up
options.B: Nose Down
options.C: Nose Level
options.D: Impossible to determine

key_points: Note: This is a completely different scenario to the similar questions that exist about spins
A spiral dive occurs when an aircraft is very directionally stable (stable in yaw) and not very laterally stable (stable in roll)

When a significant sideslip is induced, a stable aircraft will want to yaw very towards the oncoming airflow direction, and in a balanced aircraft, would also roll away from the oncoming airflow direction
learning.explanation: Note: This is a completely different scenario to the similar questions that exist about spins. A spiral dive occurs when an aircraft is very directionally stable (stable in yaw) and not very laterally stable (stable in roll). When a significant sideslip is induced, a stable aircraft will want to yaw very towards the oncoming airflow direction, and in a balanced aircraft, would also roll away from the oncoming airflow direction. However, the aircraft's roll would not be as strong in this scenario, and the strong yawing effect may even overpower it, which would cause the aircraft to yaw and roll towards the oncoming airflow. This intense yawing effect basically overpowers the other aspects of stability and makes the aircraft bank in the same direction, which forms a spiral dive. Spiral dives can make the aircraft speed up very quickly and can cause overspeed or overstress if not dealt with quickly, as they get worse with time. Spiral dives are referred to as "aperiodic" motion as they do not go back and forth (like dutch roll), they only happen once, getting further from equilibrium. The key part of this question is that spiral dives are always pointing downwards, as they are a dive. If the nose was upwards, they would be a stall/spin. Note that you can easily create an accelerated stall leading to a spin from a spiral dive, if handled incorrectly.

It is a measure of the aircraft’s ability to realign itself with the relative airflow
learning.explanation: The rotation of an aircraft about its normal, or vertical, axis is a yaw. If this movement is the result of an undesirable disturbance, then the ability of the airplane to return to its original heading without the assistance of any control-surface movement is a measure of its directional static stability. It is a measure of the aircraft’s ability to realign itself with the relative airflow. Sideslip is the displacement angle of the airplane’s longitudinal axis (plane of symmetry) in azimuth from the relative airflow (speed vector). It is positive when the relative airflow is to the right of the longitudinal axis and negative when the relative airflow is left of the longitudinal axis. An airplane has directional static stability if, when in a sideslip with the airflow coming from the left initially the nose tends to yaw left. An airplane that has excessive directional static stability compared to its lateral static stability is more prone to spiral dive.

content.question: An aircraft is on final approach, fully configured and cleared to land when suddenly a vehicle enters the runway. The pilot decides to go-around, but realises that the stabiliser trim is jammed. What should the pilot do?

key_points: An aeroplane is trimmed when it will maintain its attitude and speed without the pilot having to apply any load to the cockpit controls
If it is necessary for a control surface to be deflected to maintain balance of the aircraft, the pilot will need to apply a force to the cockpit control to hold the surface in its deflected position
This force may be reduced to zero by operation of the trim controls
learning.explanation: An aeroplane is trimmed when it will maintain its attitude and speed without the pilot having to apply any load to the cockpit controls. If it is necessary for a control surface to be deflected to maintain balance of the aircraft, the pilot will need to apply a force to the cockpit control to hold the surface in its deflected position. This force may be reduced to zero by operation of the trim controls. The aircraft may need to be trimmed in pitch as a result of: - changes of speed. - changes of power. - varying CG positions. - changes of configuration. A Trimmable Horizontal Stabiliser (THS) enables a larger CG and speed range than a conventional tailplane with stabiliser, elevator and trim tab, because the whole stabiliser may be moved for trimming the aeroplane, instead of a relatively “small” elevator and trim tab only (a larger surface is much more effective). This also leads to more control difficulty due to a jammed stabiliser. An aircraft on final apporach is configured and trimmed for low speed, i.e. nose up trim. This means that, in case of go-around, the pilot should be prepared to apply nose down or trim nose down to prevent excessive pitch up caused by the additional power.

content.question: In preparation for departure, the pilot sets the aircraft's CG position at 12% of the MAC not knowing that the actual aircraft CG is at 21% of MAC What is the possible outcome for this aircraft setting?

options.A: Higher stick force than expected.
options.B: Poor climb performance.
options.C: Longer take-off run.
options.D: Tail-strike may occur.

key_points: The chord line that passes through the geometric centre of the plan area of an aerofoil is the Mean Aerodynamic Chord (MAC) and for any planform is equal to the chord of a rectangular wing having the same wing span and the same pitching moment and lift
The MAC is often used to reference the location of the centre of gravity
Tail strike – the rotation is started before it is possible to lift-off, consequently angle of attack might be increased up to tail strike
learning.explanation: The chord line that passes through the geometric centre of the plan area of an aerofoil is the Mean Aerodynamic Chord (MAC) and for any planform is equal to the chord of a rectangular wing having the same wing span and the same pitching moment and lift. The MAC is often used to reference the location of the centre of gravity. Tail strike – the rotation is started before it is possible to lift-off, consequently angle of attack might be increased up to tail strike. In this case, a 12% CG position will tend to hold the nose down (nose-heavy). To counter this, the pilots need to set a nose up trim in order to create a nose-up pitching moment at rotation. The actual CG position is however more aft which will naturally help lifting the aircraft nose. This natural tendency, combined with a nose-up trim, will result in a tendency of the nose lifting of earlier than intended and faster, increasing the risk of a tail strike.

content.question: When a turn is initiated, adverse yaw is:

options.A: a momentary yawing motion opposite to the turn due to an incorrect differential aileron movement.
options.B: the tendency of an aeroplane to yaw in the same direction of turn due to the different wing speeds.
options.C: the tendency of an aeroplane to yaw in the opposite direction of turn mainly due to the difference in aileron form drag.
options.D: the tendency of an aeroplane to yaw in the opposite direction of turn mainly due to the difference in induced drag on each wing.

key_points: Adverse yaw is the tendency of an airplane to yaw in the opposite direction of the turn
For example, as you roll to the right, your aircraft may initially yaw to the left
When you roll your aircraft to the right, your right aileron goes up, and your left aileron goes down
learning.explanation: Adverse yaw is the tendency of an airplane to yaw in the opposite direction of the turn. For example, as you roll to the right, your aircraft may initially yaw to the left. When you roll your aircraft to the right, your right aileron goes up, and your left aileron goes down. The aileron in the upward position (the right aileron in this example) creates less lift and less drag than the aileron that is lowered. The aileron angled downward (the left aileron in this example) produces more drag and more lift, initially yawing the airplane in the opposite direction of your roll.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Consider the following airfoil sections. Which one produces the least amount of drag?

options.A: Figure 1
options.B: Figure 2
options.C: Figure 3
options.D: Figure 4

key_points: Trim Tabs (figure 1) A trim tab is a small adjustable surface set into the trailing edge of a main control surface
Its deflection is controlled by a trim wheel or electrical switch in the cockpit, arranged to operate in an instinctive sense
To maintain the primary control surface in its required position, the tab is moved in the opposite direction to the control surface until the tab moment balances the control surface hinge moment
learning.explanation: Trim Tabs (figure 1) A trim tab is a small adjustable surface set into the trailing edge of a main control surface. Its deflection is controlled by a trim wheel or electrical switch in the cockpit, arranged to operate in an instinctive sense. To maintain the primary control surface in its required position, the tab is moved in the opposite direction to the control surface until the tab moment balances the control surface hinge moment. Stabiliser Trim (figure 2) This system of trimming may be used on manually operated and power operated controls. To trim, the tailplane incidence is adjusted by the trim wheel until the tailplane load is equal to the previous elevator balancing load required. Stick force is now zero. The main advantages of a variable incidence (trimming) tailplane are: - The drag is less in the trimmed state as the aerofoil is more streamlined. - Trimming does not reduce the effective range of pitch control as the elevator remains approximately neutral when the aircraft is trimmed. - It is very powerful and gives an increased ability to trim for larger CG and speed range. The disadvantage of a variable incidence (trimming) tailplane is that it is more complex and is heavier than a conventional trim tab system. In this exercise, Figures 1 and 3 refer to trim tabs, and Figures 2 and 4 refer to stabiliser Trim. The least amount of drag would be produced by a stabiliser trim where the position of the elevator is neutral, which, in this case, is Figure 4.

content.question: When the CG position is moved aft, the elevator deflection required to achieve a given reduction in load factor will be...

options.A: smaller.
options.B: larger.
options.C: the same.
options.D: larger or smaller, depending on the position of the trim tab.

key_points: The static longitudinal stability of an airplane is defined by the tendency to return to equilibrium upon displacement
In other words, a stable airplane will resist displacement from it's trimmed speed
The control forces of the airplane should reflect the stability of the airplane and provide suitable reference to the pilot for precise control of the airplane
learning.explanation: The static longitudinal stability of an airplane is defined by the tendency to return to equilibrium upon displacement. In other words, a stable airplane will resist displacement from it's trimmed speed. The control forces of the airplane should reflect the stability of the airplane and provide suitable reference to the pilot for precise control of the airplane. The position of the CG not only affects the positive longitudinal static stability, it also affects the pitch handling characteristics. When the elevators are deflected, the pitching moment they produce must be greater than the restoring moment of the airplane’s positive longitudinal static stability. An aircraft has higher longitudinal stability with a forward CG (meaning the force and deflection required to make a pitch change is higher), so therefore an aft movement of CG decreases the stability (increases the manoeuvrability), providing the same change in load factor for a smaller control surface deflection.

content.question: To pitch a conventional aeroplane nose up, the pilot applies backpressure on the control column. This moves the elevator relatively..

options.A: downwards, increasing the positive camber of the tailplane and elevator.
options.B: upwards, increasing the positive camber of the tailplane and elevator.
options.C: upwards, increasing the negative camber of the tailplane and elevator.
options.D: downwards, increasing the negative camber of tailplane and elevator.

key_points: The pilot applies backpressure on the control column, this causes the nose to rise and, if enough thrust is present, the aircraft to climb
The control surface to cause the nose up movement is the elevator
The elevator is positioned behind the Center of Gravity, while the nose is positioned in front of it
learning.explanation: The pilot applies backpressure on the control column, this causes the nose to rise and, if enough thrust is present, the aircraft to climb. The control surface to cause the nose up movement is the elevator. The elevator is positioned behind the Center of Gravity, while the nose is positioned in front of it. Therefore, if the nose rises, the opposite action should happen at the tail. This is done by the elevator generating negative lift (also called downforce). The elevator does this by moving upwards, changing the aerodynamic camber of the tailplane to a negative camber. Whereas positive camber generates positive lift, negative camber generates negative lift. This effect pushes the tail (which is positioned behind the CG) downwards, which has an opposite reaction on the nose (in front of the CG), which comes up.

content.question: Which tab used in aerodynamic balancing moves in the same direction as the control surface and also increases control effectiveness?

options.A: Servo tab
options.B: Trim tab
options.C: Anti-balance tab
options.D: Balance tab

key_points: Because the hinge moment on some airplanes is too small, often as the result of the CP being too close to the hinge-line of the control surface, it is too easy to deflect the control surface against the aerodynamic load
Consequently, there is little control column load and there is a lack of feel to the controls
This could lead to excessive deflection of the control surface and result in serious overstressing of the airframe
learning.explanation: Because the hinge moment on some airplanes is too small, often as the result of the CP being too close to the hinge-line of the control surface, it is too easy to deflect the control surface against the aerodynamic load. Consequently, there is little control column load and there is a lack of feel to the controls. This could lead to excessive deflection of the control surface and result in serious overstressing of the airframe. To counteract these characteristics and assist the pilot to use the control surfaces correctly it is necessary to have anti-balance tabs fitted. These operate in the opposite sense to the balance tab by deflecting the anti-balance tab in the same direction as that of the primary control surface and increase the aerodynamic loading.

key_points: In all of the computations performed by the autopilot computer (the signals processor) “control laws” are taken into account
These determine how the control demands are translated into control movements - in other words the translation of computer input data to computer output control surface deflection data
Among control laws there are for example: high angle of attack, high speed, pitch attitude (30° pitch-up & 15° pitch-down), bank angle, load factor

These determine how the control demands are translated into control movements - in other words the translation of computer input data to computer output control surface deflection data. options.C: At a forward CG, the elevator is deflected upward and at an aft CG, it is deflected downward.
options.D: The position depends on speed, the position of flaps and slats and the position of the centre of gravity.

key_points: A trimmable horizontal stabilizer serves as both a stabilizer and a trim device
It allows for the adjustment of the angle of incidence during flight to trim the aircraft
In a power-assisted airplane, the stabilizer's position is influenced by factors such as speed, the configuration of slats and flaps, and the center of gravity
learning.explanation: A trimmable horizontal stabilizer serves as both a stabilizer and a trim device. It allows for the adjustment of the angle of incidence during flight to trim the aircraft. In a power-assisted airplane, the stabilizer's position is influenced by factors such as speed, the configuration of slats and flaps, and the center of gravity. The elevator deflection, in relation to the stabilizer position, may not always be zero because the control force on the control column needs to be balanced in a trimmed position. In a fully powered airplane, achieving a perfectly trimmed position for the elevator is not essential to zero out the force on the control column or stick in the cockpit. The artificial feel unit sets only the force on the controls to zero, while the elevator deflection is maintained at zero in comparison to the stabilizer position.

learning.explanation: Note: We have very minimal and broken feedback about this but a few reports of it coming up, so please read the exam question carefully and do report back if you had this in the exam, along with anything you can remember about it, thank you! This question is incredibly vague, and as yet we really don't know what the examiner wants from us, and the answer is not confirmed (we are not very sure of it either). In particular, we don't know how degraded the FBW system is, and what the options are regarding the control differences. FLY-BY-WIRE In a fly-by-wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer. The computer then processes these inputs and sends corresponding electrical signals to the servo valve which in turn controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator, which will hydraulically deflect a flight control surface. There are numerous advantages to fly by wire systems, including weight savings and safety features that can be incorporated into the computer software. FBW also enables highly reliable flight envelope protection systems which, provided the FBW system functions at its normal level, significantly enhances safety. Feedback control of airspeed, Mach Number, attitude, and angle of attack can be used to ensure that the FBW aircraft stays within its certificated flight envelope. FBW has multiple different modes of "control laws" which can be used. Normal Law - All control augmentations and protections are in place. Alternate Law - Some protections are lost, some features act differently to normal, and the autopilot may be lost (depending on the fault). Direct Law - In direct law, the pilot's controls are NOT augmented at all by the internal computers (for flight envelope protection, etc.), and the exact control movement is sent exactly as it is to the hydraulic servo valves. Autopilot is always lost. Stall and over speed warnings are still available. Mechanical back-up - Not really a control law at all, if FBW has failed, then all that is left is some form of mechanical back-up, for instance on the A320, it is some rudder control and manual trimming. Therefore, a large degradation of the aircraft, down to direct law or mechanical back-up will cause large changes in control for the pilots. It will often be quite a different aircraft to fly in this case. As for why the two aircraft might have different reactions to a degradation in FBW, we don't really know. We need more information to be able to dig into that.

key_points: Angle of attack is the difference between pitch attitude and flight path angle
It is defined as the angle between the chord of an airfoil and the relative wind
Flight path angle is the angle between the horizon and the flight path
learning.explanation: Angle of attack is the difference between pitch attitude and flight path angle. It is defined as the angle between the chord of an airfoil and the relative wind. Flight path angle is the angle between the horizon and the flight path. Also called climb or descent angle. Pitch angle is the angle between the horizon and longitudinal axis of the aircraft, it is equal to Flight path angle + Angle of attack. Bank angle is the angle between the lateral axis and the horizon. Bank is rotated around the longitudinal axis, but during a bank at level flight, the angle between the longitudinal axis and the horizon does not change. The angle between the lateral axis and horizon does.

content.question: Whilst performing a take-off in icing conditions, the aircraft nose feels heavy, and it takes a long time to rotate. What could have caused this?

options.A: Anti-icing fluid has built up between the elevator and horizontal stabiliser.
options.B: The control cables connecting the control column to the elevator have torn.
options.C: The ailerons have frozen in position.
options.D: The increased air density means insufficient thrust is being produced to reach VR.

key_points: This is an odd question as it is not mentioned in the current iteration of the learning objectives
For many candidates, this question is simply solved by removing the incorrect options and seeing what you have left: "Anti-icing fluid has built up between the elevator and horizontal stabiliser
" This is actually possible, and in fact there have been quite a few reports over the years of rejected take-offs at rotation when the aircraft has failed to rotate correctly after de-icing
learning.explanation: This is an odd question as it is not mentioned in the current iteration of the learning objectives. For many candidates, this question is simply solved by removing the incorrect options and seeing what you have left: "Anti-icing fluid has built up between the elevator and horizontal stabiliser." This is actually possible, and in fact there have been quite a few reports over the years of rejected take-offs at rotation when the aircraft has failed to rotate correctly after de-icing. So much so that EASA commissioned a report to be made, testing de-icing fluid and its effects on a horizontal stabiliser section. The build-up of thickening fluids on the front of the elevator can make it very resistive to movements during take-off, especially with manual flight controls. Although it is not in the current learning objectives, it seems that an examiner wants you to know about it. Thankfully, it is the only possible correct option. "The control cables connecting the control column to the elevator have torn." This would not be a case that is specific to icing conditions, and the cables tearing could cause a few different feelings on the control column, but most likely very light resistance to movement, not heavy. The aircraft also would not respond at all. "The ailerons have frozen in position." The ailerons provide roll control, so whilst this is a bad situation, a pilot would not notice that the nose was heavy, as the pitch is controlled by the elevators. "The increased air density means insufficient thrust is being produced to reach VR." Quite the other way, high air density due to the cold air would cause higher thrust from the engine, and better performance.

content.question: Where spoilers are used to assist ailerons with lateral control, when rolling to the right, the left aileron moves down and the right aileron moves up. How do the spoilers move?

options.A: The left spoilers remain flush and the right spoilers move up.
options.B: The left spoilers move up and the right spoilers remain flush.
options.C: The right spoilers and the left spoilers remain flush.
options.D: The right spoilers and the left spoilers move up.

key_points: Roll Spoilers operate asymmetrically in flight whenever the control wheel rotates, assisting the ailerons in providing roll control, particularly at high airspeeds
When this occurs, the appropriate spoiler servo valves are signaled by way of the aileron operating system and the requisite surfaces are deflected upward in proportion to the roll input

During a roll, the spoilers on the lowering wing deflect upward, decreasing the wing’s overall lifting capability and increasing the aircraft’s roll rate, whilst the spoilers on the opposite wing remain retracted
learning.explanation: Roll Spoilers operate asymmetrically in flight whenever the control wheel rotates, assisting the ailerons in providing roll control, particularly at high airspeeds. When this occurs, the appropriate spoiler servo valves are signaled by way of the aileron operating system and the requisite surfaces are deflected upward in proportion to the roll input. During a roll, the spoilers on the lowering wing deflect upward, decreasing the wing’s overall lifting capability and increasing the aircraft’s roll rate, whilst the spoilers on the opposite wing remain retracted. The innermost spoiler on the lowering wing also remains retracted to prevent tail buffet and degraded pitch control.

content.question: When comparing a trim tab with an anti-balance tab, which of the following statements is correct?The trim tab...

options.A: moves in the opposite direction to the control surface and the anti-balance tab moves in the same direction as the control surface.
options.B: is moved by pilot input and the anti-balance tab is moved by an electrical input.
options.C: moves in the same direction as the control surface and the anti-balance tab moves in the opposite direction to the control surface.
options.D: increases control effectiveness and the anti-balance tab reduces it.

key_points: Variable Trim Tabs Trim tabs are fitted to enable the pilot to set a required angle of deflection of the primary control surface and maintain that deflection
However, they are not suitable for jet airplanes because of their large range of operating speeds, preference, for this type of airplane, is given to the trimmable horizontal stabilizer
There are two types of trim tab in common use: the variable and the fixed
learning.explanation: Variable Trim Tabs Trim tabs are fitted to enable the pilot to set a required angle of deflection of the primary control surface and maintain that deflection. However, they are not suitable for jet airplanes because of their large range of operating speeds, preference, for this type of airplane, is given to the trimmable horizontal stabilizer. There are two types of trim tab in common use: the variable and the fixed. The variable trim tabs may be manually or electrically controlled. If manually controlled, then trim wheels located on the center console are used. For the elevator trim if the tab is deflected up the cockpit indication is nose-down and if the trim tab is deflected down the cockpit indication is nose-up. To remain in trim and maintain level flight following a deceleration the trimmer control is moved to give a nose-up movement that causes the trim tab to move down, which makes the elevator move up. This does not affect the static longitudinal stability. Anti-balance tab Because the hinge moment on some airplanes is too small, often as the result of the CP being too close to the hinge-line of the control surface, it is too easy to deflect the control surface against the aerodynamic load. Consequently, there is little control column load and there is a lack of feel to the controls. This could lead to excessive deflection of the control surface and result in serious overstressing of the airframe. To counteract these characteristics and assist the pilot to use the control surfaces correctly it is necessary to have anti-balance tabs fitted. These operate in the opposite sense to the balance tab by deflecting the anti-balance tab in the same direction as that of the primary control surface and increase the aerodynamic loading.

key_points: In flight, an aircraft can rotate about any one, or any combination of, its three axes
These axes are at right angles to each other and all pass through the aircraft’s centre of gravity
The moment around an axis is produced by changing the aerodynamic force on the appropriate aerofoil
learning.explanation: In flight, an aircraft can rotate about any one, or any combination of, its three axes. These axes are at right angles to each other and all pass through the aircraft’s centre of gravity. The moment around an axis is produced by changing the aerodynamic force on the appropriate aerofoil. The magnitude of the force is a product of the dynamic pressure (IAS) and the angular displacement of the control surface. Aerodynamic force can be changed by: - adjusting the camber of the aerofoil. - changing the incidence of the aerofoil. - decreasing lift and increasing drag by “spoiling” the airflow. Changing the camber of any aerofoil (wing, tailplane or fin) will change its lift. Deflecting a control surface effectively changes its camber. AILERONS The primary effect of ailerons is to provide roll control about the longitudinal axis A downward movement of the aileron causes an increase in the effective angle of attack and a corresponding increase in lift, whilst an upward movement of the aileron causes a reduction in the effective angle of attack and a decrease in lift. The difference in lift between the two wings produces the necessary rolling moment.

key_points: The force required to operate the primary control surfaces, even using balance tabs, is often too great to be acceptable
To relieve the pilot of the need to apply so much force to operate the controls servo-tabs are fitted to carry out this function
The servo-tab is a small tab hinged on the trailing edge of the primary control surface and linked directly to the control column
learning.explanation: The force required to operate the primary control surfaces, even using balance tabs, is often too great to be acceptable. To relieve the pilot of the need to apply so much force to operate the controls servo-tabs are fitted to carry out this function. The servo-tab is a small tab hinged on the trailing edge of the primary control surface and linked directly to the control column. There is no direct link between the control column and the primary control surface. The function and operation of the servo-tab is the same as the balance tab and moves the trim tab in the opposite direction to the movement of the primary control surface. However, at low IAS the servo-tab makes the main control surface less effective. The position of a servo-controlled primary control surface cannot be determined until a positive pressure is applied to the servo-tab by the airflow.

content.question: A jet transport aeroplane exhibits pitch up when thrust is suddenly increased from an equilibrium condition, because the thrust line is below the:

options.A: drag line of action.
options.B: neutral point.
options.C: centre of pressure.
options.D: CG.

key_points: POWER EFFECTS Its effects may cause significant changes in trim left coefficient and static longitudinal stability
The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability

If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust)
learning.explanation: POWER EFFECTS Its effects may cause significant changes in trim left coefficient and static longitudinal stability. The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability. If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust). Creating an unstable situation. Therefore, the effect is destabilizing. If the thrust line is above the CG, this is the opposite of the above and a thrust increase will produce a nose down moment (negative moment), and, in moderate amounts, can have a stabilising effect. The airplane will settle at a higher speed, which is presumably what the pilot wants (despite the "power controls altitude" mantra). When the line is too high, the airplane may even descend and accelerate more than necessary, until the aerodynamic moment balances out the thrust moment, but overall the condition is stable. Thrust is in line with CG. The airplane will start to climb (or reduce descent) and will settle on the same AoA and roughly the same speed.

content.question: What is required on a fly-by-wire aircraft, but not on one with hydraulically assisted controls?

options.A: A joystick.
options.B: An actuator control system.
options.C: An artificial feel unit.
options.D: A flight control lock.

key_points: There are 4 main types of control system: Manual - cables and pulleys connect the flight controls to the control surfaces directly
The only power supplied is by the pilot
Power assisted controls - The pilot is mechanically connected to the controls, but any force they exert will be assisted by extra force from the hydraulics
learning.explanation: There are 4 main types of control system: Manual - cables and pulleys connect the flight controls to the control surfaces directly. The only power supplied is by the pilot. Power assisted controls - The pilot is mechanically connected to the controls, but any force they exert will be assisted by extra force from the hydraulics. Similar to powered steering in a car. Fully powered controls - The flight controls physically move a servo valve which directs hydraulic pressure to the controls. No computers involved, but hydraulic pressure is absolutely required. Fly-by-wire - The flight control movements are interpreted by a computer which electronically controls the hydraulic servo valves to move the control surfaces. The hydraulics still provide the power to move the control surfaces, but a computer sits between the pilot and the hydraulics, checking and modifying the requested movements. Fly-by-wire and fully powered controls are "irreversible", meaning that there is no feedback from the control surfaces to the pilot. This means that an artificial feel system has to be installed, so the pilot can feel the correct amount of resistance when moving the controls. This is not the case on manual or power assisted control systems, which have natural feedback to the flight controls. Fly-by-wire systems do not have to be joystick controlled. Aircraft such as the B777 are controlled by yoke, but are fly-by-wire, whereas the modern Airbus aircraft use joysticks.

At low speeds, both the inboard and the outboard ailerons are controllable but once the aircraft gains speed (usually when the flaps are all the way up) only the inboard ailerons respond to control input
At high speeds, when the forces are greater and could cause greater structural distortion, outboard (low-speed) ailerons are "locked-out" as the flaps retract
learning.explanation: OUTBOARD AND INBOARD AILERONS Two sets of ailerons may be fitted, one at the wing tips (outboard ailerons) and one set inboard (inboard ailerons). At low speeds, both the inboard and the outboard ailerons are controllable but once the aircraft gains speed (usually when the flaps are all the way up) only the inboard ailerons respond to control input. At high speeds, when the forces are greater and could cause greater structural distortion, outboard (low-speed) ailerons are "locked-out" as the flaps retract.

content.question: To side slip an aircraft to the right, the pilot would apply:

options.A: Control column right, rudder right.
options.B: Control column left, rudder right.
options.C: Control column right, rudder left.
options.D: Control column left, rudder left.

key_points: Intentional slip, either forward slip or sideslip, is an intentional cross control manoeuver in which the pilot has made an aileron input in one direction with a simultaneous rudder input in the opposite direction
To side slip and aircraft to the right, left rudder must be applied to yaw the aircraft to the left
The secondary effect of a left yaw will be a left roll
learning.explanation: Intentional slip, either forward slip or sideslip, is an intentional cross control manoeuver in which the pilot has made an aileron input in one direction with a simultaneous rudder input in the opposite direction. To side slip and aircraft to the right, left rudder must be applied to yaw the aircraft to the left. The secondary effect of a left yaw will be a left roll. To prevent this secondary effect, right aileron must be applied simultaneously.

content.question: The stabiliser of an aircraft, whose CG is within the normal range, is mistakenly set with its leading edge at a more positive angle of incidence than required. As a result the pilot will encounter...

options.A: lighter-than-normal control forces requiring a longer take-off run.
options.B: higher-than-normal control forces but would require a shorter take-off run.
options.C: lighter-than-normal control forces, which may lead to over-rotation.
options.D: higher-than-normal control forces, which may lead to a later-than-normal lift-off.

key_points: The position of the CG directly affects the amount of trim necessary for the angle of attack required
A forward CG adds to the inherent longitudinal stability of the airplane; the pilot may run out of elevator up movement and be unable to maintain the required attitude
An aft CG decreases the longitudinal stability and makes the airplane more difficult or impossible to control in pitch
learning.explanation: The position of the CG directly affects the amount of trim necessary for the angle of attack required. A forward CG adds to the inherent longitudinal stability of the airplane; the pilot may run out of elevator up movement and be unable to maintain the required attitude. An aft CG decreases the longitudinal stability and makes the airplane more difficult or impossible to control in pitch. The CG must always remain within the CG safe envelope to ensure that the airplane remains controllable in all phases of flight. The elevator trim or stabilizer trim setting must be preset to a value for take-off and initial climb that will ensure a minimum stick force during this critical stage of flight. Usually, there is a graph in the airplane performance manual from which the setting appropriate to the total mass and CG position for take-off can be determined. Factors that affect the stabilizer trim position for take-off are: CG position Take-off mass Flap setting In comparison with a correctly balanced airplane during take-off, the position of the stabilizer for a nose-heavy airplane requires nose-up trim from a decreased stabilizer angle of incidence.

content.question: When an aeroplane wing’s angle of attack is increased, downwash causes the horizontal tailplane to experience...

options.A: a lower increase in angle of attack.
options.B: an initial lower angle of attack which then increases.
options.C: the same increase in angle of attack.
options.D: a higher increase in angle of attack.

key_points: The downwash of the airstream over the upper surface of the mainplane directly influences the effectiveness of the elevators of a fuselage-mounted tail plane
A change of downwash alters the effective angle of attack of the tail plane and the lift that it generates
This changes the pitching moment of the tail plane and requires a deflection of the elevators to maintain a given attitude
learning.explanation: The downwash of the airstream over the upper surface of the mainplane directly influences the effectiveness of the elevators of a fuselage-mounted tail plane. A change of downwash alters the effective angle of attack of the tail plane and the lift that it generates. This changes the pitching moment of the tail plane and requires a deflection of the elevators to maintain a given attitude. For example, if a pitch-up attitude causes the angle of the downwash to increase then the effective angle of attack of the tail plane is decreased. Consequently, the restoring moment of the tail plane is decreased, and the longitudinal static stability is diminished. If such were the case the aircraft designer would have to move the CG forward to regain the longitudinal static stability of the airplane. Note: In the figure, the "low speed" as a similar effect to a higher angle of attack.

However, they are not suitable for jet airplanes because of their large range of operating speeds, preference, for this type of airplane, is given to the trimmable horizontal stabilizer
There are two types of trim tab in common use: the variable and the fixed
learning.explanation: Trim tabs are fitted to enable the pilot to set a required angle of deflection of the primary control surface and maintain that deflection. However, they are not suitable for jet airplanes because of their large range of operating speeds, preference, for this type of airplane, is given to the trimmable horizontal stabilizer. There are two types of trim tab in common use: the variable and the fixed. The variable trim tabs may be manually or electrically controlled. If manually controlled, then trim wheels located on the center console are used. For the elevator trim if the tab is deflected up the cockpit indication is nose-down and if the trim tab is deflected down the cockpit indication is nose-up. content.question: In addition to ailerons, spoilers might be used at the same time to assist in lateral control. When doing so, how will the spoilers behave?

options.A: Down-going wing spoilers rise proportionally to aileron input, disturbing the airflow over the wing, reducing lift, and creating a roll moment.
options.B: Down-going wing spoilers fully rise with aileron input, disturbing the airflow over the wing, reducing lift, and creating a roll moment.
options.C: Up-going wing spoilers rise proportionally to aileron input, locally increasing drag, assisting to counteracting adverse yaw.
options.D: Up-going wing spoilers fully rise with aileron input, increasing total drag, reducing lift, and creating a roll moment.

key_points: Spoilers are panels on the upper wing surface that are movable
They are hinged at the forward edge and are used to disturb the airflow over the wing to reduce lift
They will also increase drag on the wing when raised
learning.explanation: Spoilers are panels on the upper wing surface that are movable. They are hinged at the forward edge and are used to disturb the airflow over the wing to reduce lift. They will also increase drag on the wing when raised. When turning, the downward-going wing will experience a decrease in lift with an upward-going aileron. This decrease in lift can be assisted by raising the spoiler as well. Raising the spoiler on the downward-going wing also increases drag on that wing, which helps to counter adverse yaw. The degree of spoiler that needs to be raised varies proportionally to the aileron input, allowing for versatility in adding drag and decreasing lift. At the same time, the spoiler on the upward-going wing will remain flush.

content.question: Artificial feel systems are installed in aircraft with (1) _____, which prevent the pilot from (2) _____ the aircraft.

options.A: (1) fully-powered controls, (2) overstressing
options.B: (1) reversable controls, (2) overstressing
options.C: (1) fully-powered controls, (2) stalling
options.D: (1) reversable controls, (2) stalling

key_points: With a fully powered flying control the pilot is unaware of the aerodynamic force on the controls, so it is necessary to incorporate “artificial feel" to prevent the aircraft from being overstressed
As shown schematically in the diagram, a device sensitive to dynamic pressure (1⁄2 ρ V2)
Pitot pressure is fed to one side of a chamber and static pressure to the other, which moves a diaphragm under the influence of changing dynamic pressure with airspeed
learning.explanation: With a fully powered flying control the pilot is unaware of the aerodynamic force on the controls, so it is necessary to incorporate “artificial feel" to prevent the aircraft from being overstressed. As shown schematically in the diagram, a device sensitive to dynamic pressure (1⁄2 ρ V2). Pitot pressure is fed to one side of a chamber and static pressure to the other, which moves a diaphragm under the influence of changing dynamic pressure with airspeed. This causes “regulated” hydraulic pressure to provide a resistance or ‘feel’ on the pilot’s input controls proportional to IAS2, just as in a manual control. In addition, stick force should increase as stick displacement increases. An advantage of artificial feel is that it can be configured to provide envelope protection, which prevents the pilot over stressing the aircraft. The Boeing777 fly- by-wire system employs envelope protection. This feature of the artificial-feel system provides increasingly greater force when the aircraft is pushed to its limits.

content.question: For a given aeroplane mass, a more aft CG position will...

options.A: decrease the take-off distance and improve the take-off climb performance.
options.B: increase the take-off distance and reduce the take-off climb performance.
options.C: increase the take-off distance and improve the take-off climb performance.
options.D: decrease the take-off distance and reduce the take-off climb performance.

key_points: CG position VS Aircraft’s performance A tail down force (created by the elevator) exists to balance the moment created between the CG and CP of the wing
Essentially, the tail works as an upside down wing which generates lift downwards
The amount of lift it needs to generate will depend on CG position and aircraft weight
learning.explanation: CG position VS Aircraft’s performance A tail down force (created by the elevator) exists to balance the moment created between the CG and CP of the wing. Essentially, the tail works as an upside down wing which generates lift downwards. The amount of lift it needs to generate will depend on CG position and aircraft weight. Consequently, when the CG moves forward and aft, tail down force and lift required for a stable flight will change. FORWARD CG increases the pitch down moment tendency of the aircraft. Therefore, greater horizontal stabilizer and elevator deflections are needed to give the aircraft a pitch-up attitude to compensate for the pitch-down moment. Extra lift is generated by increasing the angle of attack, which in turn increases induced drag. Thus performance decreases. For take-off, if the CG position is too far forward, the aircraft is said to have a “heavy nose”. Conversely, as the CG MOVES REARWARD, the aircraft will experience a reduced pitch down moment tendency, resulting in less tail-down force being required. As a consequence, drag decreases (and so does stalling speed) which improves performance. Since Climb gradient is a product of excess of thrust over drag, climb performance will be improved. For take-off, if the CG position is too far aft, the aircraft is said to have a “light nose” making the rotation easier. Additionally, an aircraft which requires less lift will have a slower rotation speed, which results in a reduced take-off distance. To simplify this concept and make it easier to answer these type of question you can think of a forward CG as having the same effects as a heavy aircraft; and an aft CG as having the same result as a light aircraft.

learning.explanation: The static longitudinal stability of an airplane is defined by the tendency to return to equilibrium upon displacement. In other words, a stable airplane will resist displacement from trim or equilibrium. The control forces of the airplane should reflect the stability of the airplane and provide suitable reference to the pilot for precise control of the airplane. The position of the CG not only affects the positive longitudinal static stability, it also affects the pitch handling characteristics. When the elevators are deflected, the pitching moment they produce must be greater than the restoring moment of the airplane’s positive longitudinal static stability. For any given elevator deflection there is a small response if the aircraft CG is located forward (i.e. stable condition) and a large response for the same angle of deflection when the aircraft CG is located at an aft position (i.e. a less-stable condition). The elevator deflection required to counter a forward CG movement during a maneuver having a load factor greater than one is increased.

content.question: If the thrust line is above the CG, how will this affect the airplane?

options.A: Pitch down, stabilising.
options.B: Pitch down, destabilising.
options.C: Pitch up, stabilizing.
options.D: Pitch up, destabilising.

key_points: POWER EFFECTS Its effects may cause significant changes in trim left coefficient and static longitudinal stability
The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability

If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust)
learning.explanation: POWER EFFECTS Its effects may cause significant changes in trim left coefficient and static longitudinal stability. The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability. If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust). Creating an unstable situation. Therefore, the effect is destabilizing. If the thrust line is above the CG, this is the opposite of the above and a thrust increase will produce a nose down moment (negative moment), and, in moderate amounts, can have a stabilising effect. The airplane will settle at a higher speed, which is presumably what the pilot wants (despite the "power controls altitude" mantra). When the line is too high, the airplane may even descend and accelerate more than necessary, until the aerodynamic moment balances out the thrust moment, but overall the condition is stable. Thrust is in line with CG. The airplane will start to climb (or reduce descent) and will settle on the same AoA and roughly the same speed.

content.question: A transport aircraft has to carry some heavy cargo aft of the CG location. The cargo would ideally be placed further forwards within the aircraft, but it is very difficult to move. The Captain verifies that the aircraft is within CG limits currently, and continues with the flight preparation. What is the effect on stick force stability and how does the leading edge of the variable-incidence horizontal stabiliser move due to this cargo?

options.A: Stick force stability is increased and the stabiliser leading edge moves down.
options.B: Stick force stability is increased and the stabiliser leading edge moves up.
options.C: Stick force stability is decreased and the stabiliser leading edge moves up.
options.D: Stick force stability is decreased and the stabiliser leading edge moves down.

key_points: Weight and CG location massively affect the handling characteristics of an aircraft
When the aircraft's CG (Centre of Gravity) is located far forwards within the aircraft, the aircraft's stability is high, and its manoeuvrability is low
When the CG is located further aft, the aircraft is less stable, but more manoeuvrable
learning.explanation: Weight and CG location massively affect the handling characteristics of an aircraft. When the aircraft's CG (Centre of Gravity) is located far forwards within the aircraft, the aircraft's stability is high, and its manoeuvrability is low. When the CG is located further aft, the aircraft is less stable, but more manoeuvrable. Pitch manoeuvrability is measured by the "stick force per G" (stick force stability), meaning how much force the pilot needs to apply to the controls to gain an extra 1G of vertical acceleration. The higher the stick force stability, the lower the manoeuvrability, so in this question, as the CG has been moved aft by the cargo, the manoeuvrability will be increased, so the stick force stability will decrease. The second part of this question is about the aircraft's trim in relation to the CG location. Most large jet aircraft calculate different pitch trim settings to use for take-off, depending on the position of the CG and the take-off mass of the aircraft. This is so the pilot can always feel roughly the same force when rotating the aircraft, and during the first phase of flight. The trim is often done (and in this question certainly done) by an all moving tailplane, known as a variable-incidence horizontal stabiliser, so the whole stabiliser moves to perform the act of trimming. If the aircraft has a far forward CG location, the nose will feel heavy to the pilot, so during the setup, the pilots will set a much more nose-up trim setting, so that at rotation, the feeling will be roughly the same. This is what the question is referring to. Adding extra cargo behind the CG will move the CG backwards, making the aircraft more tail heavy. This will require more nose-down stabiliser trim to feel the same on take-off. A nose-down stabiliser trim is caused by providing less downforce (or extra lift force) on the tail. That is created by setting the horizontal stabiliser at a higher angle, with its leading edge pointing more upwards. This will be the same during the cruise, where less nose down moment will be required, so the leading edge of the stabiliser will be pointing more upwards than if the cargo was not loaded.

options.C: (1)down; (2) down; (3) left.

key_points: Adverse yaw is a yawing motion opposite to the turning/rolling motion of the aircraft
Adverse yaw is caused by the drag on the down-going aileron being greater than that on the up-going aileron
This imbalance in drag causes the yawing motion around the normal/vertical axis
learning.explanation: Adverse yaw is a yawing motion opposite to the turning/rolling motion of the aircraft. Adverse yaw is caused by the drag on the down-going aileron being greater than that on the up-going aileron. This imbalance in drag causes the yawing motion around the normal/vertical axis. Since this yaw is adverse (i.e., in a banked turn to the left, the yaw is to the right), it is opposing the turn, which is detrimental to the aircraft's performance. To counter adverse yaw, some aircraft incorporate aileron/rudder coupling which is a system that automatically applies a rudder input in a turn to counter the adverse yawing moments generated by the ailerons. In a right turn, the left wing lift is increased by lowering the aileron. As we have described above, increased lift, increases induced drag, which generates a yawing moment in the opposite direction. As a result, the aircraft will be in an unbalanced turn. To re-balance the turn, right rudder must be applied.

content.question: How is adverse yaw compensated for during entry into and roll out from a turn?

options.A: Horn balanced controls.
options.B: Differential aileron deflection.
options.C: Servo tabs.
options.D: Anti-balanced rudder control.

key_points: Adverse yaw is a yawing motion opposite to the turning/rolling motion of the aircraft
Adverse yaw is caused by the drag on the down-going aileron being greater than that on the up-going aileron
This imbalance in drag causes the yawing motion around the normal/vertical axis
learning.explanation: Adverse yaw is a yawing motion opposite to the turning/rolling motion of the aircraft. Adverse yaw is caused by the drag on the down-going aileron being greater than that on the up-going aileron. This imbalance in drag causes the yawing motion around the normal/vertical axis. Since this yaw is adverse (i.e., in a banked turn to the left, the yaw is to the right), it is opposing the turn, which is detrimental to the aircraft's performance. Adverse (aileron) yaw is corrected in the design by the use of either differential ailerons or Frise ailerons. The differential aileron deflection system ensures that the drag generated by both ailerons when rolling into or out of a turn is equal, thus eliminating adverse yaw. This is achieved by constructing the aileron system such that the angular deflection of the upgoing aileron is always proportionately greater than the deflection of the down going aileron.

We appreciate your assistance. 081.05.07.01.01: Explain which parameters may be controlled in level flight with the pitch control law. Fly-by-wire is a sophisticated system that substitutes the traditional manual-mechanical flight controls of an aircraft with an electronic interface. Within this system, a computer interface is interposed between the pilots and the final control surfaces. Modern commercial fly-by-wire aircraft integrate a flight-envelope protection system into their flight control software, which is housed within the flight control computer. This protection system serves the crucial role of preventing pilots from issuing control commands that could push the aircraft beyond its structural and aerodynamic operational boundaries. In the realm of fly-by-wire technology, the concept of flight envelope and maneuvering envelope protections is employed. These are governed by predefined control laws that serve as a set of rules, guiding the computers in transforming input signals. One of the most commonly used control laws involves managing the load factor in pitch control. Essentially, this means that the trimmable horizontal stabilizer (THS) adjusts its position to maintain a specific load factor. When the pilot manipulates the sidestick, the THS moves accordingly, altering the load factor proportionally to the sidestick's deflection (refer to the attached diagram). This means that as long as the sidestick remains untouched, the aircraft will maintain its flight-path-angle-corrected load factor. For example, if the aircraft is in straight and level flight and the pilot pulls the sidestick, the aircraft will follow a curved trajectory, increasing its pitch angle until the sidestick is released.

options.B: The elevator is used only to trim an aeroplane and is normally operated by a dedicated control wheel, which is usually situated close to the throttle.
options.C: The elevator is the primary control surface for control about the longitudinal axis and is operated by a forward or backward movement of the control wheel or stick.
options.D: The elevator is the primary control surface for control about the lateral axis and is operated by a forward or backward movement of the control wheel or stick.

key_points: Control of the airplane about its lateral axis, or pitch control, is accomplished by using the elevators
The elevators are hinged control surfaces located on the horizontal tail plane usually at the rear of the airplane
A forward movement of the control column (stick) by the pilot will cause the elevators to go down and a backward movement will cause them to go up
learning.explanation: Control of the airplane about its lateral axis, or pitch control, is accomplished by using the elevators. The elevators are hinged control surfaces located on the horizontal tail plane usually at the rear of the airplane. A forward movement of the control column (stick) by the pilot will cause the elevators to go down and a backward movement will cause them to go up. The effect produced by the elevators is to increase the camber of the tail plane when the stick is pushed forward, which causes an increase of tail plane lift and an upward force on the underside of the control surface that results in the airplane rotating about its lateral axis through the CG and the nose being depressed. The opposite is true when the stick is pulled back, the camber is negative, and the lift generated is downward which when trimmed becomes the counterbalancing force required for longitudinal equilibrium.

Adverse yaw is a yawing motion with an opposite direction to the turning/rolling motion of the aircraft. Adverse yaw is caused by the drag on the down-going aileron being greater than that on the up-going aileron. This is because the down-going aileron is effectively acting like a trailing edge flap with high camber, so higher drag, but the up-going aileron is reducing the camber of the wing, so has a lower drag. This imbalance in drag causes the yawing motion around the normal/vertical axis. Since this yaw is adverse (i.e., in a banked turn to the left, the yaw is to the right), it is opposing the turn, which is detrimental to the aircraft's performance and may cause uncoordinated turns. Adverse (aileron) yaw is corrected in the design by the use of either differential ailerons, Frise ailerons or aileron/rudder coupling. The differential aileron system counteracts adverse yaw by making the draggy down-going aileron go proporitonally less far, so a smaller angular change, than the low drag up-going aileron. This means that the up-going aileron does more of the work, and therefore produces a similar amount of drag to the other aileron, and the aircraft roll rate is the same. This could mean, for instance, that the up-going aileron moves 30% further upwards than the down-going aileron goes downwards. For this question, BE VERY CAREFUL. The higher drag down-going aileron is on the UP-GOING WING. This means that; The up-going wing produces a greater amount of drag when normal ailerons are fitted. The differential ailerons will therefore make the aileron on that wing move less far to counteract the adverse yaw effect.

In any conventional aircraft, the application of rudder will cause some secondary effect of roll, usually towards the direction that the rudder was applied. This effect is very strong in swept wing aircraft, and very noticeable when flying them, hence the reason most jets of this kind are flown without the use of the rudder pedals except for engine failures and crosswind take-offs and landings. Using full rudder deflection only to intercept the final approach course is a terrible idea as the aircraft will violently roll to the right. This is because the left wing will be significantly accelerated through a much longer arc that the right wing, which conversely gets a much reduced speed of airflow during that motion, causing a large right wing drop, and the right wing could even stall if the effect were large enough to increase the right wing's angle of attack above the critical AoA. As for the other answers: The left wing would not stall as there is greater airspeed over it and with no significant increase of angle of attack. Adverse yaw is a secondary effect which occurs when ailerons are used for roll purposes, so does not really apply to this situation. There is indeed a potential for loss of control to occur in this scenario, but we think this answer is way too vague (and the feedback was also not 100% about the wording here so we can't confirm it yet) so for now we are saying this is less correct than the potential for the right wing stalling.

learning.explanation: The three axes of an airplane intersect at the center of gravity (CG) and are those about which an airplane moves in flight. They are the longitudinal, the lateral and the normal axes. If the forces about any axis are not balanced there will be an angular acceleration and the airplane will rotate about that axis. The horizontal straight line joining the most forward point of the fuselage of the airplane, the center of the nose, to the center of the most rearward point of the airplane’s fuselage is the longitudinal axis. It is often referred to as the roll axis because the airplane, in response to a control input by the pilot or as the result of an external disturbance, drops one wing and raises the other. Thus, it rotates or rolls about the longitudinal axis. The flight controls enable the pilot to rotate the airplane about its three axes. The ailerons and the rudder cause the airplane to roll about its longitudinal axis, the elevators enable the airplane to pitch around its lateral axis and the rudder allows the airplane to yaw around its normal axis.

Weight and CG location massively affect the handling characteristics of an aircraft. This is why most large jet aircraft calculate different pitch trim settings to use for take-off, depending on the position of the CG and the take-off mass of the aircraft. This is so the pilot can always feel roughly the same force when rotating the aircraft, and during the first phase of flight. This is what the question is referring to. Adding extra fuel behind the CG will move the CG backwards, making the aircraft more tail heavy.
